Description: DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A TRANSDISCIPLINARY APPROACH TO EVALUATE AND MITIGATE THE CUMULATIVE HEALTH CONSEQUENCES OF CHEMICAL AND PSYCHOSOCIAL STRESSORS TO CHILDREN'S HEALTH THROUGH A COMMUNITY DRIVEN PARTICIPATORY FRAMEWORK. ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ASSES THE IMPACTS OF EARLY LIFE STAGE HEALTH STRESSORS AND CREATE NEW MODELS AND LANGUAGE TO ENCOMPASS THE DATA DRIVEN INSIGHTS. THIS PROJECT WILL 1) DOCUMENT AND EVALUATE THE CUMULATIVE IMPACT OF CHILDREN'S LOW-DOSE CHRONIC PESTICIDE EXPOSURE; 2) COMPARE EARLY-LIFE MICROBIOME WITH ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSOR EXPOSURES; AND 3) DEVELOP A STATEWIDE, CUMULATIVE IMPACT ASSESSMENT TO MITIGATE CHEMICAL AND NON CHEMICAL STRESSOR EXPOSURE.SUBRECIPIENT:THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE FARMWORKER ASSOCIATION OF FLORIDA (FWAW) WITH A SUBAWARD ($116,649) TO SERVE THE TRANSLATION CORE WITH COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND PUBLIC HEALTH OUTREACH TO THE FARMWORKER POPULATION IN IMMOKALEE, FLORIDA.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS DETAILING THE CORRELATIONS BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS AND CHILDHOOD DEVELOPMENT, EVALUATIONS OF MICROBIOME EFFECTS, AND A PUBLIC HEALTH CUMULATIVE IMPACT ASSESSMENT. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, FARM WORKERS, AND STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICIALS

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE USE OF LOW-COST SENSORS AND AMBIENT AIR MONITORING TO BETTER QUANTIFY SPATIOTEMPORAL VARIATIONS OF LANDFILL METHANE EMISSIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) DEVELOP LOW-COST AIR QUALITY SENSORS TO CAPTURE METHANE VARIATION SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY; 2) INTEGRATE SENSOR DATA FROM FIXED LOCATIONS, MOBILE SAMPLING, AND DRONE SURVEYS TO MAP POLLUTION DISTRIBUTION AND ESTIMATE EMISSION FLUXES; AND 3) CORRELATE THE SPATIOTEMPORALLY RESOLVED METHANE EMISSION DATA WITH MULTIPLE ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS FOR EVALUATING METHANE REDUCTION TECHNIQUES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS INCLUDE INTEGRATING SAMPLING TECHNOLOGIES FOR METHANE EMISSION QUANTIFICATION. THE DATASETS WILL INFORM LANDFILL OPERATIONS, METHANE EMISSION MODELS AND METHANE REDUCTION TECHNIQUES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED BY THE LANDFILL STUDY SITES IN IN MIAMI, FLORIDA AS WELL THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO ARE AFFECTED BY METHANE'S CONTRIBUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

DESCRIPTION:THE OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO ASSESS THE PERFORMANCE AND FEASIBILITY TRADEOFFS OF INTEGRATING MEASUREMENTS ACROSS MEASUREMENT PLATFORMS TO ASSESS EMISSIONS AND MITIGATION OF METHANE AND VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS) FROM LANDFILLS. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL: 1) ASSESS THE UNCERTAINTY IN LANDFILL METHANE EMISSIONS AT A REPRESENTATIVE SET OF THREE LANDFILLS USING A COMBINATION OF GROUND-BASED, AIRCRAFT, AND SATELLITE TOOLS; 2) DEVELOP METHANE EMISSIONS DATA FOR THREE DIFFERENT LANDFILLS FROM INTERANNUAL DOWN TO AN HOURLY TEMPORAL RESOLUTION, AND USE IT TO IMPROVE METHANE EMISSIONS MODELS; 3) DEVELOP A LANDFILL VOC EMISSIONS DATA SET THAT CAN BE USED TO ESTIMATE SPECIATED EMISSIONS BASED ON WASTE AND ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS; 4) ASSESS INEXPENSIVE GROUND-BASED SYSTEMS TO ROUTINELY MONITOR VOCS; AND 5) ASSESS THE ABILITY OF VARIOUS MEASUREMENT SYSTEMS TO OBSERVE THE PERFORMANCE OF REAL-WORLD EMISSIONS MITIGATIONS. SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO FORT LEWIS WILL BE FOR $50,000. THEY WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE DESIGN, FABRICATION, AND APPLICATION OF DYNAMIC FLUX CHAMBERS FOR USE IN MEASUREMENT LANDFILL GAS FLUXES.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE DATASETS OF TEMPORALLY AND SPATIALLY RESOLVED METHANE AND VOC SPECIES CONCENTRATIONS SPANNING 0.5-1.5 YEARS FOR THREE LANDFILLS AS WELL DATASETS OF METHANE AND VOC SPECIES EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ADVANCEMENTS IN APPROACHES OF QUANTIFYING LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF FACTORS THAT AFFECT EMISSIONS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED FROM LANDFILLS TO BE STUDIES AS WELL THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO ARE AFFECTED BY METHANE'S CONTRIBUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEMONSTRATE AND STANDARDIZE EXISTING INVERSE MODELING AND SPATIAL MAPPING METHODS FOR IDENTIFYING HOTSPOTS OF METHANE AND OTHER HEALTH IMPACTING GASES RELEASED FROM LANDFILLS AND TO MONITOR AND QUANTIFY THESE EMISSIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) DEPLOY HIGH-SENSITIVITY LASER-BASED SENSORS TO MEASURE METHANE AT STRATEGIC LOCATIONS FOR TWO FULL YEARS AT DOWNWIND LOCATIONS OF FOUR LANDFILLS IN THE UNITED STATES; 2) DEPLOY SENSORS TO MEASURE LANDFILL GAS RELEASES THAT IMPACT LOCAL AIR QUALITY, INCLUDING AMMONIA, HYDROGEN SULFIDE AND ODORS, FOR TWO FULL YEARS AT THE SAME SITES AS THE METHANE SENSORS; 3) COLLECT COMPLEMENTARY DATA ON CARBON DIOXIDE, AMMONIA, AND HYDROGEN SULFIDE WITH THE LASER-BASED METHANE SENSOR TO DEMONSTRATE THE APPLICATION OF THE METHODS TO OTHER LANDFILL GASES; 4) USE PARALLEL DRONE-BASED MAPPING METHODS TO MAP METHANE CONCENTRATIONS ABOVE AND AROUND LANDFILLS TO IDENTIFY HOT SPOTS AND IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF FUGITIVE EMISSIONS; AND 5) APPLY THE MONITORING DATA IN AN INVERSE ATMOSPHERIC TRANSPORT MODEL TO QUANTIFY LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND FOR CALCULATING THE IMPACT FROM ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABLES AND LANDFILL OPERATIONS ON EMISSIONS.SUBRECIPIENT:ST. LOUIS UNIVERSITY ($199,701) WILL COMPLETE THE DRONE MEASUREMENTS AND THE METEOROLOGICAL ANALYSES THAT WILL BE USED IN THE PROJECT.  ST. LOUIS UNIVERSITY WILL ALSO CONDUCT THE INVERSE MODELING ANALYSIS, DATA ANALYSIS, AND THE PREPARATION OF REPORT, PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS COVER THE PROJECT RESULTS AND FINDINGS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS INCLUDE ADVANCEMENTS IN METHODS FOR MONITORING LANDFILL GAS EMISSIONS, ADVANCEMENTS IN DRONE-BASED APPROACHES FOR IDENTIFYING HOT SPOTS AND PROCESSES THAT LEAD TO HIGH EMISSIONS, AND IDENTIFICATION OF FACTORS THAT AFFECT LANDFILL EMISSIONS AND EFFECTIVENESS OF MITIGATION STRATEGIES TO REDUCE EMISSIONS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS EMITTED FROM LANDFILLS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AND HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

DESCRIPTION:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A WEB-BASED DECISION SUPPORT TOOL TO GUIDE COMMUNITIES, AGENCIES, AND PRACTITIONERS IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF EAR IN DEEP, CONFINED AQUIFERS.
ACTIVITIES:FOUR EXPERIMENTS ARE PROPOSED (COMBINED WITH MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION) TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES. EXPERIMENTS ARE DESIGNED TO REVEAL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE OUTCOMES OF SEVERAL RISK FACTORS AND TO PROMOTE SYNERGIES IN THE RESEARCH FINDINGS. SUBRECIPIENT:OLD DOMINION UNIVERSITY ($356,731) WILL ACTIVELY PARTICIPATE IN DATA COLLECTION AND SAMPLE ANALYSIS CONDUCTED AT THE PARML LABORATORY AND ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONTRIBUTING TO PROJECT DELIVERABLES. ODU RESEARCHERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN REGULARLY SCHEDULED MEETINGS REMOTELY. OUTCOMES:THE WEB-BASED DECISION SUPPORT TOOL WILL BE DESIGNED TO ADVANCE BEST PRACTICES AND ASSIST USERS IN A CAREFUL EVALUATION OF RISK AND PERFORMANCE FACTORS TO ENSURE EAR PROJECTS ARE EFFECTIVE, SUSTAINABLE, AND PROTECTIVE OF GROUNDWATER RESOURCES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE WATER QUALITY MANAGERS AND RESIDENTS OF THE EAST COAST.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE SEVERAL METHODS OF MODIFICATION OF RURAL BASINS TO ENHANCE RECHARGE WHILE MONITORING THE EFFICACY OF EACH APPROACH.ACTIVITIES:IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AND THE SITE OWNER (CITY OF ADA, OK), THIS PROJECT WILL EMPLOY MICROBIOLOGICAL, GEOCHEMICAL, SEDIMENTOLOGICAL, GROUNDWATER GAS MONITORING, GEOPHYSICAL, AND GROUNDWATER MODELING TOOLS TO TEST THE EFFECTIVENESS AND IMPACTS OF RURAL EAR STRUCTURES TO DETERMINE IF THESE STRUCTURES CAN BE DEPLOYED AS PART OF RURAL LAND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO SAFELY INCREASE GROUNDWATER SUPPLIES IN FRACTURED AND KARSTIC AQUIFERS.SUBRECIPIENT:TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITY ($443,592) WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE GROUNDWATER MODEL AND GAS TRANSPORT DEVELOPMENT (TASK E), INCLUDING TRAVEL TO RESEARCH SITES AND PROJECT MEETINGS. EAST CENTRAL UNIVERSITY OKA INSTITUTE ($294,482) WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE COLLABORATION AND ENGAGEMENT PLAN, HOST THE STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, AND MANAGE THE MARKETING AND EDUCATIONAL PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A GUIDANCE DOCUMENT FOR THE SITING AND ASSESSMENT OF RURAL EAR AS WELL AS A LITERATURE REVIEW AND MONITORING TOOLS DEVELOPED TO MANAGE RECHARGE PULSES THROUGH FRACTURED AND KARSTIC AQUIFERS, AND GUIDANCE ON MONITORING BIOGEOCHEMICAL CHANGES. THE OUTCOMES INCLUDE PROVIDING LAND AND WATER MANAGERS THE ABILITY TO SAFELY AND ECONOMICALLY IMPLEMENT RURAL EAR. THE BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF OKLAHOMA WHOSE WATER SUPPLY COMES FROM ARBUCKLE SIMPSON AQUIFER, LOCAL AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENT, INDUSTRIAL AND AGRICULTURAL USERS, THE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENT OF CONNECTED STREAMS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT AIMS TO RESEARCH THE EFFECTIVENESS OF STORMWATER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) USED FOR ENHANCED AQUIFER RECHARGE (EAR) TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF URBAN STORMWATER RECHARGING GROUNDWATER SUPPLIES.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL EXAMINE THE IMPACT OF LATERAL EXFILTRATION OF STORMWATER RUNOFF COUPLED WITH VADOSE ZONE STRATIFICATION AND THE IMPACT OF LATERAL FLOW ON POLLUTANT TRANSPORT INTO GROUNDWATER. THE PROJECT WILL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES, A) MONITOR FLOW PATHS AND CHARACTERIZE SOIL CHARACTERISTICS TO EVALUATE INFILTRATION RATES; B) USING HIGHEST FLOW PATHWAYS, IDENTIFY CRITICAL SAMPLING LOCATIONS OF POLLUTANT TRANSPORT AND ASSESS HUMAN HEALTH RISK; AND C) CALIBRATE THE OPENHYDROQUAL MODEL BY INPUTTING FIELD MONITORING DATA.SUBRECIPIENT:SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA COASTAL WATER RESEARCH PROJECT ($275,539) WILL SERVE AS THE LEAD OF WATER QUALITY INVESTIGATION WILL CONDUCT A SURVEY OF BIORETENTION-TYPE BMP PRACTICES ACROSS LAC TO IDENTIFY AND CATALOG DESIGN AND MAINTENANCE CONDITIONS PREVENTING OR PROMOTING EFFECTIVE OPERATION OF THE BMP IN TERMS OF PHYSICAL ABILITY TO CAPTURE RUNOFF. CATHOLIC UNIVERSITY OF AMERICA ($235,450) WILL COMMIT INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT AND A VARIETY OF RESOURCES AND DR. ARASH MASSOUDIEH WILL SERVE AS THE MODELING LEAD FOR THE PROJECT. LAWRENCE BERKELEY NATIONAL LABORATORY ($1,074,011) WILL SERVE AS GEOPHYSICAL INVESTIGATION LEAD FOR THE PROJECT. 
OUTCOMES:THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A FREE AND OPEN-SOURCE MODELING TOOL FOR EVALUATION OF PERFORMANCE OF EAR BMPS, IN ADDITION TO ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS. ENGINEERS, PLANNERS, AND OTHER USERS WILL BE ABLE TO INPUT PARAMETERS OF THEIR SPECIFIC BMP SYSTEMS AND BE ABLE TO ASSESS THE LONG-TERM PERFORMANCE OF BMPS USED FOR EAR, INCLUDING IDENTIFYING ANY RISKS OF POLLUTANT HAZARD RISKS TO GROUNDWATER. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE WATER RESOURCE MANAGERS, COMMUNITIES DEPENDENT ON GROUNDWATER SUPPLY, LA COUNTY WATER USERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PORTABLE RAMAN AND ELECTROCHEMICAL NANOSYSTEM (I-PRENS) TO BE DEPLOYED FOR ONSITE DETECTION AND DEGRADATION OF NEONICOTINOID PESTICIDES IN RURAL DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES IN ALABAMA'S BLACK BELT REGION.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL APPLY THE BEST-AVAILABLE NANOTECHNOLOGY-ENABLED SENSING AND TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES INTO A FIELD-DEPLOYABLE PROTOTYPE DESIGNED FOR LONG-TERM MONITORING AND CHEMICAL-SUPPLY-FREE REMEDIATION OF NEONICOTINOID-IMPACTED DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) DEVELOP A HOT SPOT NORMALIZED SURFACE-ENHANCED RAMAN SPECTROSCOPIC (HSN-SERS) SENSING MODULE FOR REAL-TIME QUANTIFICATION OF NEONICOTINOIDS; (2) DEVELOP A NANOBIOCHAR-ENABLED PRE-TREATMENT MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID PRE-CONCENTRATION; (3) DEVELOP A SENSOR-CONTROLLED CATALYTIC ADVANCED OXIDATION PROCESS (AOP) MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID DEGRADATION; AND (4) DEVELOP AND DEPLOY A SMALL-SCALE I-PRENS PROTOTYPE IN RURAL ALABAMA.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD OF $490,241 TO YALE UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SENSOR-CONTROLLED CATALYTIC ADVANCED OXIDATION PROCESS (AOP) MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID DEGRADATION. SUBAWARD OF $379,206 TO AUBURN UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NANOBIOCHAR-ENABLED PRE-TREATMENT MODULE FOR NEONICOTINOID PRE-CONCENTRATION AND THE DEPLOYMENT OF A PROTOTYPE.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS DOCUMENTING THE PROGRESS TOWARD DEVELOPING THE TECHNOLOGY AND RESULTS FROM FIELD DEPLOYMENT. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE RURAL ALABAMA COMMUNITY, COMMUNITIES THAT DEPEND ON PESTICIDE-IMPACTED DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES, PRIVATE/COMMUNITY WELL OWNERS, RESEARCHERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1) INVESTIGATE HOW ELECTRIFYING AND WEATHERIZING HOMES REDUCES ENERGY USAGE, WHILE PROVIDING ENERGY SECURITY, AMELIORATING THE INDOOR AIR QUALITY OF RESIDENTIAL DWELLINGS, AND IMPROVING COMFORT AND PRODUCTIVITY OF OCCUPANTS; AND 2) IDENTIFY THE BARRIERS TO ADOPTING ELECTRIFICATION AND WEATHERIZATION IN LOW-INCOME HOMES. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE TRI-STATE, TEN COUNTY AREA OF GREATER CINCINNATI AND WILL: 1) ANALYZE THE EFFECTS OF COMBINED ELECTRIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY, AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY ALONE, ON HOUSEHOLD ENERGY CONSUMPTION, SECURITY, AND BEHAVIOR IN LOW-INCOME MULTIFAMILY DWELLING UNITS; 2) ESTIMATE THE BENEFITS OF ELECTRIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY TECHNOLOGIES ON INDOOR AIR POLLUTION EMISSIONS IN LOW-INCOME MULTIFAMILY DWELLING UNITS; AND 3) EVALUATE THE FACTORS THAT DRIVE AND INHIBIT HOUSEHOLD, MUNICIPAL, AND REGIONAL DECISIONS ABOUT WHETHER TO ADOPT ELECTRIFICATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGIES, RESPECTIVELY, AND TO DO SO SPECIFICALLY FOR UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE INDIANA UNIVERSITY ($278,190) WILL LEAD THE DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION, AND ANALYSIS OF THE HOUSEHOLD SURVEYS AND ENERGY DIARIES. 

SUBAWARDEE CARNEGIE MELLON UNIVERSITY (CMU) ($129,674) WILL LEAD THE ANALYSIS OF THE ENERGY EFFICIENCY BENEFITS OF ELECTRIFICATION AND WEATHERIZATION. CMU WILL ALSO LEAD THE ANALYSIS OF AIR QUALITY CHANGES AFTER ELECTRIFICATION. 

SUBAWARDEE OVER-THE-RHINE COMMUNITY HOUSING (OTRCH) ($466,800) WILL SUPPORT THE PROJECT BY LEADING THE BUILDING AND UNIT SELECTION AS WELL AS TENANT RECRUITMENT AND ONGOING ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS. OTRCH WILL ALSO CONDUCT THE PROCUREMENT PROCESS TO SECURE CONTRACTORS TO COMPLETE BUILDING INTERVENTIONS AND OVERSEE THE EXECUTION OF THE WORK.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING THE RESEARCH FINDINGS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE EXTENSIVE SOCIOECONOMIC AND BEHAVIORAL INSIGHTS THAT CAN BE USED TO UNDERSTAND AND ADVANCE THE DIFFUSION OF LOW-CARBON AND EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGIES AMONG LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE MULTIFAMILY HOME RESIDENTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN CINCINNATI, OH; LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN ENERGY-JUSTICE MODEL FOR FREIGHT VEHICLE ELECTRIFICATION IN AN URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITY THAT IS RESPONSIVE TO COMMUNITY NEEDS WHILE ADVANCING SCIENCE IN AIR QUALITY, PUBLIC HEALTH, SOCIOECONOMIC, ORGANIZATIONAL, AND INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS THAT PLAY A ROLE IN ASSESSING BENEFITS AND COSTS OF TRANSITIONING INTO FREIGHT VEHICLE ELECTRIFICATION.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) ANALYZE THE SOCIOTECHNICAL REGIME IN WHICH A TRANSITION TO ELECTRIFIED FREIGHT VEHICLES WILL OCCUR; 2) EVALUATE POTENTIAL SCENARIOS FOR SUCH A TRANSITION IN TERMS OF THEIR REDUCTION IN AIR EMISSIONS; AND 3) DETERMINE THE HEALTH BENEFITS OF SUCH A TRANSITION FOR A COMMUNITY THAT IS HEAVILY IMPACTED BY FREIGHT VEHICLE TRAFFIC. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS CHICAGO WILL LEAD THE WORK ON BASELINE EXPOSURE ASSESSMENT, ELECTRIFICATION SCENARIO ANALYSIS OF EMISSION MODELING, AIR DISPERSION MODELING, AND EXPOSURE AND HEALTH IMPACTS ASSESSMENT. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS CHICAGO WILL ALSO BE INVOLVED IN RECRUITING COMMUNITY PARTICIPANTS, MOBILE SENSOR TRAINING, AND BASELINE AIR MONITORING DATA COLLECTION.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A COMMUNITY AIR MONITORING AND EXPOSURE ASSESSMENT PLAN (AMEAP); COMMUNITY AIR MONITORING GUIDANCE MATERIALS FOR LOW-COST SENSORS; A DATA REPOSITORY THAT CONTAINS A VARIETY OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND TRAFFIC DATA COLLECTED BY THE PROJECT; A HOLISTIC ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ANALYSIS TOOL KIT; AND AN ONLINE MAPPING TOOL FOR COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE IMPROVED ABILITY TO PREDICT THE POTENTIAL PUBLIC HEALTH AND AIR QUALITY RISK TRADEOFFS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES DUE TO THE FREIGHT ELECTRIFICATION-RELATED ENERGY TRANSITIONS; AND ENHANCED SOCIOECONOMIC, CULTURAL, AND BEHAVIORAL INSIGHTS THAT CAN INFORM FUTURE ELECTRIFICATION SCENARIOS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS OF THE LITTLE VILLAGE NEIGHBORHOOD IN SOUTHWEST CHICAGO AND SIMILAR COMMUNITIES SITUATED NEAR FREIGHT RAILS AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH LARGE-SCALE CHANGES IN ENERGY AND TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO CHARACTERIZE THE ENVIRONMENTAL, PUBLIC HEALTH, ECONOMIC, AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE (EJ) IMPACTS OF A LARGE-SCALE SWINE WASTE-TO-ENERGY (SWE) OPERATION IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) USE STAKEHOLDER SURVEYS, INTERVIEWS, AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES TO QUANTITATIVELY AND QUALITATIVELY ASSESS RISK PERCEPTIONS AND SOCIAL, ECONOMIC, AND EJ CONSIDERATIONS RELATED TO SWE; 2) COLLECT AIR, PRIVATE WELL WATER, AND SURFACE WATER SAMPLES BEFORE AND DURING CONSTRUCTION, AND AFTER COMPLETION OF A PLANNED SWE OPERATION; 3) SPATIOTEMPORALLY EVALUATE IMPACTS OF SWE OPERATIONS ON AIR AND WATER QUALITY OF ADJACENT COMMUNITIES, AND COMPARE SWE WITH OTHER ALTERNATIVE ENERGY SOURCES; AND 4) USE THE FINDINGS TO FACILITATE MULTISECTORAL DIALOGUE AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO SWE. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITY ACTION NETWORK (EJCAN) WILL ASSIST IN THE COMMUNITY SAMPLING EFFORTS, ESTABLISH AN EJCAN COMMUNITY LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS OF WATER SAMPLES, AND COORDINATE COMMUNITY-LED STAKEHOLDER WORKSHOPS. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $233,410.

SUBAWARDEE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL (UNC) WILL BE INVOLVED IN CONDUCTING THE ANALYSIS OF COMMUNITY AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS RISK PERCEPTIONS AND ASSIST WITH SITE SELECTION AND DATA ANALYSIS OF ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING DATA. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $299,839.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS AN EASY-TO-USE, INTERACTIVE TOOL DESIGNED TO HELP COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS CONSIDER HOW SWE OPERATIONS AFFECT CLIMATE, AIR QUALITY, AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL GOALS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC FINDINGS THAT WILL BE OF INTEREST TO COMMUNITIES WITH EJ CONCERNS AS WELL AS ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH PRACTITIONERS AND DECISION-MAKERS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RESIDENTS IN SAMPSON AND DUPLIN COUNTIES IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA, DECISION MAKERS CONCERNED ABOUT THE IMPACTS OF SWINE WASTE-TO-ENERGY (SWE) OPERATIONS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL IS TO ANALYZE IMPACTS OF CURRENT ENERGY SYSTEMS AND PATHWAYS FOR ENERGY TRANSITIONS THAT ENHANCE WELL-BEING THROUGH IMPROVED PUBLIC HEALTH, ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, AND ENERGY JUSTICE OUTCOMES WITH A FOCUS ON UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING A TRIBAL NATION AND RURAL COMMUNITIES, IN A FOREST-DEPENDENT REGION IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL: 1) QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF WOOD, PAPER, PLASTICS, AND TIRE-DERIVED FUELS (WPPT) ENERGY GENERATION IN TERMS OF ECONOMIC WELL-BEING AT THE HOUSEHOLD AND COMMUNITY SCALE AND OF AIR QUALITY AFFECTING HUMAN HEALTH; 2) EVALUATE THE IMPACTS AND POTENTIAL TRANSITION DRIVERS ASSOCIATED WITH LOCAL USE OF FUELWOOD ALONG WITH IMPROVED VENTILATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY OPTIONS; AND 3) ASSESS THE POTENTIAL DECARBONIZATION OF THE ELECTRIC POWER SECTOR TO PROVIDE ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND SECURE ACCESS TO ENERGY SERVICES IN WAYS THAT ENHANCE THE MANUFACTURING SECTOR AS WELL AS COMMUNITY AND HOUSEHOLD WELL-BEING IN TERMS OF AIR QUALITY, PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENERGY JUSTICE.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE CENTER FOR ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO PROTOCOL DEVELOPMENT IN ALL ASPECTS OF INDOOR AIR QUALITY RESEARCH AND RESIDENTIAL ENERGY AUDIT AND ENERGY ASSESSMENTS. ($135,000)OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE REPORTS AND JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING RESULTS OF THE RESEARCH. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF: 1) THE AIR QUALITY IMPACTS OF WPPT ENERGY PRODUCTION FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; 2) IMPACTS OF CURRENT ENERGY SERVICES PROVISION ON INDOOR AIR QUALITY AND POTENTIAL DRIVERS TO INCREASE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND USE OF WOOD PRODUCTS IN WAYS THAT DO NOT HAVE NEGATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACTS; AND 3) POTENTIAL DRIVERS OF A TRANSITION IN FOREST PRODUCT USE THAT CAN SUPPORT JUST ENERGY SERVICES ACCESS AS WELL AS ECONOMIC WELL-BEING FOR HOUSEHOLDS, COMMUNITIES, AND INDUSTRIES THAT ENHANCE EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE RURAL COMMUNITIES AND TRIBAL NATIONS IN FOREST DEPENDENT AREAS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH LARGE-SCALE CHANGES IN THE ENERGY SYSTEMS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE THE NATURAL EXPERIMENT AFFORDED BY A RECENT OIL REFINERY CLOSURE IN NORTHERN CA, STATE-OF-THE-SCIENCE AIR QUALITY MODELING, AND A UNIQUE DATASET OF AMBIENT AIR POLLUTION MONITORING DATA TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF REFINERY EMISSIONS ON LOCAL AIR QUALITY AND COMMUNITY HEALTH AND COMPARE PRESENT CONDITIONS TO ALTERNATE SCENARIOS OF REFINERY RETIREMENT AND BIOFUEL CONVERSION.ACTIVITIES:SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL: 1) UTILIZE THE 2020 CLOSURE OF THE MARATHON OIL REFINERY IN MARTINEZ, CALIFORNIA AS A NATURAL EXPERIMENT TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF OIL REFINING ON RATES OF PRETERM BIRTH, EMERGENCY ROOM VISITS, AND HOSPITALIZATIONS; 2) MODEL THE AIR QUALITY, HEALTH, AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF RETIRING THE FOUR OPERATIONAL OIL REFINERIES IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AND COMPARE THEM TO ALTERNATIVE SCENARIOS OF RETROFIT TO BIOFUEL PRODUCTION; AND 3) ENGAGE COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND ADVOCATES IN STUDY DESIGN AND RESULTS DISSEMINATION AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A WEB-BASED INTERACTIVE TOOL TO INFORM PETROLEUM REFINERY CONVERSION OR RETIREMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA BERKELEY WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STUDY DESIGN AS WELL AS IN THE DATA ANALYSIS, INTERPRETATION AND DISSEMINATION OF STUDY RESULTS. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $196,558.

SUBAWARDEE PSE ENERGY WILL BE INVOLVED IN AIR QUALITY MODELING, HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT, AND DEVELOPMENT OF AN ONLINE REFINERY RETIREMENT AND RETROFIT DATA VISUALIZATION TOOL. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $390,000.

SUBAWARDEE ASIAN PACIFIC ENVIRONMENTAL NETWORK WILL SUPPORT THE PROJECT BY PROVIDING ADVICE TO THE STUDY TEAM, ASSISTING IN RESULTS TRANSLATION AND DISSEMINATION, AND PARTICIPATING IN AND COORDINATING REGULAR COMMUNITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEETINGS. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $200,440.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS DOCUMENTING RESEARCH FINDINGS ON LINK BETWEEN HEALTH AND AIR QUALITY IMPACTS OF OIL REFINERY OPERATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE AGGREGATE AIR QUALITY AND HEALTH BENEFITS OF RETIRING OR RETROFITTING MULTIPLE PETROLEUM REFINERIES IN A DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED REGION. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS LIVING NEAR OIL REFINERIES IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS AIR QUALITY DEGRADATION AND PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH OIL REFINING FOR ENERGY PRODUCTION.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW SOCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS DRIVE INDIVIDUAL AND HOUSEHOLD ELECTRIFICATION DECISIONS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND HOW THESE FACTORS AFFECT ENVIRONMENTAL CO-BENEFITS OF ENERGY-EFFICIENT ELECTRIFICATION.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL USE COMMUNITY-BASED PARTICIPATORY RESEARCH (CBPR) APPROACH AND INTEGRATE ETHNOGRAPHIC AND BEHAVIORAL ECONOMIC METHODS WITH ENGINEERING ANALYSIS AND AIR QUALITY TESTING TO: 1) TO UNDERSTAND HOW LOW- AND MODERATE-INCOME (LMI) HOUSEHOLDS AND NEIGHBORHOODS IN AN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITY EXPERIENCE AND ENVISION THE 21ST CENTURY ENERGY TRANSITION AND IDENTIFY COMMUNITY PRIORITIES; 2) DEVELOP A ROBUST COMMUNITY-BASED RESEARCH PLATFORM FOR DESIGNING SCALABLE SOLUTIONS TO THE CHALLENGE OF ENERGY-EFFICIENT ELECTRIFICATION OF AGING HOUSING INFRASTRUCTURE; AND 3) WORK WITH LOCAL HOUSING PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT AND TEST COMMUNITY CO-DESIGNED INTERVENTIONS AND PROTOTYPES TO ASSESS THEIR EFFICACY IN ADDRESSING HOUSEHOLD PRIORITIES, INCLUDING INDOOR AIR QUALITY, COMFORT, AND COST. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE NORTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY WILL OVERSEE THE CO-DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A SERIES OF PARTICIPATORY CAUSAL LOOP DIAGRAMMING (CLD) WORKSHOPS TO INFORM AND FACILITATE STAKEHOLDER-LED INPUT TO IDENTIFY BARRIERS TO JUST ENERGY TRANSITION TOWARDS DECARBONIZATION, TRAIN FACILITATORS FOR THE WORKSHOPS, CO-DESIGN AND SUPERVISE THE EXECUTION OF PARTICIPATORY CLD SESSIONS TO DRAW A SYSTEMS REPRESENTATION OF THE CURRENT ENERGY SYSTEMS; AND CO-DESIGN AND SUPERVISE DEBRIEFING SESSIONS TO IDENTIFY BARRIERS TO JUST TRANSITIONS AND IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR INTERVENTION. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $50,314.

SUBAWARDEE NEIGHBOR TO NEIGHBOR WILL DO RESIDENT RECRUITMENT, HOST GROUP SESSIONS, AND ASSIST IN PLANNING WORKSHOPS, MEETINGS AND
A COMMUNITY FORUM. THE REQUESTED AMOUNT IS $199,720.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS, AS WELL AS CO-DESIGNED SCALABLE, ADAPTABLE SOLUTIONS FOR HOUSEHOLD ELECTRIFICATION. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE REGARDING THE DRIVERS, BARRIERS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CO-BENEFITS OF HOUSEHOLD ELECTRIFICATION IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE LOW- AND MODERATE-INCOME (LMI) HOUSEHOLDS IN MASSACHUSETTS, AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO STUDY DRIVERS AND IMPACTS OF HOUSEHOLD ELECTRIFICATION.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR EVALUATING CHANGES IN NEIGHBORHOOD AIR POLLUTION DISTRIBUTIONS ARISING FROM ALTERNATIVE FUTURE SCENARIOS FOR PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND ELECTRICITY GENERATION, UTILIZING AN ATMOSPHERIC POLLUTION DISPERSION MODELING TO ESTIMATE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND ELECTRICITY GENERATION IMPACTS ON AIR POLLUTION CONCENTRATIONS.ACTIVITIES:SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) QUANTIFY THE EXISTING DISPARITIES IN AIR POLLUTION EXPOSURE TO PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION AND ELECTRICITY GENERATION IN MARICOPA COUNTY; 2) COLLECT DATA ON PLANNED PUBLIC TRANSIT INTERVENTIONS FOR DECARBONIZATION OF THE TRANSPORTATION FLEET IN MARICOPA COUNTY; 3) EVALUATE AIR QUALITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE IMPACTS OF FUTURE PUBLIC TRANSIT SCENARIOS; AND 4) DEVELOP A VISUALIZATION TOOL OF PROPOSED PLANNED INFRASTRUCTURE FOR STAKEHOLDERS AND COMMUNITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:$314,618 IS BUDGETED TO UNLIMITED POTENTIAL. THEY WILL PROVIDE INPUT TO DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR ANALYZING PROPOSED TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS, CREATE COMMUNITY FOCUS GROUPS TO UNDERSTAND THE LOCAL PERCEPTIONS OF AIR QUALITY AND PREFERENCES OVER CERTAIN PROGRAMS TO REDUCE AIR POLLUTION, AND COORDINATE COMMUNITY OUTREACH ACTIVITIES TO DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS. OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A DATABASE OF POLLUTION CONCENTRATIONS DUE TO EXISTING ELECTRICITY GENERATION AND PUBLIC TRANSIT INFRASTRUCTURE IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, AN INVENTORY OF PLANNED PUBLIC TRANSIT DEVELOPMENTS AND COMMUNITY SURVEY ABOUT POTENTIAL PROGRAMS AND INTERVENTIONS WITH ASSOCIATED EMISSIONS IN MARICOPA COUNTY, AND A DATABASE OF POLLUTION EXPOSURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE STATUS AT THE CENSUS BLOCK GROUP LEVEL. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE THAT THE PROJECT'S STAKEHOLDERS CAN INCORPORATE IN THEIR FUTURE ENERGY TRANSITION DECISIONS AND HELP CITIES IDENTIFY WHICH PLANNED ELECTRIFICATION AND TRANSPORTATION POLICIES CAN REDUCE ENVIRONMENTAL DISPARITIES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS OF MARICOPA COUNTY IN ARIZONA, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACCELERATE DECARBONIZATION OF THE ELECTRICAL GRID BY DELIVERING INFORMATION AND TOOLS THAT EMPOWER COMMUNITY-BASED ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS TO IDENTIFY AND ADVOCATE FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH COMMUNITY VALUES.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL SYNTHESIZE EXISTING MODELING TOOLS INTO AN INTEGRATED WRAPPER THAT CAN SCREEN ALTERNATIVE DECARBONIZATION SCENARIOS IN TERMS OF THE VARIOUS ECOLOGICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND HEALTH OUTCOMES OF INTERESTS. RESEARCHERS WILL RECRUIT RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITY MEMBERS INTO DELIBERATIVE WORKSHOPS IN ORDER TO QUANTIFY THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF COMPETING ATTRIBUTES AND IDENTIFY THE INFORMATION THAT IS MOST INFLUENTIAL IN THE FORMATION OF ATTITUDES. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL ALSO INCORPORATE QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE INFORMATION INTO COST-BENEFIT ANALYSES WHICH WILL BE PERFORMED ON RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS UNDER CONSIDERATION FOR NEW ENGLAND.SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO CLEAN ENERGY NH WILL BE FOR $33,038. THEY WILL SUPPORT THEIR PROVISION OF INPUT ON SCENARIO DEVELOPMENT, SURVEY INSTRUMENTS, AND CHARACTERIZATIONS OF IMPACTS AND BENEFITS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS UNDER CONSIDERATION IN YEAR 3.

THE SUBAWARD TO DARTMOUTH COLLEGE WILL BE FOR $114,055. THEY WILL SUPPORT CO-MENTORSHIP OF THE POSTDOC AND ANALYSIS OF DATA COLLECTED. 

THE SUBAWARD TO UMASS BOSTON WILL BE FOR $224,961. THEY WILL SUPPORT DELIBERATIVE VALUATION STUDY DESIGN, GRADUATE STUDENT RECRUITMENT, AND WORKSHOP ADMINISTRATION.
  OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE 1) INCREASED CAPACITY FOR COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO GENERATE INDEPENDENT CHARACTERIZATIONS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY PRODUCTS; 2) INCREASED CREDIBILITY OF AVAILABLE INFORMATION; 3) INCREASED CAPACITY FOR COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO IDENTIFY AND ADVOCATE FOR PROJECTS; AND 4) ENHANCED COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS TOOLS THAT CAN EXPLICITLY VALUE PUBLIC PREFERENCE REGARDING COMPETING ATTRIBUTES FOR ALTERNATIVE RENEWABLE ENERGY SCENARIOS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE NEW ENGLAND COMMUNITIES IN RURAL, LOW-INCOME ENVIRONMENTS MOST AFFECTED BY RENEWABLES TRANSMISSION AND/OR GENERATION INFRASTRUCTURE, HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL IS TO UNDERSTAND THE ROLE OF STATEWIDE LOCAL ENERGY ACTION NETWORKS (LEANS) IN SUPPORTING AND ADVANCING RENEWABLE ENERGY AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY (REE) IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, WITH COMMUNITY-ENGAGED STATE AND LOCAL PILOT PROJECTS FOCUSING ON INDIGENOUS, RURAL, AND LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL: 1) IDENTIFY AND COMPARE BARRIERS, OPPORTUNITIES, DECISION DRIVERS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY (REE) ADOPTION FOR INDIVIDUALS, COMMUNITY, AND GOVERNMENT OF UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; 2) EXAMINE BENEFITS, CHALLENGES, AND EFFECTIVENESS OF STATEWIDE LOCAL ENERGY ACTION NETWORKS (LEANS) IN SUPPORTING REE ADOPTION IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; AND 3) EXAMINE THE ROLE OF TARGETED INTERVENTIONS (CAPACITY, EDUCATION, OWNERSHIP) IN ADVANCING REE AWARENESS, ENGAGEMENT, AND ADOPTION IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. 

SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEE PENOBSCOT NATION (PN) TRIBAL GOVERNMENT WILL HAVE A SUSTAINABLE ENERGY COORDINATOR TO SERVE ALL WABANAKI TRIBES, BUILD CAPACITY AND ACCELERATE IMPLEMENTATION OF LOCAL ENERGY SOLUTIONS, OVERSEE PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, ENGAGE COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND ENGAGE IN RESEARCH ACTIVITIES.  ($307,007)
OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE COMMUNITY CO-CREATED RESEARCH INSTRUMENTS AND RESEARCH PRODUCTS INCLUDING REPORTS, BRIEFINGS, ARTICLES, AND PRESENTATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF BARRIERS, OPPORTUNITIES, DECISION DRIVERS RELATED TO SUSTAINABLE ENERGY ADOPTION IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; EFFECTIVE METHODS FOR ENGAGEMENT AND CO-PRODUCTION OF KNOWLEDGE WITH COMMUNITIES; BEST PRACTICES FOR STATE NETWORKS AND STATE POLICY/PROGRAM DESIGN TO SUPPORT LOCAL SUSTAINABLE ENERGY ADOPTION. ADDITIONAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED ADOPTION AND DIFFUSION OF SUSTAINABLE ENERGY IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS IMPROVED RISK MANAGEMENT FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN CLIMATE AND ENERGY RESILIENCE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE TEN UNDERSERVED INDIGENOUS, LOW-INCOME, AND/OR RURAL MAINE COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS SIMILAR COMMUNITIES IN OTHER STATES.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INFORM HOW ENERGY TRANSITIONS CAN BE IMPROVED TO BE MORE ATTENTIVE TO ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND COMMUNITY CONCERNS BY IMPROVING THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE IMPACTS THROUGHOUT THE LIFE CYCLE OF RENEWABLE ENERGY STORAGE INFRASTRUCTURES AND ACTIVITIES FROM A COMMUNITY-ENGAGED PERSPECTIVE.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVE OF THE RESEARCH IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW RENEWABLE ENERGY TRANSITIONS CAN OCCUR IN WAYS THAT MAXIMIZE POTENTIAL POSITIVE IMPACTS AND MINIMIZE POTENTIAL NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO UNIVERSITY OF NEVADA RENO WILL BE FOR $117,168. THEY WILL BE WORKING ON COMMUNITY ENGAGED CASE STUDY RESEARCH AND CONTRIBUTING TO RESEARCH IMPLEMENTATION AND SHARING RESULTS. 

THE SUBAWARD TO SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY WILL BE FOR $98,140. THEY WILL BE WORKING ON COMMUNITY ENGAGED CASE STUDY RESEARCH AND CONTRIBUTING TO RESEARCH IMPLEMENTATION AND SHARING RESULTS. 

THE SUBAWARD TO CAL POLY POMONA WILL BE FOR $115,000. THEY WILL BE WORKING ON COMMUNITY ENGAGED CASE STUDY RESEARCH AND CONTRIBUTING TO RESEARCH IMPLEMENTATION AND SHARING RESULTS.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS INCLUDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR JUST AND SUSTAINABLE RENEWABLE ENERGY STORAGE, PRESENTATIONS FOR A VARIETY OF FORUMS (E.G., ACADEMIC CONFERENCES, PUBLIC AGENCIES), AND SERIES OF ENTRIES FOR THE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE ATLAS AND OTHER COMMUNITY-ENGAGED RESEARCH PRODUCTS. THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO INFORM HOW RENEWABLE ENERGY TRANSITIONS CAN OCCUR IN WAYS THAT MAXIMIZE POTENTIAL POSITIVE IMPACTS AND MINIMIZE POTENTIAL NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY CAPACITY AND BUILD WORKING RELATIONSHIPS THAT WILL CONTINUE BEYOND THE LIFE OF THE PROJECT. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE COMMUNITIES IN THE WESTERN U.S. AFFECTED BY ACTIVITIES OR INFRASTRUCTURE ASSOCIATED WITH RENEWABLE ENERGY STORAGE, SUCH AS MINERAL EXTRACTION ACTIVITIES, BATTERY MANUFACTURING AND ASSEMBLY, UTILITY-SCALE ENERGY STORAGE, AND BATTERY RECYCLING.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL IS TO ADDRESS AIR POLLUTION AND SUBSEQUENT HEALTH IMPACTS WHILE CONSIDERING THE CHALLENGES FOR ENERGY, MOBILITY, ACCESSIBILITY, AND EQUITABILITY IN FIFTEEN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE COLUMBUS METROPOLITAN AREA (CMA). ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) PARTNER WITH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE CMA TO UNDERSTAND THEIR NEEDS FOR ELECTRIFICATION AND MOBILITY AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF CURRENT EFFORTS; 2) DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO GUIDE TRANSITION INVESTMENT AND DEPLOYMENT TO IMPROVE HEALTH, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIAL CONDITIONS OVER TIME FOR THE CMA COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE URBAN-EXURBAN-RURAL GRADIENT; AND 3) UNDERSTAND HOW KNOWLEDGE, PERCEPTION, AND VALUES VARY, AND DESIGN AND EVALUATE INFORMATIONAL INTERVENTIONS THAT INFORM INDIVIDUAL AND DOMICILE-LEVEL DECISIONS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS. OTHER EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: COMMUNITY ASSESSMENTS AND TOOLKITS TO SUPPORT LOCAL AND REGIONAL DECISION-MAKERS ON TRANSITIONS TO ELECTRIFIED ENERGY AND MOBILITY; AND ELECTRICITY AND MOBILITY INFRASTRUCTURE PLANNING WHITE PAPERS AND PRESENTATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE TESTED INFORMATIONAL INTERVENTIONS FOR USE IN HELPING MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES UNDERSTAND THE DECISIONS FACING THEIR HOUSEHOLDS DURING ELECTRIFIED ENERGY AND MOBILITY TRANSITIONS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE COLUMBUS METROPOLITAN AREA AS WELL AS RESEARCHERS WORKING WITH SIMILAR COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS AIR QUALITY, PUBLIC HEALTH, AND COST CONCERNS ASSOCIATED WITH ELECTRIFIED ENERGY AND TRANSPORTATION SERVICES.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE THE RELATIVE IMPACTS OF PERCHLORATE FROM FIREWORKS ON SURFACE DRINKING WATER SOURCES AND GROUNDWATER DRINKING SOURCES ACROSS THE US BY MEASURING PERCHLORATE AT SIX SITES (TWO RIVERS, THREE LAKES, AND A GROUNDWATER SITE) DURING JULY 4TH EVENTS, AS WELL AS PERIODIC FIREWORK DISPLAYS FROM BASEBALL STADIUMS ON THE TWO RIVERS SELECTED. SEVEN SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES WILL BE ADDRESSED THROUGH A COMBINATION OF FIELD AND LABORATORY STUDIES COMBINED WITH MODELING EFFORTS TO FILL CRITICAL KNOWLEDGE GAPS.ACTIVITIES:DRINKING WATER SOURCES IN THE WATERSHEDS WILL BE EVALUATED BEFORE AND AFTER MAJOR PERIODS OF FIREWORKS AND DURING SUBSEQUENT RAIN EVENTS. IN ADDITION TO MEASURING THE PERCHLORATE INPUTS DUE TO RUNOFF OR INFILTRATION, THE RESEARCH WILL ALSO MEASURE THE DIRECT DEPOSITION INTO WATER BODIES. AERIAL DEPOSITION WILL BE MEASURED BY LIMITED DIRECT AIR AND DEPOSITION SAMPLING AT SOME SITES. TO EXPAND THE REACH OF THE STUDY, ADDITIONAL SAMPLES WILL BE REQUESTED FROM CASTNET AND NADP (TWO EXISTING SAMPLING NETWORKS), AND THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE NATION-WIDE SURVEYS OF PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY INTAKES BEFORE AND AFTER PERIODS OF FIREWORKS. ALL CHEMICAL, PHYSICAL, AND BIOLOGICAL OBSERVATIONS FROM THE SIX SITES WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO A WIDELY APPLIED WATERSHED MODEL, SOIL AND WATER ASSESSMENT TOOL (SWAT), WHICH WILL EXPAND THE TOOL'S ABILITY TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF FIREWORK-DRIVEN PERCHLORATE EMISSIONS.SUBRECIPIENT:PENN STATE UNIVERSITY ($620,000): SUBAWARD FOR (1) SAMPLING OF THE PITTSBURGH LOCATION, AND (2) MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION (OBJECTIVES 5, 6, AND 7). GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY ($174,165): SUBAWARD FOR (1) SAMPLING THE ATLANTA LOCATION, AND (2) MODEL DEVELOPMENT (OBJECTIVES 1, 5, AND 6). UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKLEY ($375,098): SUBAWARD FOR (1) SAMPLING THE LAKE TAHOE LOCATION, AND (2) STUDIES ON PERCHLORATE REDUCTION. UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE ($319,999): SUBAWARD FOR (1) SAMPLING THE MASSACHUSETTS LOCATION, AND (2) STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSES (OBJECTIVES 4 AND 5). UNIVERSITY OF NEVADA, LAS VEGAS ($329,985): SUBAWARD FOR (1) SAMPLING THE LAS VEGAS LOCATION, AND (2) STUDIES ON AIR DEPOSITION, CITIZEN SCIENTIST LAKE SURVEY, LAKE MODELING (OBJECTIVES 1, 2, AND 6).
OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE NEW INFORMATION AND DATA ON: 1) CONCENTRATIONS, MASSES, ATTENUATION RATES OF PERCHLORATE FROM FIREWORKS USE IN DIVERSE SURFACE WATERS AS WELL AS RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS FROM COMMERCIAL DISPLAYS AND PUBLIC USE AND DIRECT INPUTS AND INDIRECT FROM RUNOFF; (2) DEPOSITION RATES, AERIAL EXTENTS, AND LOCAL AND REGIONAL IMPACTS OF PERCHLORATE DEPOSITION; 3) THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DENSITY OF FIREWORKS USE (MASS OR COST), POPULATION, AND RESULTANT RESIDUAL PERCHLORATE THAT ENTERS THE ENVIRONMENT; 4) THE BIOLOGICAL ATTENUATION RATE AS A FUNCTION OF THE CHARACTERISTICS OF WATER SOURCES; AND 5) THE IMPACT OF FIREWORKS USE ON GROUNDWATER RESOURCES. ADDITIONAL OUTPUTS INCLUDE REFINED AND CALIBRATED MODELS TO EVALUATE PERCHLORATE INPUT AND FATE IN SURFACE WATER RESOURCES, A NATIONAL SURVEY OF THE IMPACT OF PERCHLORATE IN DRINKING WATER SOURCES, IDENTIFICATION OF KEY PREDICTIVE VARIABLES TO PREDICT PERCHLORATE IMPACT, AND DEVELOPMENT OF A SCREENING TOOL TO EVALUATE IMPACTS. POTENTIAL BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE DRINKING WATER UTILITIES AS WELL AS STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND COMMUNITIES WHOSE DRINKING WATER IS AFFECTED BY POLLUTION FROM THE USE OF FIREWORKS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE A SET OF HOUSEHOLD FOOD WASTE PREVENTION INTERVENTIONS RESEARCHERS HAVE DEVELOPED WITH LOCAL HEALTH, FOOD, AND ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS IN NORTH CAROLINA.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL ENROLL 200 LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS IN THE RALEIGH, NC AREA TO IMPLEMENT AN INTERVENTION THAT IS BASED ON EACH HOUSEHOLD'S ROOT CAUSES OF FOOD WASTE. IT AIMS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE INTERVENTION BY MEASURING THE IMPACTS ON AVOIDABLE FOOD WASTE (GRAMS/HOUSEHOLD/WEEK), FOOD WASTE PREVENTION BEHAVIORS, PSYCHOSOCIAL DRIVERS OF FOOD WASTE, AND FOOD SECURITY. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SIMULATE THE IMPACT OF THE INTERVENTIONS ON ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES (E.G., GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS, BLUE WATER WITHDRAWAL, LAND USE, AND ENERGY USE) AND COST-EFFECTIVENESS FOR NATIONAL-SCALE APPLICATION.SUBRECIPIENT:RTI INTERNATIONAL ($149,979) WILL PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC GUIDANCE AND EXPERTISE FOR DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING THE RESEARCH METHODS AS A RESEARCH PARTNER. OUTCOMES:THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS, COMMUNICATION MATERIALS, AND EDUCATION/TRAINING MATERIALS TO HELP COMMUNITIES AND INDIVIDUALS TO PREVENT AND REDUCE HOUSEHOLD CONSUMER FOOD WASTE. OUTPUTS INCLUDE AN INTERVENTION TOOLKIT FOR HOUSEHOLDS, ESTIMATES OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT AND COST-EFFECTIVENESS, DISSEMINATION MATERIALS, AND AT LEAST THREE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS. OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE WIDESPREAD DISSEMINATION OF INTERVENTION MATERIALS RESULTING IN EXTENSIVE REDUCTION IN HOUSEHOLD FOOD WASTE NATIONALLY. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE INDIVIDUAL CONSUMERS AND COMMUNITIES IN THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA AND OTHER REGIONS IN THE UNITED STATES.

DESCRIPTION:THE PROPOSED RESEARCH INVESTIGATES A HIGHLY INNOVATIVE AND SCALABLE APPROACH TO STRENGTHEN CONSUMERS' MOTIVATION, OPPORTUNITY, AND ABILITY TO REDUCE FOOD WASTE BY ADAPTING PROFESSIONAL CULINARY EDUCATION INTERVENTIONS TO THE HOME KITCHEN.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF A SERIES OF INNOVATIVE FOOD WASTE PREVENTION AND MINIMIZATION CULINARY EDUCATION VIDEOS (AND SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIALS) FOR HOME COOKS. THE VIDEOS WILL BE DEVELOPED BY NATIONALLY RENOWNED FOOD PREPARERS AND FOOD WASTE EDUCATORS IN COLLABORATION WITH DREXEL FOOD LAB. THE COMMUNITY-BASED EDUCATION SESSION WITH 100 SELECTED HOUSEHOLDS WILL BE COMPRISED OF 8 EDUCATIONAL CULINARY VIDEOS DESIGNED TO EMPOWER CONSUMERS BY PROVIDING THE MOTIVATION, KNOWLEDGE, AND SKILLS TO REDUCE HOUSEHOLD FOOD WASTE THROUGHOUT THE PROCESS INCLUDING MEAL PLANNING, SHOPPING, CONSUMING, STORING, AND DISPOSING. THE PROJECT WILL MEASURE THE IMPACTS OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ON FOOD WASTE REDUCTION AT HOUSEHOLD AND COMMUNITY LEVELS AND TEST NATIONAL SCALABILITY AND APPLICABILITY.SUBRECIPIENT:JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY ($76,386) WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE IN EVALUATION DESIGN AND WILL ALSO ACT AS A SCIENTIFIC ADVISOR.

OUTCOMES:THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH PUBLICATIONS, COMMUNICATION AND EDUCATION MATERIALS, AND MULTI MEDIA (VIDEO) TRAINING MATERIALS TO EDUCATE AND MOTIVATE COMMUNITIES AND INDIVIDUALS TO REDUCE HOUSEHOLD CONSUMER FOOD WASTE. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES WOULD BE MEANINGFUL REDUCTION IN FOOD WASTE THROUGH CONSUMER BEHAVIOR CHANGES INVOLVED IN FOOD SHOPPING, PREPARATION, CONSUMPTION, AND POST-CONSUMPTION DISPOSAL. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE HOUSEHOLDS AND COMMUNITIES IN PHILADELPHIA AREA AND OTHER REGIONS, AND PUBLIC IN THE UNITED STATES.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO LEVERAGE THE MILWAUKEE PUBLIC SCHOOLS DISTRICT PERSONNEL AND FACILITIES TO BUILD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE AGAINST ADVERSE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON AIR POLLUTION LEVELS AND REDUCE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH INEQUITIES IN MILWAUKEE AND OTHER COMMUNITIES.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL (1) ENGAGE MILWAUKEE PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS, STAFF AND FAMILIES IN A CLIMATE CHANGE AND HEALTH CURRICULUM AND DIALOGUE FOCUSED ON THE HEALTH IMPACTS OF GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE AND HOW STUDENTS, STAFF AND FAMILIES CAN SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MILWAUKEE CLIMATE AND EQUITY PLAN IN ORDER TO SAFEGUARD COMMUNITY HEALTH, AND (2) QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF MPS SCHOOLYARD GREENING AS AN EFFECTIVE COMMUNITY-BASED SOLUTION TO MITIGATE CLIMATE IMPACTS ON HEAT EXPOSURE, AIR POLLUTION, EDUCATIONAL ENGAGEMENT AND
ACHIEVEMENT, AND MENTAL/EMOTIONAL HEALTH AND WELL-BEING.SUBRECIPIENT:MILWAUKEE PUBLIC SCHOOLS ($435,000) WILL REVIEW AND IMPLEMENT THE CLIMATE JUSTICE RESOLUTION CURRICULUM WITH
TEACHERS ACROSS GRADE LEVELS AND CONTENT AREAS. MPS WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR
TEACHERS, PROVIDE TEACHERS WITH COACHING ON THE CLIMATE JUSTICE CURRICULUM, AND SUPPORT TEACHERS IN
THE CLASSROOM ON USING THE CURRICULUM AND RESOURCES EFFECTIVELY.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS AN EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULUM TO SUPPORT TEACHERS IN TEACHING CLIMATE HEALTH EQUITY IN K-12 SCHOOLS, AND SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE OF THE IMPACT OF SCHOOLYARD GREENING ON CLIMATE HEALTH AMONG LOW-INCOME, URBAN MINORITY CHILDREN. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF LOW-INCOME URBAN MINORITY SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN AND ENVIRONMENTAL EQUITY IN MILWAUKEE AREA AND OTHER UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES ARE TEACHERS AND STUDENTS IN MILWAUKEE PUBLIC SCHOOLS, PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, AND STATE AND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE CUMULATIVE HEALTH IMPACTS OF CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL EXPOSURES EXACERBATED BY CLIMATE CHANGE AMONG THE MOST VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES IN ATLANTA AND TO DEVELOP SUITABLE INTERVENTION PROGRAMS TO REDUCE EXPOSURES.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL 1) CREATE AN INDEX AND MAP AT THE NEIGHBORHOOD LEVEL FOCUSED ON THE CUMULATIVE CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL EXPOSURE OF INDIVIDUALS IN ATLANTA AND HOW THEIR HEALTH IS ADVERSELY IMPACTED BY ELEVATED AIR POLLUTION DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE; 2) SEEK TO UNDERSTAND HOW HIGHLY SUSCEPTIBLE INDIVIDUALS WITH CHRONIC DISEASE PERCEIVE AND MANAGE THE EFFECTS OF CHEMICAL, NON-CHEMICAL, AND CLIMATE-RELATED FACTORS ON THEIR MENTAL HEALTH, ASTHMA, AND OBESITY-SENSITIVE CONDITIONS; AND 3) FACILITATE COMMUNITY-LED EDUCATION INITIATIVES AND INTERVENTIONS TO EMPOWER THE COMMUNITY AND INCREASE RESILIENCE AGAINST CLIMATE CHANGE AND ITS HEALTH EFFECTS.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD TO ECO-ACTION ($455,773) FOR LEADING COMMUNITY-ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AS LISTED IN THE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PLAN. SUBAWARD TO SPELMAN COLLEGE ($134,408) TO PROVIDE THE PRELIMINARY DATA ON CUMULATIVE ENVIRONMENTAL VULNERABILITY ANALYSIS NEEDED FOR OBJECTIVE 1. IN ADDITION, SPELMAN WILL LEAD THE COMMUNITY LEVEL ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARD DATA COLLECTION USING THE PROCTOR CREEK CITIZEN SCIENCE APP.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS, PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS, AND SCIENTIFIC REPORTS AS WELL AS EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS, HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, AND COMMUNITY PLANNERS AND LEADERS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A REDUCTION OF HARMFUL POLLUTANT EXPOSURES AND A GENERAL IMPROVEMENT IN ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AMONG RESIDENTS WITH PREEXISTING HEALTH CONDITIONS IN THE ATLANTA AREA. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS, HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, AND VULNERABLE SUBPOPULATIONS IN THE ATLANTA AREA.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY WHICH POPULATIONS ARE MOST IMPACTED BY WILDFIRE-ASSOCIATED AIR POLLUTION EXPOSURES AND DETERMINE WHETHER THESE EXPOSURES INCREASE RISK FOR ADVERSE BIRTH AND CHILD NEURODEVELOPMENTAL OUTCOMES. ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL 1) BUILD A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE TO UNDERSTAND THE DISTRIBUTION OF WILDFIRE-RELATED AIR POLLUTION IN CALIFORNIA ACROSS A RANGE OF FAMILY, NEIGHBORHOOD, AND COMMUNITY FACTORS THAT COULD INDICATE INCREASED VULNERABILITY; 2) EXAMINE PERINATAL WILDFIRE EXPOSURES IN ASSOCIATION WITH BIRTH OUTCOMES, INCLUDING GESTATIONAL AGE AND WEIGHT AT BIRTH; 3) LINK EXPOSURES TO CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES DATA TO EVALUATE ASSOCIATIONS WITH DIAGNOSES OF AUTISM AND DEVELOPMENTAL DELAYS; AND 4) EVALUATE EXPOSURE WINDOWS, EXPOSURE MIXTURES, AND COMPOUNDING VULNERABILITY FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH HIGHER RISK.SUBRECIPIENT:UCLA ($100,001) WILL EVALUATE EXPOSURE WINDOWS, EXPOSURE
MIXTURES, AND COMPOUNDING VULNERABILITY FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH HIGHER RISK. IT WILL TRAIN
MEMBERS OF VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES TO LEAD EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES ON BUILDING LOW-COST AND
EFFECTIVE CORSI-ROSENTHAL AIR FILTER BOXES AND OTHER WAYS TO MITIGATE EXPOSURESOUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION AND PUBLICATIONS TO EDUCATE AND TRAIN AIR QUALITY MANAGERS, PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, PEDIATRIC SPECIALISTS, PARENTS, CLINICIANS, AND COMMUNITY LEADERS ON IDENTIFYING THE MOST VULNERABLE GROUPS FOR WILDFIRE RELATED POLLUTANTS AND REDUCING THEIR EXPOSURE. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A REDUCTION IN HARMFUL EXPOSURE TO WILDFIRE-RELATED AIR POLLUTANTS AND IMPROVED HEALTH OF VULNERABLE RESIDENTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL AIR QUALITY MANAGERS, PUBLIC HEALTH SPECIALISTS, PEDIATRICIANS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, AND YOUNG CHILDREN AND OTHER VULNERABLE RESIDENTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY AND EXPAND COMMUNITY WATER AND SOIL TESTING PROGRAMS BY INTEGRATING HISTORICAL DATA WITH LOCAL KNOWLEDGE AND THE COMMUNITY GOALS AND ASSETS, AND FACILITATE DECISION-MAKING FOR TARGETING FUTURE WORK, INCLUDING COMMUNITY VISIONING FOR STORM WATER MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN THE UNDERSERVED TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN DUWAMISH VALLEY SO THEY MAY HAVE OWNERSHIP OVER ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING AND CLEANUP PROCESS THAT TRULY SUPPORT COMMUNITY NEEDS,. THE PROJECT WILL 1) ENSURE THAT THE PROJECT WILL MEET THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITIES BY THOROUGH SURVEYS, INTERVIEWS, AND SHARING OF PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED DATA; 2) DETERMINE THE EXTENT AND DEGREE OF CONTAMINATION AT THE SITE AS WELL AS THE RESEARCH GUIDANCE AND REPORTS THAT WILL BE MOST USEFUL TO COMMUNITY LEADERS; 3) MONITOR SOIL, WATER, AND SEDIMENT CONTAMINANTS (PAH, PCB, METALS, DIOXIN/FURANS) THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED DURING STORM WATER SURGES TO IDENTIFY AND MAP HIGH-RISK AREAS; AND 4) INFORM COMMUNITIES OF VIABLE SOLUTIONS TO BUILD RESILIENCE AND CAPACITY AGAINST MIGRATION OF WATER CONTAMINANTS. SUBRECIPIENT:DUWAMISH RIVER CLEANUP COALITION ($32,000) WILL CONVENE COMMUNITY SCIENCE WORKSHOPS AND ENSURE THE COMMUNITY NEEDS ARE PRIORITIZED AND CENTERED.

ENVIRONMENTAL COALITION OF SOUTH SEATTLE (ECOSS) ($15,000) - AS A COMMUNITY BASED ORGANIZATION, THEY WILL ASSIST IN CONVENING COMMUNITY SCIENCE WORKSHOPS THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS DATABASE AND PUBLICATIONS FOR MAKING SOUND EVIDENCE-BASED DECISIONS ON MITIGATING WATER CONTAMINANTS EXACERBATED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED HEALTH FOR THE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES AND RESIDENTS IN DUWAMISH VALLEY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE COMMUNITY DECISION MAKERS, PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANUP MANAGERS, COMMUNITY PLANNERS, AND TRIBAL LEADERS IN THE DUWAMISH VALLEY AND OTHER SIMILAR COMMUNITIES.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN DIVERSE CLIMATE-INDUCED CONCERNS RELATED TO WATER INFRASTRUCTURE AND WATER QUALITY AND THEIR EFFECTS ON HEALTH IN ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT AIMS TO BUILD CAPACITY AGAINST CLIMATE CHANGE RISKS BY ADDRESSING WATER INFRASTRUCTURE ISSUES IN ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) CONDUCT COMMUNITY-BASED MONITORING (CBM) AND DIRECT SAMPLING TO ASSESS WATER QUALITY; 2) GATHER SURVEYS AND INTERVIEWS AND PHOTOVOICE SUBMISSIONS TO CAPTURE WATER INSECURITY AND LOCAL VULNERABILITIES; 3) ASSESS THE CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF WATER QUALITY, WATER INSECURITY, AND LOCAL VULNERABILITIES ON HEALTH, MENTAL HEALTH AND NON-WESTERN PERSPECTIVE OF HEALTH USING STATISTICAL ANALYSES AND FUZZY-SET QUALITATIVE COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS; AND 4) BUILD RESILIENT WATER INFRASTRUCTURE CAPACITY.SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS ($303,681) WILL IDENTIFY TECHNOLOGY AND TECHNIQUES FOR REDUCING CLIMATE-BASED RISKS TO WATER INFRASTRUCTURE IDENTIFIED IN TASK 1.1. WATER INFRASTRUCTURE AND TASK 3.1 BUILD ADAPTIVE CAPACITY OF WATER INFRASTRUCTURE.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS (1) HYDRAULIC MODELS OF THE WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM AND OPEN-SOURCE DATA-DRIVEN ALGORITHMS AND CODES FOR LEAK DETECTION AND LOCALIZATION, (2) MAPS OF THE MOST VULNERABLE HOUSEHOLDS AT RISK OF WATER QUALITY AND INSECURITY, AND (3) COMPREHENSIVE MODELS SHOWING THE FACTORS THAT ARE THE MOST SIGNIFICANT IN DETERMINING HEALTH, MENTAL HEALTH AND NON-WESTERN HEALTH OUTCOMES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE RESILIENT WATER INFRASTRUCTURES AND IMPROVED HEALTH IN ALASKA NATIVE COMMUNITIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, IN ALASKA.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE CASCADING IMPACTS OF RECURRENT AND PROLONGED WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE ON HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF THE RESIDENTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER RELEVANT ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS SUCH AS SOCIAL ADVERSITY IN LOW-INCOME, MINORITY COMMUNITIES IN CALIFORNIA.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) ESTIMATE THE HEALTH EFFECTS OF SUB-DAILY EXPOSURE TO WILDFIRE-SPECIFIC PM2.5 IN CALIFORNIA, INCLUDING ACROSS SOCIAL VULNERABILITY FACTORS, WITH
PARTICULAR FOCUS ON EFFECTS WITHIN EJ COMMUNITIES; 2) ANALYZE COMMUNITY RECOVERY FROM SHORT-TERM HEALTH EFFECTS FOLLOWING EXPOSURE; 3) QUANTIFY INDOOR INFILTRATION OF WILDFIRE
SMOKE AND THE MITIGATING EFFECT OF HOUSING QUALITY AND BEHAVIORS; AND 4) WORK WITH COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP MITIGATION INTERVENTIONS TO FIT THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA - BERKELEY ($705,047) WILL (1) QUANTIFY WILDFIRE SPECIFIC FINE PARTICULATE MATTER FOR FIRE SEASONS, (2) ESTIMATE MAGNITUDE OF EFFECT BY WILDFIRE PM ON HEALTH OUTCOMES, AND (3) DETERMINE INDOOR PENETRATION BASED ON HOUSING ATTRIBUTES DATA. CENTRAL CALIFORNIA ASTHMA COLLABORATION (CCAC) ($60,000) WILL COORDINATE ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS, INCLUDING RECRUITING STAKEHOLDERS, ADMINISTRATING SURVEYS, AND CONDUCTING FOCUS GROUPS.  $23,100 TO SEVEN SUBAWARDEES (TBD) TO CO-DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PILOT ADAPTATION STRATEGIES.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS WITH MORE ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF WILDFIRE-SPECIFIC PM2.5 DISTRIBUTIONS ACROSS COMMUNITIES AND SMOKE INFILTRATION DATA FOR HOUSING ACROSS CALIFORNIA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE REDUCTION OF WILDFIRE-RELATED PM EXPOSURE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LOW-INCOME, MINORITY RESIDENTS LIVING IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ACROSS CALIFORNIA, PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS, AIR QUALITY SPECIALISTS, AND COMMUNITY PLANNERS.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO BUILD COMMUNITY-LEVEL RESILIENCE AGAINST INCREASED AIR AND WATER POLLUTION DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE MYSTIC RIVER WATERSHED. ACTIVITIES:: THE PROJECT WILL 1) USE A NOVEL MULTI-STRESSOR HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT (HIA) FRAMEWORK TO ENCODE COMMUNITY INSIGHTS INTO A HIGH-RESOLUTION GEOSPATIAL DATABASE CHARACTERIZING CHEMICAL EXPOSURES, VULNERABILITY, AND GEOGRAPHIC/SOCIODEMOGRAPHIC CO-OCCURRENCE OF HAZARDS; 2) DEVELOP IMPACT MODELS TO HIGHLIGHT LOCATIONS PRONE TO CUMULATIVE CLIMATE RISKS AND CHEMICAL EXPOSURES; 3) USE MULTI-STRESSOR EPIDEMIOLOGICAL ANALYSES TO EVALUATE CONJOINT OR CASCADING HAZARDS TO VULNERABLE PEOPLE AND NEIGHBORHOODS; AND 4) APPLY THE RESEARCH FINDINGS TO REFINE HEALTH RISKS AND TO INFORM STATE AND LOCAL POLICIES AND INVESTMENTS TO PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT. SUBRECIPIENT:MYSTIC RIVER WATERSHED ASSOCIATION (MYRWA, $180,000) WILL PARTNER WITH BU TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT SURVEY INSTRUMENTS IN THE COMMUNITY, CONVENE MEETINGS OF EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS TO ASSESS COMMUNITY PREFERENCES, PROVIDE CONTACT WITH LOCAL DECISION MAKERS TO FACILITATE SOLUTIONS-ORIENTED WORK, AND ENGAGE WITH ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEMBERS TO SOLICIT FEEDBACK ON GRANT PROGRESS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AND SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS. OUTPUTS INCLUDE A HIGH-RESOLUTION GEOSPATIAL DATABASE AND MAPPING TOOL THAT IS READILY RESPONSIVE TO COMMUNITY INTERESTS AND CONCERNS. THE TOOL WILL BE USED BY PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS AND COMMUNITY PLANNERS TO PRIORITIZE OPERATIONAL AND CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS NEEDED TO PREVENT AND DECREASE CHEMICAL EXPOSURES AND IMPROVE CLIMATE RESILIENCE AMONG VULNERABLE PEOPLE AND NEIGHBORHOODS OVER TIME. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED HUMAN HEALTH OF THE RESIDENTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE MYSTIC RIVER WATERSHED. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE COMMUNITIES IN THE MYSTIC RIVER WATERSHED AS WELL AS OTHER SIMILAR COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE NATION, AS WELL AS PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS AND STATE AND LOCAL RESOURCE MANAGERS.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO FILL SCIENTIFIC DATA GAPS THAT ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DEVELOPING COMMUNITY-CENTERED TOOLS TO ASSESS HEALTH IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND SOCIAL DISPARITIES IN RURAL TRIBAL AND AGING COMMUNITIES IN ALASKA.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) USE A CO-DEVELOPMENT PROCESS THAT ENGAGES ACADEMIC RESEARCHERS, STATE, TRIBAL, WILDFIRE MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC HEALTH ENTITIES, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS
TO ENVISION, DEVELOP, AND TEST LOCALLY-RELEVANT AND PRACTICAL TOOLS TO ACCESS THE STATE-OF-THE ART CLIMATE AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATA; 2) MODEL PROJECTIONS AND INFORMATION ON HEALTH AND
SOCIAL VULNERABILITY IN A USEFUL AND UNDERSTANDABLE WAY THAT ALLOWS COMMUNITIES TO ASSESS COMPOUNDING CLIMATE HAZARDS AND SOCIAL VULNERABILITIES; 3) PRIORITIZE CLIMATE-RELATED HEALTH IMPACTS AND VULNERABLE DEMOGRAPHIC GROUPS; AND 4) DESIGN EFFECTIVE INTERVENTIONS AND APPLY TO THE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN ALASKA.SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON ($270,000) WILL ASSIST WITH DESIGN AND FACILITATION OF WORKSHOPS, AND SUMMARIZING KEY FINDINGS FROM EACH WORKSHOP. UW COLLABORATORS WILL LEAD THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE USER GUIDE AND EVALUATION OF THE LOW COST SENSOR IMPLEMENTATION.
ALASKA NATIVE TRIBAL HEALTH CONSORTIUM (ANTHC,$45,000) WILL HELP RECRUIT COMMUNITY PARTNERS, PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT TEAM WORKSHOPS, AND SUPPORT AND REVIEW THE STORY-BASED
USER GUIDE TO ENSURE THAT THE FINAL TOOL AND GUIDE ARE CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE AND GENERALIZABLE FOR THE ALASKAN COMMUNITIES THEY WORK WITH.
UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS (UAF, $301,617) WILL ASSIST WITH COMMUNITY PARTNER RECRUITMENT, DESIGN AND FACILITATION OF WORKSHOPS, AND SUMMARIZING KEY FINDINGS FROM EACH WORKSHOP. THEY WILL ALSO TAKE THE LEAD ON DATA MANAGEMENT, MODELING, AND WEB DESIGN ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT, AND WILL WORK WITH ALL PROJECT TEAM MEMBERS TO MAKE THESE DATA AND MODEL OUTPUTS FULLY ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. THEY WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DATA CURATION, QUALITY CONTROL, AND STORAGE AND METADATA CREATION.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS, AS WELL AS COMMUNITY-BASED ASSESSMENT TOOLS FOR PUBLIC AGENCIES, COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PLANNERS, AND WILDFIRE MANAGEMENT SPECIALISTS. EXPECTED OUTPUTS INCLUDE 1) A STATEWIDE COMMUNITY-DRIVEN, SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT, WEB-BASED TOOL IN ALASKA TO ASSESS THE CUMULATIVE HEALTH IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, 2) AN ASSESSMENT OF MAJOR CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO VULNERABILITY TO WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF TRIBAL, PUBLIC HEALTH, AND WILDFIRE MANAGEMENT STAKEHOLDERS, 3) SCENARIOS TO SHOWCASE EXAMPLES OF COMMUNITY-DRIVEN APPROACHES TO USE THE CO-DEVELOPED TOOL, INCLUDING TO ASSESS VULNERABILITY AND GUIDE RESPONSIVE INTERVENTIONS, AND 4) AN UNDERSTANDING OF MAJOR CHALLENGES AND FACILITATORS FOR DEPLOYMENT OF LOW-COST AIR QUALITY SENSORS IN ALASKAN COMMUNITIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED HEALTH OF THE RESIDENTS IN TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN ALASKA. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES AND PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICIALS IN ALASKA AND OTHER SIMILAR COMMUNITIES.

DESCRIPTION:THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO ADVANCE THE THEORY AND PRACTICE OF SANITATION JUSTICE (EQUITABLE ACCESS, AGENCY, AND ADAPTIVE CAPACITY FOR SANITATION INFRASTRUCTURE) AMIDST INTENSIFYING CLIMATE STRESSORS FOR MARGINALIZED U.S. COMMUNITIES.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL 1) COMPARE SANITATION-RELATED EXPOSURE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS FOR AN URBAN AND RURAL COMMUNITY; 2) PRIORITIZE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE STRESSORS ON SANITATION INFRASTRUCTURE AND CONTAMINANT HEALTH IMPACTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; 3) DESIGN AND EVALUATE IMPROVED SANITATION INFRASTRUCTURE TO REDUCE EXPOSURE WHILE MAXIMIZING ECONOMIC VIABILITY AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:BAYLOR COLLEGE OF MEDICINE ($340,000) WILL LEAD OBJECTIVE 1, AND IN PARTICULAR TASK 1.1 FOCUSED ON PARASITE QUANTIFICATION. CENTER FOR RURAL ENTERPRISE AND ENVIRONMENTAL (CREEJ) ($340,000) WILL CO-LEAD OBJECTIVES 2 AND 3, SPECIFICALLY THE SANITATION INFRASTRUCTURE SURVEY (TASK 2.1), WORKSHOPS FOCUSED ON TECHNOLOGY DOWN-SELECTION (TASK 3.1) AND PILOT-SCALE INVESTIGATIONS (TASK 3.2).OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION FOR COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PLANNERS REGARDING DEMOGRAPHICS AND CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE, AS WELL AS OPEN-SOURCE DATASETS ON SANITATION QUALITY AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES AND RESIDENTS OF UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO RESEARCH AND BRING ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE-FOCUSED STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE SEPTIC FAILURES IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES UNDER THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS OF RISING SEA LEVELS AND INCREASED FLOODING.ACTIVITIES:RESEARCHERS WILL 1) IDENTIFY AND PARTNER WITH VULNERABLE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THAT ARE AT RISK OF SEPTIC SYSTEM FAILURES NOW AND IN THE FUTURE DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGES; 2) ADDRESS THE ANTECEDENT CONDITIONS (INCLUDING HISTORICAL SETTLEMENT PATTERNS AND EXCLUSION FROM MUNICIPAL SEWERS) THAT POTENTIALLY EXACERBATE CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE BY COLLECTING PRIMARY DATA ON SEPTIC HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT TO DEVELOP COMPOSITE RISKS; AND 3) EVALUATE WHERE AND HOW SPECIFIC POLICY AND TECHNOLOGY SOLUTIONS CAN ADDRESS THE COMPOUNDED RISKS, WHILE ENSURING THAT BENEFITS ACCRUE IN A WAY THAT ADDRESSES PAST DISCRIMINATORY PRACTICES.SUBRECIPIENT:RESOURCES FOR THE FUTURE ($477,000) WILL MEASURE THE VALUE OF SEWER AS CAPTURED IN PROPERTY VALUES AND AS MEASURED BY THE PREFERENCES OF LOCAL RESIDENTS AND COMMUNITY LEADERS. GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY ($226,000) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FLOOD HAZARDS MODELING COMPONENT OF THE PROPOSED WORK, INCLUDING CLIMATE INDUCED COASTAL FLOODING AND SEA-LEVEL RISE INUNDATION. SOUTHEAST RURAL COMMUNITY ASSISTANCE PROJECT ($117,705) WILL CO-PRODUCE RESEARCH (E.G., GUIDING RESEARCH QUESTIONS TO ENSURE THEY ARE RELEVANT); SUPPORT DATA-SHARING WHERE APPROPRIATE; ADMINISTER A SURVEY OR SUPPORT RESIDENT INTERVIEWS; SUPPORT COLLECTION OF WATER/SOIL SAMPLES; AND SUPPORT RESEARCH OUTREACH.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS AS WELL AS SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS, EDUCATIONAL INFORMATION, AND SOLUTIONS FOR PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES AND COMMUNITY PLANNERS TO PREVENT AND MITIGATE SEPTIC FAILURES IN UNDERSERVED COASTAL COMMUNITIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE PREVENTION OF WATER CONTAMINATION FROM SEPTIC FAILURES AND IMPROVED PUBLIC HEALTH. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE UNDERSERVED COASTAL COMMUNITIES IN EASTERN MARYLAND, STATE AND LOCAL WATER RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES.

DESCRIPTION:THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ENGAGE SMALL COMMUNITIES THAT ARE RELIANT ON SMALL WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS AND EMPOWER THEM TO IDENTIFY STRATEGIES THAT SUSTAIN WATER QUALITY, QUANTITY, AND ACCESSIBILITY AND PROVIDE RESILIENT CONTINUOUS ACCESS TO POTABLE WATER. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CHALLENGES AND PROBLEMS CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND CHANGE POSE TO WATER DISTRIBUTION AND QUALITY THAT MIGHT IMPACT PUBLIC HEALTH THROUGH WATERBORNE DISEASES. ACTIVITIES:METEOROLOGICAL OBSERVATIONS WILL ESTABLISH CLIMATE RELATIONSHIPS IMPORTANT TO PATHOGEN EXPOSURE AND PROVIDE INFORMATION TO UNDERSTAND HIGH RESOLUTION CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECTIONS FOR
MICROCLIMATES. COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT METHODS, KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS, DATA COLLECTION OF RAINFALL, WATER QUALITY, AND SURVEILLANCE OF WATERBORNE PATHOGENS WILL BE CONDUCTED. RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH WATER OPERATORS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO DETERMINE COMMUNITY-LED, SCIENCE-BASED SOLUTIONS APPROPRIATE FOR EACH CONTEXT TO MITIGATE HEALTH IMPACTS. OBSERVED FACTORS LIKE NUMBER SERVED, FINANCIAL STATUS, ACCUMULATED RAINFALL, WATER SOURCE, WATER TREATMENT, AND POWER SOURCE WHEN USED WITH HIGH-RESOLUTION CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECTIONS WILL PROVIDE HOLISTIC SOLUTIONS FOR RISK ASSESSMENT AND BUILDING RESILIENCE.SUBRECIPIENT:THE INTER AMERICAN UNIVERSITY ($490,660) WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE ON WATER SAMPLING DESIGN, COMMUNITY VISITS, DESIGN OF WATER QUALITY RELATED DATA COLLECTION, AND FORMS FOR SELF -REPORTED HEALTH DATA FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND WILL CONDUCT COMMUNITY VISITS AND ANALYZE DATA RELATED TO WATER QUALITY AND HUMAN HEALTH. NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY ($180,649) WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE ON CLIMATE RELATED DATA COLLECTION AND DESIGN THIS ASPECT OF INFORMATION COLLECTION AND ANALYSES. THIS INCLUDES TRAINING COMMUNITY LEADERS AND MEMBERS TO COLLECT AND REPORT DATA ON RAIN QUANTITY AND FREQUENCY, TEMPERATURE, AND OTHER INDICATORS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION REGARDING WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY RISK ASSESSMENTS FOR CAPACITY BUILDING. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ADVANCING THE SCIENCE AND UNDERSTANDING OF IMPACTS OF WEATHER AND CLIMATIC CHANGE ON RURAL COMMUNITIES AND MICROCLIMATES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS IN PUERTO RICO AND OTHER SIMILAR COMMUNITIES.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO INVESTIGATE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE DURING PREGNANCY AND THE HEALTH OF THE NEWBORN BABY AND MOTHER, AS WELL AS TO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND OTHER PREVENTIVE SOLUTIONS TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.
ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL UTILIZE AN EXISTING SPATIOTEMPORALLY RESOLVED LOWER-COST AIR MONITORING NETWORK IN RICHMOND, CA AND AGGREGATE DATA FROM OTHER NETWORKS ACROSS CONTRA COSTA COUNTY FOR THREE AIMS: (1) CHARACTERIZING LOCAL DISPARITIES IN EXPOSURE TO AIR POLLUTION, HEAT, AND HUMIDITY, AND THE IMPACT OF WILDFIRES ON EXACERBATING THESE DISPARITIES; (2) ASSESSING RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN EXPOSURE AND PERINATAL OUTCOMES; AND (3) DEVELOPING MODEL COMMUNITY-DRIVEN INTERVENTIONS AND POLICIES TO REDUCE EXPOSURES AND HEALTH IMPACTS. SUBRECIPIENT:UC BERKELEY ($486,995) WILL ASSIST WITH ANALYSIS, CLEANING, AND MANAGEMENT FOR EXPOSURE DATA AND WILL ESTABLISH AUTOMATED QUALITY ASSURANCE FOR ALL SOURCES OF DATA.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL INFORMATION ON THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE SMOKE ON INFANT AND MATERNAL HEALTH COMMUNICATED TO PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, PEDIATRIC SPECIALISTS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, AND PREGNANT MOTHERS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE MOTHERS, CHILDREN, AND PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AND SIMILAR COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ENGAGE S.E. QUEENS RESIDENTS IN THE MEASUREMENTS OF KEY AIR POLLUTANTS (NO2, O3, SO2, PM2.5, TOXIC METALS AND PFAS), THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED
PARTICIPATORY RESEARCH (CBPR), INCREASING THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF CLIMATIC FACTORS AND AIR POLLUTION IMPACTS ON HEALTH, AND EMPOWERING THEM TO USE SUCH KNOWLEDGE TO INFORM POLICY ON ALLEVIATING CLIMATE IMPACTS AND SUSTAINING GOOD HEALTH.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL TEST THE HYPOTHESIS THAT CBPR IS A POWERFUL DRIVER IN PROMOTING AIR POLLUTION REDUCTION WITH THE AIM OF PROTECTING THE HEALTH OF S.E. QUEENS RESIDENTS AND THE ENVIRONMENT. THE PROJECT WILL (1) DEMONSTRATE THE IMPACT OF POLLUTANT EMISSIONS FROM NEARBY WASTE STATIONS ON AIR QUALITY IN S.E. QUEENS THROUGH RESEARCH FIELD MEASUREMENTS; (2) TRAIN RESIDENTS TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY SCIENCE STRATEGIES SUCH AS CROWDSOURCING TOOLS WITH NEW KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THE MEASUREMENTS, ENABLING RESIDENTS FACING ENVIRONMENTAL INJUSTICE TO MOBILIZE NEW INNOVATIVE, LOW-COST, REPLICABLE STRATEGIES LEADING TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BETTER MANAGEMENT OF WASTE TRANSFER STATIONS; AND (3) TRANSLATE THE RESEARCH DATA AND COMMUNITY INPUT INTO STATE AND LOCAL CLIMATE AND POLICY SOLUTIONS FOR TRAFFIC EMISSION REDUCTION AND RELIEF FROM CURRENT HEALTH STRESSORS, IMPROVING QUALITY OF LIFE.  SUBRECIPIENT:CUNY-MEDGAR EVERS COLLEGE ($245,629) WILL PROVIDE MEASUREMENT/MONITORING OF AIR POLLUTANTS INCLUDING PM2.5 AND PFAS.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY ($335,076) WILL (1) LEAD SAMPLING EFFORTS AT THREE SITES TO DETERMINE TOXIC METALS ASSOCIATED WITH PM2.5, (2) PARTICIPATE IN SAMPLING PREPARATION AND ANALYTICAL LAB PROCEDURES, (3) SUPERVISE A GRADUATE STUDENT, AND (4) LEAD LAB TOUR TO PROMOTE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT.

OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL RESEARCH REPORTS, AS WELL AS JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS WITH CRITICAL DATA ADDRESSING URGENT ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH URBAN, MINORITY, AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE NEVER BEEN INVESTIGATED IN NEW YORK CITY. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED HEALTH AND WELL-BEING FOR RESIDENTS LIVING IN LOW-INCOME URBAN MINORITY COMMUNITIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, STATE AND LOCAL POLICY MAKERS, ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS, AND COMMUNITY LEADERS.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE RESEARCH IS TO EXAMINE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG BASEMENT INDOOR AIR QUALITY, AIR PATHOGENS AND CONTAMINANTS, BASEMENT MOISTURE, DAILY RAINFALL EXTREMES, HOUSING AND NEIGHBORHOOD CONDITIONS, AND CUMULATIVE HEALTH IMPACTS FOR RESIDENTS ACROSS THE LIFESPAN UNDER THE CONTEXT OF INCREASED RAINFALLS AND FLOODING DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGES. 

ACTIVITIES:THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL: (1) CHARACTERIZE BACTERIAL AND FUNGAL PATHOGENS AND INDOOR AIR QUALITY (E.G., RADON CONCENTRATIONS, HUMIDITY) IN RESIDENTIAL BASEMENTS IN TWO PREDOMINANTLY BLACK, LOW INCOME, URBAN NEIGHBORHOODS IN PITTSBURGH; (2) CHARACTERIZE RESPIRATORY AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CONDITIONS OF RESIDENTS EXPOSED TO MICROBIAL PATHOGENS; (3) EXAMINE ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN BASEMENT PATHOGENS AND CONTAMINANTS, BASEMENT MOISTURE, DAILY RAINFALL EXTREMES, HOUSING AND NEIGHBORHOOD CONDITIONS, AND CUMULATIVE HEALTH IMPACTS FOR RESIDENTS ACROSS THE LIFESPAN; AND (4) DEVELOP AND DISSEMINATE COMMUNITY-BASED SOLUTIONS TO ADDRESS CUMULATIVE HEALTH IMPACTS OF PATHOGEN/CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE RELATED TO WET BASEMENTS AND HEAVY RAINFALL EVENTS.
SUBRECIPIENT:BLACK ENVIRONMENTAL COLLECTIVE ($45,000) WILL FACILITATE NETWORKING AND COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND ORGANIZATIONS IN THE HOMEWOOD AND HILL DISTRICT NEIGHBORHOODS. THE COLLABORATION WILL ENHANCE EFFORTS TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY-BASED SOLUTIONS TO HEAVY RAINFALL EVENTS, WET BASEMENTS, AND RELATED HEALTH CHALLENGES.
THE UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH ($464,575) WILL COLLECT AND ANALYZE ALL ENVIRONMENTAL DATA IN THE PROJECT.
THE HOMEWOOD CHILDREN'S VILLAGE ($160,000) WILL MANAGE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND SUPPORT FOR PARTICIPANTS OF THE LEADERSHIP INITIATIVE.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS CRITICAL SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION FOR PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, INDOOR AIR SPECIALISTS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, AND HOUSING AUTHORITIES INCLUDING POTENTIAL EVIDENCE THAT HOUSING AND WEATHER CONDITIONS AND INDOOR AIR QUALITY CAN HAVE ADVERSE HEALTH IMPACTS DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE RESIDENTS IN LOW-INCOME, PREDOMINANTLY BLACK UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THE PITTSBURG AREA AND SIMILAR COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY COMMUNITY STRESSORS AND RESILIENCE-ENHANCING ASSETS THAT SHAPE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED EXPOSURES [HEAT, OZONE (O3), FINE PARTICULATE MATTER (PM2.5)] AND CHILD HEALTH.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL: 1) WORK WITH NY PEDIATRIC ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SPECIALTY UNITS (PEHSU) AND COMMUNITY AND GOVERNMENT PARTNERS TO PRIORITIZE STRESSORS AND ASSETS; 2) LEVERAGE COMPLETE PATIENT-LEVEL DATA ON ALL CHILD (AGE 0-17) EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT VISITS AND HOSPITALIZATIONS IN UPSTATE NY OVER 2005-2019; 3) EXAMINE STRESSORS IDENTIFIED BY THE NYS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION CLIMATE JUSTICE WORKING GROUP, AND APPLY THE RESILIENCE ACTIVATION FRAMEWORK, WHICH ORGANIZES ASSETS IN FIVE DOMAINS (HUMAN, ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, POLITICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL CAPITAL); 4) GENERATE DAILY FINE-SCALE EXPOSURE ESTIMATES FOR HEAT, O3, AND PM2.5, AND EXAMINE VARIATION IN EXPOSURE-HEALTH RELATIONSHIPS USING CASE-CROSSOVER METHODS; AND 5) APPLY CLIMATE PROJECTIONS TO ESTIMATE IMPACTS UNDER VARYING EMISSIONS SCENARIOS, AND, WITH PARTNERS, INTEGRATE FINDINGS INTO LOCAL AND STATE CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND PEDIATRIC CLINICAL INITIATIVES.SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURG ($120,551) WILL SUPPORT ALL ASPECTS OF DATA MANAGEMENT AND GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) ANALYSIS FOR THE PROJECT. ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI ($527,838) WILL PROVIDE LOCAL CLINICAL EXPERTISE IN CHILD HEALTH OUTCOMES, ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURES, AND COMMUNITY ASSETS, INPUT ON USE OF NY CHILDREN'S HEALTH DATA, AND ASSIST ANALYSIS OF ASSET INDICATORS AND ADVISE ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF STATISTICAL ANALYSIS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS INDICATORS AND MAPS OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS TO PROVIDE PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, PEDIATRIC SPECIALISTS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, AND PARENTS WITH EVIDENCE THAT TAILORED INVESTMENTS IN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES TODAY CAN ALLEVIATE CURRENT AND FUTURE CLIMATE IMPACTS ON CHILDREN'S HEALTH. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE PARENTS AND CHILDREN IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN NEW YORK STATE AND SIMILAR COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ANALYZE THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSOR EXPOSURES ON PERSONAL HEALTH OUTCOMES OF RESIDENTS LIVING IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE INDEPENDENT, LATENT, CUMULATIVE, AND INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS (PM2.5, CRITERIA AIR POLLUTANTS, INDOOR AIR CONTAMINANTS, TRAFFIC RELATED POLLUTION, COMBUSTION RELATED CONTAMINANTS) AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSORS FROM THE BUILT, NATURAL, PHYSICAL AND SOCIAL ENVIRONMENTS, INHERENT PERSONAL CHARACTERISTICS, ACTIVITIES, AND BEHAVIORS, ON THE PROGRESSION OF DISPARATE HEALTH OUTCOMES. ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL COMPARE THE ARRAY OF AVAILABLE DATA IN BROAD CATEGORIES OF CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSOR EXPOSURES, AND FOUR SOURCES OF DE-IDENTIFIED PERSONAL HEALTH DATA WILL BE CROSS-EXAMINED TO PLACES OF RESIDENCE IN LOW-INCOME, UNDERSERVED, AND HIGH-INCOME COMMUNITY COHORTS FOR THE YEARS 2014-2020. THE HEALTH OUTCOMES INVESTIGATED WILL INCLUDE MENTAL HEALTH, SUBSTANCE ABUSE, OUTPATIENT DIALYSIS, STROKE, RESPIRATORY DISEASE, HEART DISEASE, DIABETES, OBESITY, HYPERTENSION, CANCER, KIDNEY DISEASE, OSTEOPOROSIS, AND ADVERSE PREGNANCY OUTCOMES. THE RESEARCH WILL REVEAL IMPORTANT KNOWLEDGE REGARDING WHICH RESIDENTS EXHIBIT DIFFERENTIAL RISK TRAJECTORIES FOR DISPARATE HEALTH AND POLICY OUTCOMES AT THE POPULATION LEVEL IN RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED CHEMICAL AND NON-CHEMICAL STRESSOR EXPOSURES FROM THE BUILT, NATURAL, PHYSICAL, AND SOCIAL ENVIRONMENT. SUBRECIPIENT:MEHARRY MEDICAL COLLEGE ($91,055) WILL PROVIDE THE DATA CURATION FOR THE PROJECT. UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE ($89,665) WILL LEAD THE EFFORT TO DESIGN, DEVELOP, SYNTHESIZE AND IMPLEMENT NOVEL COMBINATORIAL ALGORITHMS REQUIRED FOR THE ANALYSIS OF HIGHLY HETEROGENEOUS DATA RELEVANT TO THIS PROJECT. UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI ($116,308) WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE IN THE APPLICATION OF REMOTE SENSING AND GIS TECHNIQUES.
OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS, AND COMMUNICATION DOCUMENTS TO BOTH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH POLICY PROFESSIONALS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING ABOUT THE HEALTH RISKS THREATENING UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN OHIO.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN OHIO AND OTHER SIMILAR COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS COMMUNITY LEADERS AND STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICIALS.

DESCRIPTION:THE FOCUS OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO STUDY WILLINGNESS TO PAY (WTP) FOR WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS IN MIDWESTERN RESERVOIRS. RESEARCHERS WILL BE MEASURING LINKAGES BETWEEN WATER QUALITY AND PROVISION OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES TO INFORM POTENTIAL SCENARIOS AND ECOSYSTEM ATTRIBUTES. WTP WILL BE MEASURED BY INCORPORATING CHOICE EXPERIMENTS TO DETERMINE IMPACTS OF WATER QUALITY RESTORATION ALONG WITH SCENARIOS AND ACCOUNTING FOR ECOSYSTEM SERVICES BUNDLING. LASTLY, RESEARCH WILL EVALUATE DEMOGRAPHIC AND SPATIAL CHARACTERISTICS THAT MAY INFORM THE EXTENT TO WHICH WATER QUALITY CHANGES IMPACT WTP.ACTIVITIES:NON-MARKET VALUATION TECHNIQUES WILL BE USED TO CHARACTERIZE THE MARKET EXTENT. THE GRANTEE WILL ALSO INCORPORATE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES MODELING TO INFORM PLAUSIBLE SCENARIOS AND ECOSYSTEM ATTRIBUTES IN VALUATION QUESTIONNAIRES. FINALLY, THE GRANTEE WILL INTEGRATE DEMOGRAPHIC, AND SPATIAL CHARACTERISTICS THAT MAY INFORM THE EXTENT TO WHICH WATER QUALITY CHANGES IMPACT WTP.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD TO KANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY. 
CO-PIS DR. TRISHA MOORE AND DR. ALEKSEY SHESHUKOV WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR CREATION, CALIBRATION AND VALIDATION, AND GENERATION OF SCENARIOS AND RESULTS FOR A COUPLED WATERSHED HYDROLOGY-RESERVOIR EUTROPHICATION MODEL. THE MODEL FRAMEWORK DEVELOPED BY MOORE AND SHESHUKOV WILL BE APPLIED TO UP TO 3 STUDY RESERVOIRS.  OUTCOMES:THE EXPECTED OUTCOME WILL BE TO FORECAST THE REALISTIC FUTURE OF MIDWEST RESERVOIRS. THIS INCLUDES PUBLICATIONS DESCRIBING RESEARCH RESULTS AND WILLINGNESS TO PAY ESTIMATES FOR WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT. IN ADDITION, SWAT-BATHTUB MODELS FOR THREE RESERVOIRS AND THEIR RESPECTIVE WATERSHED AREAS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE PUBLIC, STATE AND LOCAL REGULATORS, WATER QUALITY PROGRAM MANAGERS, AND COMMUNITIES LOCATED CLOSE TO THE RESERVOIRS TO BE STUDIED.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON DEVELOPING MODELS TO DETERMINE THE IMPACTS OF WATER QUALITY CHANGES ON PROPERTY VALUES BY STUDYING THREE LARGER, SOMEWHAT UNDERSTUDIED BODIES OF WATER INCLUDING PUGET SOUND, LONG ISLAND SOUND, AND THE TEXAS GULF COAST.ACTIVITIES:THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL IMPLEMENT A TWO-STAGE ECONOMETRIC MODEL OF RECREATION AND HOUSING DEMAND TO EVALUATE THE RECREATIONAL AND AMENITY VALUE OF WATER QUALITY CHANGES IN THE THREE REGIONS. THE TEAM WILL ALSO COMPARE ESTIMATES ACROSS WATERBODY TYPES, REGIONS, AND SOCIOECONOMIC CHARACTERISTICS OF PROPERTY OWNERS AND RECREATORS.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD 1, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND BALTIMORE COUNTRY: ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COLLABORATING WITH THE OTHER PIS TO COLLECT DATA ON WATER QUALITY, RECREATION BEHAVIOR, AND HOUSING MARKETS FROM FOUR MAJOR US COASTAL AREAS, ESTIMATING A TWO-STAGE
ECONOMETRIC MODEL TO QUANTIFY CAPITALIZATION EFFECTS OF BOTH LOCAL AND RECREATIONAL WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS IN THESE REGIONS, PREPARING MANUSCRIPTS DETAILING THE RESEARCH APPROACH AND RESULTS, AND PRESENTING RESULTS TO USEPA AND AT ACADEMIC
CONFERENCES.
