SUBAWARD 2, UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA-CHAMPAIGN: ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COLLECTING DATA ON WATER QUALITY, RECREATION ACTIVITY AND HOUSING MARKETS FOR FOUR MAJOR U.S. COASTAL AREAS, ESTIMATING A TWO-STAGE ECONOMETRIC MODEL TO ESTIMATE THE BENEFITS OF AMBIENT WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS, PREPARING ACADEMIC MANUSCRIPTS AND PRESENTING RESULTS AT ACADEMIC CONFERENCES.OUTCOMES:THE TEAM WILL PRODUCE REGIONAL WATER QUALITY VALUATION ESTIMATES FOR THREE UNDER-STUDIED REGIONS, AT LEAST THREE PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL ARTICLES, AT LEAST SIX SCHOLARLY PRESENTATIONS, TWO DOCTORAL DISSERTATIONS, AND BROAD DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS VIA POLICY-ORIENTED PUBLICATIONS, PRESENTATIONS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE PUBLIC, STATE AND LOCAL REGULATORS, WATER QUALITY PROGRAM MANAGERS, AND COMMUNITIES SURROUNDING PUGET SOUND, LONG ISLAND SOUND, AND THE TEXAS GULF COAST.

DESCRIPTION:THE STUDY SEEKS TO PROVIDE INSIGHT ON THE EXTENT OF THE MARKET, WILLINGNESS TO PAY (WTP), AND DISTANCE DECAY IN REPRESENTATIVE WATERSHEDS WITHIN EACH OF THE NINE ECOREGIONS OF THE US. THE PROJECT ALSO SEEKS TO DEVELOP DATA AND MODELS TO QUANTIFY A 'BIOLOGICAL CONDITION GRADIENT (BCG)' IN WATERSHEDS BY USING STATED AND REVEALED PREFERENCE SURVEYS ACROSS THE COUNTRY. BIOLOGICAL INDEX DATA FROM STATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCIES WILL BE ASSEMBLED TO PREDICT PLACE-SPECIFIC BASELINE BCG SCORES AND INTEGRATE THESE INTO THE SURVEY PROTOCOLS. ONCE COMPLETED, THE RESEARCHERS WILL APPLY THE BENEFIT FUNCTIONS FROM SURVEYS IN A NATIONAL INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT MODELING (IAM) FRAMEWORK TO CONSIDER THE EFFICIENCY AND DISTRIBUTIONAL CONSEQUENCES OF POTENTIAL POLICY ACTIONS.ACTIVITIES:THE RESEARCH WILL FIRST EXPAND THE ASSESSMENT OF BASELINE BIOLOGICAL CONDITION GRADIENT CONDITIONS TO A NATIONWIDE SCALE WHICH WILL ALLOW THE RESEARCH TEAM TO ADAPT THE SURVEY INSTRUMENT TO MEASURE AND COMPARE TOTAL VALUES FOR MAJOR ECOREGIONS ACROSS THE COUNTRY, INCLUDING REGIONS THAT ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN THE BODY OF PRIOR VALUATION RESEARCH. SECOND, THE TEAM  WILL SUPPLEMENT THE STATED PREFERENCE ESTIMATES OF TOTAL VALUE WITH REVEALED PREFERENCE RECREATION DEMAND ESTIMATES. LAST, THE TEAM WILL INCORPORATE A NATIONWIDE BCG VALUATION MODULE INTO THEIR ONGOING INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT MODEL DEVELOPMENT WORK THAT AIMS TO PROVIDE BROADSCALE WATER QUALITY VALUATION CAPABILITIES.  SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA:
PI FINLAY AND RESEARCHER DOLPH WILL BE WORKING ON ALL OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT.  PI FINLAY WILL ADVISE ON THE STUDY DESIGN, INTERPRET FOR LAY AUDIENCES AND SUPERVISE THE PROJECT.  RESEARCHER DOLPH WILL OVERSEE ASSEMBLY AND COMPILATION OF DATASETS, CO-SUPERVISE THE UW PHD STUDENT, CONDUCT ANALYSES, ASSIST IN SUMMARIZATION FOR LAY AUDIENCES, AND AUTHOR PEER-REVIEWED RESEARCH FOR PUBLICATION.

IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY:
DR. JI WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE RESEARCH TEAM IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROPOSED NATIONWIDE NON-MARKET VALUATION SURVEY, ESPECIALLY THE REVEALED PREFERENCE PART. THIS INCLUDES SUCH TASKS AS DEVELOPING SURVEY QUESTIONS, WRITING AND IMPLEMENTING THE ONLINE SURVEY, DATA ANALYSIS, AND WRITING RESEARCH RESULTS.

UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS: 
PI KAISER WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE STUDY DESIGN, OVERSEE EFFORTS TO USE RESULTS FROM THE STUDIES TO UPDATE AN NATIONAL INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT MODEL.

UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE:
PI VOSSLER WILL ASSIST WITH THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROPOSAL NATION-WIDE SURVEY, DATA ANALYSIS, AND WRITING THE RESEARCH RESULTS.  HE WILL ALSO AID WITH EFFORTS TO OBTAIN IRB APPROVAL FOR HUMAN SUBJECTS RESEARCH.

CORNELL:
PI KLING WILL ASSIST IN SURVEY DESIGN, FOCUS GROUPS, AND SURVEY IMPLEMENTATION. SHE WILL WORK WITH TEAM MEMBERS TO PROVIDE NEEDED LINKAGES BETWEEN THE SURVEY RESULTS AND MODULES OF THE INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT MODEL.  SHE IS NOT REQUESTING ANY FUNDS FROM THIS PROJECT.

OUTCOMES:THE RESEARCH WILL  GENERATE SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE AND PRODUCTION OF ESTIMATES THAT MAY CONTRIBUTE TO COST-BENEFIT ANALYSES AND MORE EFFICIENT PUBLIC POLICY. OUTPUTS FROM THE PROJECT INCLUDE A VALUATION FRAMEWORK TO RECOVER SCIENTIFICALLY VALID ESTIMATES OF THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF SURFACE WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS AT NATIONWIDE LOCATIONS AND AN INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT MODULE TO ALLOW PREDICTION OF THE TOTAL BENEFITS, ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE CONSEQUENCES, AND OTHER DISTRIBUTIONAL FEATURES OF SPECIFIC WATER QUALITY POLICIES. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE RESEARCH PAPERS, CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS, POLICY BRIEFINGS, AND INFORMAL UPDATES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCIES, ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMISTS, AND THE PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP A NON-MARKET VALUATION SURVEY ADMINISTERED TO RESIDENTS ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER TO EVALUATE HOW BENEFITS VARY ACROSS SOCIOECONOMIC AND GEOGRAPHIC SCALES AND POPULATIONS OF CONCERN. RESEARCH WILL EVALUATE TRADEOFFS BETWEEN EQUITY AND EFFICIENCY WITH RESPECT TO WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS AND RIVER RESTORATION AND WILL ALSO EXPLORE HOW DIFFERENT METHODS LEAD TO ALTERNATIVE POLICY CONCLUSIONS RESULTING IN BETTER APPROACHES/TOOLS FOR POTENTIAL POLICY ACTIONS. OVERALL, THE RESEARCH WILL EMPOWER COMMUNITIES TO ADVOCATE FOR THEIR PRIORITIES AND WILL LEAD TO IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE BENEFITS AND DISTRIBUTION OF WATER QUALITY CHANGES. ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE A NON-MARKET VALUATION SURVEY ADMINISTERED TO RESIDENTS OF THE 246 COUNTIES AND PARISHES THAT BORDER OR ARE ADJACENT TO THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER. THE SURVEY WILL ASK RESPONDENTS TO REPORT DAY AND OVERNIGHT TRIPS TO THE RIVER AND WILL INCLUDE A DISCRETE CHOICE REFERENDUM BASED ON PROPOSED CHANGES IN WATERSHED RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT, RECREATIONAL, CULTURAL, AND/OR ECOLOGICAL VALUES. IN ADDITION TO A 'PUSH TO WEB' APPROACH BASED ON POSTCARD MAILERS TO A RANDOMLY-SELECTED ADDRESS#8208;BASED SAMPLE, POTENTIAL SURVEY PARTICIPANTS WILL BE IDENTIFIED VIA SOCIAL MEDIA PROFILES AND SIGNAGE AT RIVER LOCATIONS WILL DIRECT VISITORS TO AN ONLINE SURVEY. ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS WORKING ON ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE ALONG THE RIVER WILL TAKE THE FORM OF PARTICIPATORY WORKSHOPS AND CO-DESIGN OF CITIZEN SCIENCE APPROACHES THAT ADDRESS COMMUNITY-ARTICULATED PRIORITIES FOR RESTORATION OR MANAGEMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON, LEAD PI, SPENCER WOOD
TEAM MEMBERS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON WILL:
-DEVELOP, TEST, AND DEPLOY APPROACHES FOR USING NEW TECHNOLOGY AND DATA SOURCES TO ELICIT INFORMATION FROM COMMUNITIES WITHIN THE STUDY CORRIDOR.
-STORE AND AGGREGATE RAW DATA TO CHARACTERIZE POPULATIONS
-SUMMARIZE FINDINGS IN REPORTS AND PUBLICATIONS

MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY, LEAD PI, DR. FRANK LUPI
TEAM MEMBERS FROM MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY WILL:
-CONTRIBUTE TO THE DESIGN, TESTING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WATER QUALITY VALUES USING THE SURVEY DATA AND AVAILABLE SECONDARY DATA
-ADVISE O N AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE ECONOMIC MODELING OF WATER QUALITY VALUES USING THE SURVEY DATA AND AVAILABLE SECONDARY DATA.
-CONTRIBUTE TO AND CO-AUTHOR PROJECT-RELATED PUBLICATIONS.OUTCOMES:GRANT RESULTS INCLUDE NEW METHODS OF ELICITING ENVIRONMENTAL VALUES AND INSIGHTS INTO HOW DIFFERENT METHODS LEAD TO ALTERNATIVE POLICY CONCLUSIONS ACROSS EQUITY AND EFFICIENCY OBJECTIVES. IN ADDITION TO PEER REVIEWED PAPERS AND PRESENTATIONS, THE RESEARCH WILL MAKE CONTRIBUTIONS TO BENEFIT-COST ANALYSES AND WILL  INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEXT-GENERATION INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT MODELS BY TESTING THE GENERALIZABILITY AND SCALABILITY OF NEW METHODS FOR VALUATION ACROSS SPATIAL AND DEMOGRAPHIC GRADIENTS. LAST, THE PROJECT WILL DELIVER BENEFICIAL OUTCOMES TO PARTNER COMMUNITIES ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE PUBLIC, STATE AND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCIES, REGULATORS, AND PARTNER COMMUNITIES ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT WILL STRATEGICALLY COMBINE APPLIED RESEARCH, DECISION-SUPPORT INNOVATIONS, AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT TO LOWER BARRIERS TO WIDESPREAD ADOPTION OF ENHANCED AQUIFER RECHARGE (EAR) AND UNLOCK ITS POTENTIAL TO PROVIDE MULTIPLE WATER SECURITY BENEFITS.  
ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A LIFE-CYCLE VIEW OF EAR TO ENCOMPASS THREE PILLARS OF DECISION MAKING: GEOCHEMICAL AND PHYSICAL CONSIDERATIONS; LEGAL AND INSTITUTIONAL CONSIDERATIONS; AND COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS AND LIFE-CYCLE ASSESSMENT. THE PROJECT WILL A) GENERALIZE AND CONTEXTUALIZE CUTTING EDGE RESEARCH CONTRIBUTIONS, B) PRODUCE A COMPREHENSIVE PICTURE OF THE LIFE CYCLE OF EAR IMPLEMENTATION, AND C) CREATE ACTIONABLE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PRACTITIONERS AND DEVELOP AND FORMALIZE BEST PRACTICES FOR EAR.SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO UC DAVIS ($82,259) IS FOR RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIS ON GEOPHYSICAL ELEMENTS AND TECHNICAL METHODS FOR EAR. THE SUBAWARD TO UC SANTA CRUZ ($254,912) IS FOR RESEARCH AND SYNTHESIS ON GEOPHYSICAL ELEMENTS AND TECHNICAL METHODS FOR EAR, AS WELL AS WORK ON METHODS AND CONSIDERATIONS FOR MANAGING WATER QUALITY. THE SUBAWARD TO UC HASTINGS ($59,994) SUPPORTS RESEARCH ON LEGAL, POLICY AND INSTITUTIONAL TOPICS.OUTCOMES:THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS AN EAR LIFECYCLE MAP THAT CAN BE USED AS A TOOL FOR STATE AND LOCAL DECISION-MAKERS CONTEMPLATING EAR PROJECTS AND AS A REPOSITORY FROM WHICH KEY RESOURCES AND TOOLS CAN BE FOUND AND EVALUATED. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE WATER QUALITY MANAGERS, STATE AND LOCAL DECISION MAKERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, ESPECIALLY IN AREAS SUSCEPTIBLE TO DROUGHT.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE HOW REAL-LIFE EXPOSURE TO MULTIPLE CHEMICALS IS CONSIDERED IN TOXICITY ASSESSMENTS OF CHEMICAL MIXTURES.ACTIVITIES:RESEARCHERS WILL IDENTIFY REAL-LIFE CHEMICAL MIXTURES FROM BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES TAKEN DURING A LARGE EPIDEMIOLOGIC BIRTH COHORT STUDY. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL THEN PRIORITIZE EXPOSURE MIXTURES USING EPIDEMIOLOGIC ANALYSIS TO IDENTIFY MIXTURES MOST STRONGLY ASSOCIATED WITH CHILD HEALTH. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO DEVELOP MIXTURE TOXICITY ASSESSMENTS FOR PRIORITIZED EXPOSURES. SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD TO CLEMSON UNIVERSITY WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR AIM 3, WHICH INVOLVES TESTING THE TOXICITY OF THE CHEMICAL MIXTURES USING CELL LINES. THE GOALS ARE TO FIRST SCREEN INDIVIDUAL CHEMICALS TO ASSESS WHETHER THEY CAN CAUSE OR INHIBIT ADIPOGENSIS. THEN, RESEARCHERS WILL DEVELOP A SET OF TRANSFECTED MESENCHYMAL STEM CELLS THAT HAS FIVE DIFFERENT RECEPTORS OF INTEREST TO TEST WHETHER THE SELECTED CHEMICALS BIND TO THEM, AND DETERMINE THE POTENCY OR STRENGTH OF THE BINDING. FINALLY, THE CLEMSON LAB WILL USE THE PRIORITIZED CHEMICALS AND MIXTURES FROM AIMS 1 AND 2 TO EXAMINE ALTERED ADIPOCYTE FORMATION AND TRIGLYCERIDE DEPOSITION, WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY EXAMINING MECHANISTIC EFFECTS IN THE TRANSFECTED CELLS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS AN INNOVATIVE FRAMEWORK FOR TOXICOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT OF REAL-WORLD EXPOSURE MIXTURES ACROSS A BROAD RANGE OF BIOLOGICAL ENDPOINTS. THE RESULTING TOOLS MAY PROVIDE A VALUABLE RESOURCE TO RISK ASSESSORS AND THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY INTERESTED IN RISK ASSESSMENT OF CHEMICAL MIXTURES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE CHILDREN'S HEALTH, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXAMINE CHEMICAL MIXTURES OF INCREASING COMPLEXITY FOR THEIR DEVIATIONS FROM EXPECTED ADIPOGENIC EFFECTS USING CONCENTRATION ADDITION AND INDEPENDENT ACTION MODELS.
ACTIVITIES:THE RECIPIENT WILL INTERROGATE THE COMPARABILITY OF JOINT TOXICITY AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF METHODS FOCUSED VARIOUS LEVELS OF BIOLOGICAL ORGANIZATION. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) EVALUATE MIXTURES OF INCREASING COMPLEXITY FOR ABILITY TO PROMOTE ADIPOGENESIS; (2) ASSESS AVAILABLE MIXTURE MODELS THROUGH CONTROLLED ASSESSMENTS OF CONTAMINANTS ACTING THROUGH SHARED, DISTINCT, AND MIXED MECHANISMS; AND (3) PROMOTE A GREATER FUNCTIONAL UNDERSTANDING OF COMPLEX MIXTURE EFFECTS THAT CAN BE UTILIZED TO BOLSTER RISK ASSESSMENTS OF DIVERSE CONTAMINANT EXPOSURES. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS A NEW METHOD OF MIXTURE RISK ASSESSMENTS THROUGH USING COMPONENT MECHANISTIC EFFECT LEVELS TO DETERMINE COOPERATIVE EFFECTS ON COMPLEX HEALTH ENDPOINTS AND/OR OUTCOMES. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL UTILIZE ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES (HOUSEHOLD DUST) TO DEVELOP A RECEPTOR BIOACTIVITY COMPONENT MODEL TO PREDICT ADIPOGENIC HEALTH OUTCOMES. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT MAY PROMOTE A GREATER FUNCTIONAL UNDERSTANDING OF COMPLEX MIXTURE EFFECTS THAT CAN BE UTILIZED TO BOLSTER RISK ASSESSMENTS OF DIVERSE CONTAMINANT EXPOSURES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PEOPLE AT RISK OF METABOLIC HEALTH CONDITIONS, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW INDIVIDUAL CHEMICALS IN WILDLIFE SMOKE INDUCE IN VITRO RESPONSES THAT GROUP ACCORDING TO BIOLOGICAL PATHWAYS AND INFORM MIXTURES-BASED JOINT TOXICITIES THAT OVERLAP WITH IN VIVO PULMONARY RESPONSES AND DISEASE OUTCOMES.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO (1) ESTABLISH QUALITATIVE MEMBERSHIP OF WILDFIRE MIXTURE COMPONENTS INTO PATHWAY GROUPINGS THROUGH IN VITRO TRANSCRIPTOMIC SCREENING; (2) QUANTIFY JOINT TOXICITIES ACROSS PATHWAY GROUPINGS AND COMPARE TO WHOLE BIOMASS SMOKE MIXTURE EFFECTS THROUGH IN SILICO MODELING; AND (3) RELATE IN VITRO WILDFIRE CHEMICAL-INDUCED SIGNATURES TO SIMILARLY EXPOSED MICE AND HUMAN PULMONARY DISEASE TISSUES TO EVALUATE EVENTS ALONG ADVERSE OUTCOME PATHWAYS (AOPS). RESEARCHERS WILL LEVERAGE EXISTING CHEMICAL CHARACTERIZATION RESULTS FROM VARIABLE BIOMASS BURN SCENARIOS, REPRESENTING WILDFIRE EVENTS, TO PRIORITIZE CHEMICALS THAT CO-OCCUR IN WILDFIRE SMOKE TO TEST FOR CHEMICAL GROUPINGS AND JOINT TOXICITIES. LUNG CELLS FROM HUMAN DONORS WILL BE EXPOSED TO INDIVIDUAL CHEMICALS, AND TRANSCRIPTOMIC SIGNATURES FROM EXPOSED CELLS WILL BE USED TO GROUP CHEMICALS. THESE CHEMICAL GROUPS WILL THEN BE TESTED USING THE SAME IN VITRO MODEL, ALONGSIDE THE FULL CHEMICAL MIXTURE AND WHOLE BIOMASS SMOKE MIXTURES TO COMPARE INDIVIDUAL CHEMICALS, CHEMICAL GROUPS, AND WHOLE MIXTURE EFFECTS ON PATHWAY-LEVEL RESPONSES. SUBRECIPIENT:A SUBAWARD TO NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY ($45,000) WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS OVERALL DATA PROCESSING AND STATISTICAL EVALUATION INCORPORATING BAYESIAN BASED METHODOLOGIES AND ADVANCED MIXTURES MODELING.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS AN IMPROVED MECHANISTIC UNDERSTANDING AND HEALTH RISK QUANTIFICATION OF WILDFIRE SMOKE. RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY MAY HELP IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS AND VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AT INCREASED RISK OF MOST HARMFUL EXPOSURE CONDITIONS, BASED ON BIOMASS COMPOSITION/BURN SCENARIOS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS AND VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AT INCREASED RISK OF WILDFIRES, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE THIS STUDY IS TO DESIGN AND ENGINEER AN IN VITRO 3D CELL CULTURE INTEGRATED INTO A FLOW-CELL BIOREACTOR TO CONDUCT THE TOXICOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBON (PAH) MIXTURES THAT CAN BE FOUND IN FOOD. ACTIVITIES:THE RECIPIENT WILL USE HUMAN, MICE, AND PIG INTESTINAL CELLS TO ANALYZE TOXICOLOGICAL MARKERS AND PATHWAYS OF PAH MIXTURES. THIS WILL ALLOW RESEARCHERS TO EVALUATE THE ABILITY OF THE GUT MICROBIOME TO BIODEGRADE PAHS AND WHETHER THE BIODEGRADATION BY-PRODUCTS CAN CAUSE TOXIC EFFECTS TO THE INTESTINAL TRACT. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS A NOVEL, VALIDATED 3D CELL CULTURE THAT CAN BE INTEGRATED WITH IN VITRO AND IN VIVO RESULTS TO IDENTIFY TOXICOLOGICAL MARKERS AND PATHWAYS OF POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBON (PAH) MIXTURES IN HUMANS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PEOPLE WHO ARE EXPOSED TO PAHS VIA FOOD; HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE A COMBINATION OF IN SILICO, IN VITRO, AND IN VIVO TOOLS TO TEST THE OVERARCHING HYPOTHESIS THAT BINDING OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) TO HEMOGLOBIN IS A PHYSIOLOGICAL SIGNAL FOR PREDICTING THE TOXICITY OF PFAS MIXTURES.ACTIVITIES:USING PFAS CONCENTRATIONS AND RATIOS OF MIXTURES FOUND IN SURFACE AND DRINKING WATER ACROSS THE COUNTRY, RESEARCHERS WILL QUANTIFY THE BINDING OF SINGLE PFAS AND THEIR MIXTURES TO HEMOGLOBIN. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) DEVELOP MECHANISTIC MODELS TO DETERMINE WHETHER THE TOXICITY OF PFAS MIXTURES DEVIATES FROM ADDITIVITY, (2) INFORM AND VALIDATE IN SILICO MODELS USING PFAS AND HEMOGLOBIN BINDING AFFINITY DATA, AND (3) INFORM AND VALIDATE IN SILICO MODELS USING IN VIVO TOXICITY TESTS. THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PRODUCE MECHANISTIC TOXICITY DATA FOR PFAS MIXTURES TO SUPPORT HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH RISK ASSESSMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:A SUBAWARD TO JACKSON STATE UNIVERSITY FOR $166,223 TO CONDUCT COMPUTATIONAL PROTEIN DOCKING AND QSAR MODELING OF PFAS AND THEIR MIXTURES.
A SUBAWARD TO HENDRIX UNIVERSITY FOR $36,964 TO RUN EQUILIBRIUM DIALYSES; GENERAL TOXICITY TESTING WITH MIDGES AND HEMOGLOBIN CONTENT.
OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS AND  THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NOVEL, SIMPLE, COST-EFFECTIVE AND ECOLOGICALLY RELEVANT APPROACH FOR TESTING THE TOXICITY OF PFAS MIXTURES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE U.S. EXPOSED TO PFAS MIXTURES, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A NOVEL, EFFECTS-BASED APPROACH FOR SCREENING CONTAMINANT MIXTURES FOR DEVELOPMENTAL IMPAIRMENTS.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO (1) DEVELOP AND VALIDATE A NOVEL WHOLE ANIMAL NEW APPROACH METHODOLOGY (NAM) IN CRUSTACEAN EMBRYOS THAT TARGETS DISRUPTIONS IN CONSERVED DEVELOPMENTAL PATHWAYS THROUGH GENE  AND BEHAVIORAL ASSAYS FOR USE IN HUMAN HEALTH RISK ASSESSMENTS; (2) EVALUATE THE ABILITY OF FISH AND CRUSTACEAN EMBRYO TESTS TO DETECT DEVELOPMENTAL TOXICITY TO SINGLE COMPOUNDS AND SIMULATED MIXTURES OF AIR POLLUTANTS AND COMPARE WITH PREDICTED VALUES FROM TOXICOLOGICAL DATABASES ASSUMING ADDITIVE TOXICITY; AND (3) VALIDATE THE APPLICABILITY OF THE ASSAYS USING AIR SAMPLES COLLECTED FOLLOWING OPEN DETONATIONS OF UNEXPLODED ORDNANCE IN VIEQUES, PUERTO RICO. THE PROPOSED ASSAYS CAN BE SCALED TO PROVIDE HIGH-THROUGHPUT SCREENING OF CHEMICAL MIXTURES FROM BOTH MANUFACTURED CHEMICAL FORMULATIONS AND ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES, SPECIFICALLY RELEVANT TO HUMAN HEALTH.SUBRECIPIENT:THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS ($314,995) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING FISH EMBRYO TESTS, RT-QPCR, AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY NON-TARGET ANALYSIS ON AIR SAMPLING FILTERS.
THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO - RIO PIEDRAS ($128,851) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR AIR SAMPLING IN VIEQUES, PR AND FOR OVERSEEING PROJECT ACTIVITIES BY A PH.D. STUDENT FROM THE UPR CHEMISTRY DEPARTMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS A ROBUST FRAMEWORK FOR IDENTIFYING HIDDEN STRESSORS IN AIR POLLUTION MIXTURES. THE APPROACH PROVIDES NOVEL TOOLS WHICH MAY IMPROVE THE RISK ASSESSMENT OF COMPLEX AIR POLLUTION MIXTURES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE THE COMMUNITY OF VIEQUES, PUERTO RICO AND OTHER COMMUNITIES WITH ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE CONCERNS IN THE U.S., HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH A PLATFORM TO QUANTIFY INTRAUTERINE EXPOSURE TO METAL MIXTURES AND DETERMINE THEIR EFFECT ON EPIGENETIC LOCI CHANGES IN NEWBORNS.ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) DEVELOP A STANDARDIZED METHODOLOGY FOR ASSESSING INTRAUTERINE EXPOSURE USING MECONIUM AS A BIOMARKER AND QUANTIFY METAL MIXTURES AMONG AN
URBAN POPULATION, AND (2) EXPLORE AND QUANTIFY THE EFFECT OF METAL MIXTURE EXPOSURE ON METHYLATED GENES FOR THREE ADVERSE BIRTH OUTCOMES: SMALL FOR GESTATIONAL AGE, INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY, AND AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS. RESEARCHERS WILL DEVELOP A STANDARDIZED METHOD TO QUANTIFY METALS IN MECONIUM AND IMPLEMENT THIS APPROACH TO MEASURE METAL CONCENTRATIONS FROM NEWBORNS DELIVERED IN NEW YORK CITY. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL ALSO COLLECT BUCCAL CELLS FROM MOTHERS AND INFANTS AND IDENTIFY METHYLATED GENES FOR THE ADVERSE BIRTH OUTCOMES. RESEARCHERS WILL THEN INVESTIGATE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE METAL MIXTURES AND DNA METHYLATION.SUBRECIPIENT:A SUBAWARD TO UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA ($97,947) WILL DEVELOP A COMPLEX BAYESIAN MIXTURE MODEL TO EVALUATE THE ASSOCIATION BETWEEN METAL MIXTURES AND ADVERSE BIRTH OUTCOMES AND ANALYZE THE DNA METHYLATION IN THE PROPOSED STUDY.

A SUBAWARD TO MEDGER EVERS COLLEGE ($42,395) WILL DEVELOP A STANDARDIZED METHOD FOR ASSESSING METAL CONCENTRATIONS IN MECONIUM AS WELL AS SAMPLE DIGESTION AND PROCESSING FOR ANALYSIS.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS THE IDENTIFICATION OF GENE LOCI WHERE METAL MIXTURE EFFECTS RESULT IN CHANGES IN METHYLATION, WHICH COULD ENHANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE PATHWAYS THAT RESULT IN HUMAN HARM. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT MAY LEAD TO STATE AND LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS TO IDENTIFY AT-RISK INFANTS AND DEVELOP REMEDIATION STRATEGIES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE MOTHERS AND INFANTS IN NEW YORK CITY, INFANTS AT RISK OF HEAVY METALS EXPOSURE, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A QUANTITATIVE ADVERSE OUTCOME PATHWAY (QAOP) NETWORK WITH ADVANCED MIXTURES RISK ASSESSMENT FOR ASSESSING DEVELOPMENTAL NEUROTOXICITY (DNT) OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCE (PFAS) MIXTURES AT MULTIPLE LEVELS OF BIOLOGICAL ORGANIZATION. INVESTIGATORS WILL USE THE NEMATODE C. ELEGANS AS AN INVERTEBRATE IN VIVO MODEL, WHICH CAN BE INTEGRATED IN A MANNER USEFUL TO HAZARD AND/OR RISK ASSESSMENT.ACTIVITIES:THE RECIPIENT WILL IMPROVE THE FUNDAMENTAL KNOWLEDGE ON DEVELOPMENTAL NEUROTOXICITY (DNT) TESTING THAT HAS NOT YET BEEN CONDUCTED IN-DEPTH FOR PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS). THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) CONSTRUCT AN ENVIRONMENTALLY RELEVANT AND REPRESENTATIVE PFAS REFERENCE MIXTURE; 2) CONDUCT SYSTEMATIC EXPERIMENTS TO EVALUATE DEVELOPMENTAL NEUROTOXICITY (DNT) OF INDIVIDUAL PFAS AND REFERENCE MIXTURE IN C. ELEGANS TO DEVELOP A QUANTITATIVE ADVERSE OUTCOME PATHWAY (QAOP) NETWORK; 3) PERFORM A WHOLE MIXTURE ASSESSMENT IN WATER SAMPLES BY EVALUATING SUFFICIENT SIMILARITY TO THE REFERENCE MIXTURE. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS A NEWLY DEVELOPED QUANTITATIVE ADVERSE OUTCOME PATHWAY (QAOP) NETWORK, INTEGRATED WITH NON-MAMMALIAN C. ELEGANS WITH SUPPORT OF STATISTICAL MODELS, WHICH MAY CONTRIBUTE DATA USEFUL FOR MIXTURE-BASED HAZARD AND DOSE-RESPONSE ASSESSMENTS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PEOPLE THAT ARE SIMULTANEOUSLY AND/OR SEQUENTIALLY EXPOSED TO MULTIPLE PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCE (PFAS) FROM VARIOUS SOURCES; CHILDREN WITH DEVELOPING BRAINS THAT ARE ESPECIALLY SENSITIVE TO TOXIC CHEMICALS; HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A NEW APPROACH METHODOLOGY (NAM) BASED ON HIGH-THROUGHPUT IN VITRO AIR-BLOOD BARRIER ARRAYS (ABBA) TO PREDICT RESPIRATORY TRACT INFLAMMATION RISK. ACTIVITIES:THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) PRODUCE DEFINED PAH COMPONENT AND MIXTURE SOLUTIONS INCLUDING SECONDARY ORGANIC AEROSOLS (SOA), (2) DEVELOP AN AIR-BLOOD BARRIER ARRAYS (ABBA)-BASED NEW APPROACH METHODOLOGY (NAM) AND DETERMINE FULL DOSE-RESPONSE CURVES FOR POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBON (PAH)/SECONDARY ORGANIC AEROSOL (SOA) COMPONENTS TO DERIVE  INFLAMMATORY TOXIC EQUIVALENCY FACTOR (ITEF), AND (3) ANALYZE PAH/SOA MIXTURES FOR JOINT TOXICITIES. RESEARCHERS WILL OBTAIN FULL DOSE-RESPONSE CURVES FOR AIR-BLOOD BARRIER PROPERTY DEGRADATION AND WILL USE NEUTROPHIL CELL INFILTRATION TO TEST THE ABILITY TO GROUP PAHS ACCORDING TO A NEWLY PROPOSED ITEF. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL ALSO ANALYZE THE JOINT TOXICITIES OF MIXTURES AND THE UTILITY OF ITEFS TO PREDICT MIXTURES TOXICITY. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS AS WELL AS A BROADLY USEFUL NEW APPROACH METHODOLOGY (NAM) THAT IS A PRACTICAL, HUMAN CELL-BASED ALTERNATIVE TO THE CURRENT RODENT-BASED BRONCHOALVEOLAR LAVAGE-BASED RESPIRATORY TRACT INHALATION TOXICITY ASSESSMENTS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PEOPLE EXPOSED TO AIR POLLUTANTS FROM AMBIENT AND OCCUPATIONAL SOURCES, CHILDREN AND OLDER ADULTS WITH ASTHMA, CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD), HEART DISEASE, OR DIABETES; HOUSEHOLDS IN THE WILDLAND-URBAN INTERFACE THAT ARE AT RISK FOR FOREST FIRES; HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INTEGRATE IN VITRO AND IN SILICO HIGH THROUGHPUT TESTING WITH IN VIVO TESTS USING A ZEBRAFISH MODEL IN ORDER TO EVALUATE THE NEUROTOXICITY OF MIXTURES OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS), AND THEIR MIXTURES WITH OTHER ORGANIC CONTAMINANTS. ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THE RESEARCH ARE TO (1) DERIVE INFORMATION ON THE EFFECTS OF PFAS MIXTURES ON CELLULAR KEY EVENTS LEADING TO NEUROTOXICITY, (2) DEVELOP MACHINE LEARNING TOXICITY PREDICTION TOOLS TO MAP THE MULTIVARIATE DATA ON THE STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONALITY OF PFAS MIXTURES, (3) INVESTIGATE THE ROLE OF CELLULAR TRANSPORTERS IN PFAS UPTAKE AND LOCALIZATION, AND (4) VALIDATE THE RESULTS FROM IN VITRO AND IN SILICA APPROACHES USING A ZEBRAFISH IN VIVO MODEL TO ASSESS IMPACTS OF PFAS ON NEURODEVELOPMENT. SUBRECIPIENT:THE HELMHOLTZ CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH ($150,009) WILL HOST A STUDENT FROM UB TO INVESTIGATE MIXTURE EFFECTS USING NEURONAL CELL LINES TO BE PERFORMED IN THE HIGH-THROUGHPUT TESTING FACILITY CITEPRO. THE INSTRUMENTS AT HELMHOLTZ HAVE SPECIFIC DISPENSER TO PREPARE COMPLEX MIXTURES OF DEFINED COMPOSITIONS, CUSTOM-BUILT ROBOTIC DEVICES FOR PIPETTING ALL STEPS OF CELL-BASED BIOASSAY AND AN IMAGE EXPRESS HIGH CONTENT MICROSCOPE FOR ENDPOINT DETECTION.

SUNY STONY BROOK UNIVERSITY ($205,797) WILL CONDUCT IN VIVO STUDIES USING ZEBRAFISH TO ASSESS NEURODEVELOPMENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL IMPACTS OF SELECTED PFAS, INDIVIDUALLY AND AS MIXTURES, AND PFAS MIXTURES WITH OTHER ORGANIC CONTAMINANTS. BIOACCUMULATION AND BIOTRANSFORMATION OF TREATMENT CHEMICALS IN ZEBRAFISH WILL BE EVALUATED TO CORRELATE INTERNAL CONCENTRATIONS OF PFAS WITH NEUROTOXICITY AND EXPLOIT DISTINCT EXPERIMENTAL ADVANTAGES OF ZEBRAFISH MODELS IN MULTI-WELL DISHES.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS MODELS TO PREDICT NEUROTOXICITY OF PFAS MIXTURES. THE DATA GENERATED MAY ENABLE THE APPLICATION OF ADVERSE OUTCOME PATHWAY  FRAMEWORKS FOR PFAS NEUROLOGICAL OUTCOMES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE TIMELY RISK-BASED ASSESSMENT OF MIXTURES AND UNKNOWN VARIABLE COMPOSITION OR BIOLOGICAL SUBSTANCES (UVCBS) THAT ENSURES HUMAN HEALTH PROTECTION FROM THE TOXICITY OF KNOWN AND UNKNOWN COMPONENTS. ACTIVITIES:THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL EVALUATE THE COMPOSITION AND HAZARDS OF CHEMICAL MIXTURES AND UNKNOWN VARIABLE COMPOSITION OR BIOLOGICAL SUBSTANCES (UVCBS) THROUGH INTEGRATION OF NOVEL TOXICOLOGICAL, ANALYTICAL, AND MODELING METHODS. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) GROUP CHEMICAL MIXTURE COMPONENTS FOR HAZARD ASSESSMENT BY INTEGRATING MULTI-PHENOTYPE AND MULTI-TISSUE BIOACTIVITY DATA FROM A COLLECTION OF HUMAN INDUCED PLURIPOTENT STEM CELL-DERIVED CELLS, (2) PRIORITIZE COMPONENTS IN WHOLE MIXTURES OR UVCBS MOST LIKELY TO CONTRIBUTE TO JOINT TOXICITY THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF MEDIATION AND INTERACTION METHODS INTEGRATING NOVEL ANALYTICAL AND IN VITRO BIOACTIVITY DATA, (3) PREDICT JOINT TOXICITY OF WHOLE OR DEFINED MIXTURES AND UVCBS THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF PROBABILISTIC ADDITIVITY MODELS OF GROUPED AND PRIORITIZED COMPONENTS, AND (4) DEMONSTRATE THE INTEGRATION OF THE PROPOSED EXPOSURE, TOXICOLOGICAL AND MODELING METHODS INTO A TIERED HYBRID EXPERIMENTAL-COMPUTATIONAL STRATEGY FOR RAPID RISK ASSESSMENT OF COMPLEX ENVIRONMENTAL MIXTURES OR UVCBS. SUBRECIPIENT:PERSONNEL AT NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE STATISTICAL MODELING AND THE ANALYSIS OF DATA FROM THIS GRANT. SPECIFIC TASKS WILL INCLUDE: MAINTENANCE OF DATA FOR NC STATE INVESTIGATORS, INCLUDING PHENOTYPES, COVARIATES, DOSE RESPONSE PROFILES AND THE IMS-MS DATA; DEVELOPMENT OF NOVEL STATISTICAL MODELING TO MEASURE THE
INTERACTION OF THE COMPONENTS IN WHOLE MIXTURES; PERFORMING THE MEDIATION ANALYSIS AND PREDICTING JOINT TOXICITY OF WHOLE OR DEFINED MIXTURES; PROVIDING INTERMEDIATE ANALYZED DATASETS
FOR PUBLIC REPOSITORIES, AND TO PROVIDE TO COLLABORATORS FOR FURTHER DOWNSTREAM ANALYSES.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS, AS WELL AS A SUITE OF ANALYTICAL, IN VITRO, AND COMPUTATIONAL METHODS AND TOOLS THAT CAN BE APPLIED IN A TIERED STRATEGY FOR RAPID QUANTITATIVE CHARACTERIZATION OF THE COMPOSITION AND HAZARDS OF COMPLEX ENVIRONMENTAL MIXTURES AND UVCBS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY CHEMICAL RE-DISTRIBUTION FOLLOWING NATURAL DISASTERS, HUMAN HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

DESCRIPTION:
THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO COMBINE STATE-OF-THE-ART ONLINE HIGH-RESOLUTION CHEMICAL IONIZATION MASS SPECTROMETERS (HR-TOF-CIMS) TOGETHER WITH NOVEL AIR- AND PARTICLE-PHASE SAMPLING TECHNIQUES TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF FUGITIVE EMISSIONS OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFASS) FROM STATIONARY POINT SOURCES. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT WILL: 1) DETERMINE HR-TOF-CIMS CALIBRATION CURVES AND DETECTION LIMITS FOR ATMOSPHERICALLY-RELEVANT PFASS; 2) OXIDIZE PFAS STANDARDS WITH HYDROXYL RADICALS (OH) AND OZONE UNDER CONTROLLED LABORATORY SETTINGS TO GENERATE COMMERCIALLY-UNAVAILABLE PFASS THAT ARE ALSO KEY TO UNDERSTANDING PFASS' ATMOSPHERIC TRANSFORMATIONS AND FATES; AND 3) DEPLOY A MOBILE LABORATORY WITH THESE NEWLY DEVELOPED AND LABORATORY-VALIDATED CIMS METHODS AT A STATIONARY POINT SOURCE TO STUDY FUGITIVE PFAS EMISSIONS AND PFAS NEAR-SOURCE DOWNWIND CHEMISTRY.
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE ADVANCEMENTS IN MEASUREMENT TECHNIQUES TO MEASURE AMBIENT LEVELS OF GAS- AND PARTICLE-PHASE PFASS AND ADVANCEMENTS IN NEAR-SOURCE MEASUREMENT METHODS FOR ESTIMATING EMISSIONS OF PFASS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY PFAS EXPOSURES.
SUBRECIPIENT:
SUBAWARDEE TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY WILL CONDUCT AND LEAD THE LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS USING THE HIGH RESOLUTION CHEMICAL IONIZATION MASS SPECTROMETERS TO DETERMINE CALIBRATION FACTORS AND DETECTION LIMITS AND TO DETERMINE WHETHER LEGACY OR EMERGING PFASS CAN BE OXIDIZED BY ATMOSPHERIC HYDROXYL RADICALS. IN ADDITION, THEY WILL DEPLOY A MOBILE LABORATORY TO COLLECT AMBIENT DATA FOR THE FIELD STUDY NEAR THE CHEMOURS FACILITY.

DESCRIPTION:
THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND VALIDATE A MOBILE PLATFORM FOR QUANTIFICATION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF EMISSIONS OF SUB-10 NM PARTICLES. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT WILL: 1) DESIGN AND BUILD A PLATFORM TO MEASURE THE SIZE, MORPHOLOGY, AND ELEMENTAL COMPOSITION OF SUB-10 NM PARTICLES EMITTED TO AMBIENT AIR; AND 2) DEMONSTRATE THAT THE PLATFORM CAN BE USED FOR SOURCE IDENTIFICATION, SOURCE APPORTIONMENT STUDIES, AND CREATION OF DETAILED MAPS WITH EMISSION INVENTORIES FOR SUB-10 NM PARTICLES IN URBAN ENVIRONMENTS. 
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. PROJECT OUTPUTS INCLUDE (1) A MOBILE SAMPLING SYSTEM WITH REAL-TIME MAPPING, (2) CITY-SCALE SUB- 10 NM CONCENTRATION MAPS FOR TWO URBAN CENTERS IN THE SOUTH EASTERN U.S., (3) A SOURCE INVENTORY DESCRIBING EMISSIONS FROM SELECTED SOURCES, AND (4) A TARGET INVENTORY THAT WILL HIGHLIGHT GEOGRAPHICAL AREAS WITH LIKELY HIGH-TOXICITY SOURCES, EXCEPTIONALLY STRONG SOURCES EVIDENCED BY LARGE EMISSION RATES OR HIGH NUMBER CONCENTRATIONS, AND PLUMES AFFECTING RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOODS, SCHOOLS, HOSPITALS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY LOCALES WITH POTENTIAL FOR HIGH IMPACTS ON HUMAN HEALTH OR COMMUNITY WELL-BEING. THE MAIN EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THE PROPOSED WORK IS A NEW VALIDATED TECHNIQUE USING A MOBILE NEAR-SOURCE MEASUREMENT SYSTEM THAT CAN QUANTIFY THE EMISSION RATES OF FUGITIVE SUB-10 NM PARTICLE EMISSIONS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY AMBIENT EXPOSURES TO ULTRAFINE PARTICLES.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DESCRIPTION:
THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP AN OPEN-SOURCE REFERENCE INSTRUMENT AND METHODOLOGY FOR OPERATION, VALIDATION, AND QA/QC OF OPEN-PATH OPTICAL REMOTE SENSING (OP-ORS) MONITORING OF VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS AND OTHER AIR TOXICS.
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL: 1) DESIGN AND BUILD A PORTABLE OPEN-PATH REFERENCE INSTRUMENT FOR ACCURATE DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION OF SEVERAL AIR TOXICS; 2) VALIDATE THE REFERENCE OP-ORS SYSTEM WITH OTHER ANALYTICAL METHODS; 3) DEPLOY THE REFERENCE SYSTEM IN PARALLEL WITH A CURRENT STATE-OF-THE-ART OP-ORS SYSTEM AT A LOCAL REFINERY IN THE LOS ANGELES AIR BASIN TO DEVELOP AND TEST VALIDATION PROTOCOLS; AND 4) DEVELOP GUIDANCE FOR BEST PRACTICES FOR OPERATION, QA/QC, AND FIELD VALIDATION FOR OP-ORS OBSERVATIONS.
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE DEMONSTRATION OF A PORTABLE OP-ORS SYSTEM FOR ACCURATE QUANTIFICATION OF SEVERAL AIR TOXICS, AND THE ESTABLISHMENT OF OP-ORS AS A RELIABLE AND TRUSTED TOOL TO MONITOR AIR TOXIC RELEASES FROM INDUSTRIAL FACILITIES AND FOR COMMUNITY AIR QUALITY MONITORING OF THESE COMPOUNDS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY AIR TOXIC POLLUTION.
SUBRECIPIENT:
SUBAWARDEE SOUTH COAST AIR QUALITY MANAGEMENT DISTRICT WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE RECIPIENT, UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA LOS ANGLES (UCLA), TO: 1) DEVELOP THE QUALITY ASSURANCE PROJECT PLAN FOR THE OPTICAL REMOTE SENSING (ORS) SYSTEM THAT WILL BE DESIGNED BY UCLA; 2) CONTRIBUTE TO THE EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND EXECUTION OF THE ORS SYSTEM CONTROLLED-RELEASE VALIDATION EXPERIMENT; 3) THE CO-LOCATION OF THE ORS SYSTEM AT A REFINERY IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA; AND 4) WRITE GUIDANCE DOCUMENTS FOR QUALITY ASSURANCE/QUALITY CONTROL (QA/QC) AND VALIDATION OF ORS SYSTEMS.

DESCRIPTION:
THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP, CHARACTERIZE, AND DEMONSTRATE A NOVEL TECHNIQUE FOR A LOW-COST WAY OF MEASURING ORGANIC HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (HAPS) WITH HIGH SENSITIVITY AND SELECTIVITY AND AT HIGH TIME RESOLUTION. 
ACTIVITIES:
ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) DEVELOPING A NEW MULTIDIMENSIONAL TECHNIQUE FOR IDENTIFYING AND QUANTIFYING HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (HAPS); 2) DEMONSTRATING THE USE OF A PROTOTYPE DEVICE IN BOTH THE LABORATORY AND THE FIELD; 3) OPTIMIZING DATA PROCESSING AND INTERPRETATION USING ADVANCED ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES; AND 4) DEVELOPING A MODULAR APPROACH FOR OPTIMIZING MEASUREMENT METHODS TO TARGET SPECIFIC HAPS.
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT AND DEMONSTRATION OF PROTOTYPE INSTRUMENTS THAT PROVIDE LOW-COST WAYS TO CONDUCT REAL-TIME MONITORING OF HAPS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY HAPS.
SUBRECIPIENT:
SUBAWARDEE MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY WILL LEAD THE DEVELOPMENT OF SENSOR ARRAY AND DATA APPROACHES TO INTERPRET THE RESULTS FOR THE PROTOTYPE DEVICE THAT WILL BE DEVELOPED. SUBAWARDEE SOUTH COAST AIR QUALITY MANAGEMENT DISTRICT WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE OVERALL DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LABORATORY TESTING PORTION OF THE PROJECT.

DESCRIPTION:
THIS GOAL OF THIS PROJECT TO DEVELOP AND IMPROVE A METHOD FOR ONLINE DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION OF SEVERAL UNDERSTUDIED TOXIC PLASTIC ADDITIVES OF EMERGING CONCERN IN ATMOSPHERIC PARTICULATE MATTER. 
ACTIVITIES:
ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CALIBRATING AN EXTRACTIVE ELECTROSPRAY HIGH-RESOLUTION TIME-OF-FLIGHT MASS SPECTROMETER (EESI-TOF) FOR SENSITIVE DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION OF TARGETED PLASTIC ADDITIVES; 2) EXPANDING ON A CURRENT METHODOLOGY FOR DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION OF TARGETED PLASTIC ADDITIVES IN BULK WATER SAMPLES AND EXTRACTS FROM HIGH-VOLUME AEROSOL FILTER SAMPLES; 3) QUANTIFYING TARGETED PLASTIC ADDITIVES IN THE PARTICULATE MATTER IN THE AMBIENT COASTAL MARINE ENVIRONMENT IN SAN DIEGO, CALIFORNIA IN SUMMER AND WINTER; AND 4) ANALYZING TARGETED PLASTIC ADDITIVES IN PARTICULATE MATTER SAMPLED IN THE FIELD AND HOW THEY EVOLVE DUE TO CHANGING PROPERTIES OF SEAWATER, WASTEWATER OUTFLOW RATES, AND VARYING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) DEMONSTRATION AND VALIDATION OF A NEW APPROACH FOR DETECTION AND QUANTIFICATION FOR PLASTIC ADDITIVES OF EMERGING CONCERN IN PARTICULATE MATTER; AND 2) NEW INSIGHTS AND KNOWLEDGE THAT WILL HELP TO INFORM ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT AND RISK ASSESSMENT ANALYSES OF PLASTIC ADDITIVES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO ARE AFFECTED BY EXPOSURE TO PLASTIC ADDITIVES IN PARTICULATE MATTER.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DESCRIPTION:
THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP AND VALIDATE NOVEL PASSIVE SAMPLING DESIGNS THAT CAN BE USED TO MEASURE A DIVERSE SUITE OF AIR TOXICS AND CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN (CEC) AT LOW DETECTION LIMITS. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT WILL: 1) REFINE AND VALIDATE THE USE OF POLYETHYLENE (PE) FILMS AS PASSIVE AIR SAMPLERS FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (HAPS) AND CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN (CECS); 2) DEVELOP A NOVEL PASSIVE SAMPLER TO MEASURE AIR TOXICS THAT PREFERENTIALLY ACCUMULATE IN WATER; AND 3) DEMONSTRATE THE CAPABILITY OF PASSIVE SAMPLERS TO LOCATE SOURCES OF EMISSIONS AND ASSESS CHRONIC EXPOSURES IN A LOCAL COMMUNITY. 
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS VALIDATION OF A LOW-COST METHOD THAT WILL ENABLE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND COMMUNITIES TO ASSESS CHRONIC EXPOSURES TO AIR TOXICS AND CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN (CECS) AT CONCENTRATIONS TYPICAL OF AMBIENT URBAN AIR. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COMMUNITIES THAT ARE EXPOSED TO AIR TOXICS AND/OR CECS.
SUBRECIPIENT:
ANALYSES OF FLUOROTELOMERS, ORGANOPHOSPHATE ESTERS, AND OTHER COMPOUNDS USING LIQUID CHROMATOGRAPHY AND QUADRUPOLE TIME- OF-FLIGHT MASS SPECTROMETRY WILL BY CONDUCTED BY SUBAWARDEE STONY BROOK UNIVERSITY.

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP A PORTABLE, SMALL, LIGHTWEIGHT, LOW-POWER INSTRUMENT FOR NEAR REAL-TIME SPECIATION AND QUANTIFICATION OF VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS), INCLUDING HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (HAPS), IN THE AMBIENT ATMOSPHERE AND INDOORS.
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL BUILD, TEST, AND FIELD DEPLOY A GAS CHROMATOGRAPHY CROSSFLOW ION MOBILITY SPECTROMETER (GC-CF-IMS) THAT IS MODERATE IN COST, CAN PROVIDE MEASUREMENTS AT GOOD TIME RESOLUTION, REQUIRES LOW POWER, IS COMPACT AND LIGHTWEIGHT, AND CAN IDENTIFY INDIVIDUAL COMPOUNDS THAT ARE HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (HAPS). AT LEAST TWO FIELD STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED WITH THE INSTRUMENT TO TEST ITS CAPABILITIES IN SITUATIONS RELEVANT TO COMMUNITIES FACING ENVIRONMENTAL INJUSTICES. A COMMUNITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE WILL BE FORMED TO ASSIST IN DEVELOPING A DEPLOYMENT STRATEGY FOR FIELD TESTING IN SUCH COMMUNITIES AND IN WORKING WITH THESE COMMUNITIES TO UNDERSTAND THE STUDY RESULTS AND TRANSLATE THEM INTO ACTIONS FOR REDUCING EXPOSURE TO HAPS.
OUTCOMES:
THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL PROGRESS AND FINAL REPORTS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A NEW INSTRUMENT SUITABLE FOR UNDER-RESOURCED COMMUNITIES TO USE TO DETECT HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (HAPS) IN THE AIR THEY BREATHE AND USE THIS INFORMATION TO MOTIVATE EMISSIONS CONTROLS LEADING TO CLEANER AIR AND CONSEQUENTLY IMPROVED HEALTH. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY AIR TOXIC POLLUTION.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DESCRIPTION:
THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO CREATE A COMMUNICATION INFRASTRUCTURE IN COLORADO FOR AIR QUALITY INFORMATION THAT (A) ENHANCES THE AVAILABLE INFORMATION ABOUT AIR QUALITY, (B) DEVELOPS TARGETED MESSAGING THAT REACHES INDIVIDUALS BASED ON THEIR LEVELS OF NEED AND VULNERABILITY, AND (C) UTILIZES TRUSTED SOURCES OF INFORMATION. 
ACTIVITIES:
THE PROJECT WILL 1) EXPAND LOW-COST MONITORING NETWORKS IN THE PROJECT'S PARTNER TEST-BED COMMUNITIES IN COLORADO; 2) DEVELOP REAL-TIME SUB-CITY-SCALE SMOKE MAPS TO SUPPORT ACCURATE AND ACTIONABLE COMMUNICATION ABOUT AIR QUALITY; 3) CONDUCT INTERVIEWS WITH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND MEMBERS TO DEVELOP MESSAGING THROUGH MULTIPLE COMMUNICATION CHANNELS IN ORDER TO ENHANCE THE CAPABILITY OF COMMUNITIES TO PROVIDE TIMELY, ACCURATE, AND ACTIONABLE INFORMATION ABOUT AIR QUALITY; AND 4) EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF COMMUNICATION CAMPAIGNS IN DEVELOPING INDIVIDUAL-LEVEL AWARENESS, COGNITIVE, AND BEHAVIORAL OUTCOMES.
OUTCOMES:
 THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE REAL-TIME, HIGH-RESOLUTION PARTICULATE MATTER AND OZONE CONCENTRATION MAPS COVERING THE REGIONS OF THE PROJECT'S PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS; DEVELOP BEST PRACTICES FOR COMMUNICATING AIR QUALITY INFORMATION; AND PROVIDE RESEARCH FINDINGS ON EFFECTIVENESS OF THE COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES DEVELOPED BY THE PROJECT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE EXPANDED LOW-COST MONITORING NETWORKS, ENHANCED COMMUNICATION INFRASTRUCTURE IN COLORADO FOR AIR QUALITY INFORMATION, AND IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW BEST TO COMMUNICATE HEALTH RISKS AND AIR QUALITY INFORMATION TO ENABLE PROTECTIVE ACTIONS TO REDUCE WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND COLORADO RESIDENTS WHO ARE AFFECTED BY WILDFIRE SMOKE. 
SUBRECIPIENT:

THE PURPOSE OF PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO IDENTIFY THE MOST EFFECTIVE DATA SOURCES AND DISSEMINATION STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNICATING WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE RISKS AND THE DRIVERS OF THE DISCONNECT THAT EXISTS BETWEEN SCIENTISTS AND COMMUNITIES ON EXPOSURE AND HEALTH RISK COMMUNICATION. THE PROJECT WILL 1) CONDUCT A MULTI-TIER ASSESSMENT OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF EXPOSURE RISK COMMUNICATION IN THE BAY AREA OF CALIFORNIA; AND 2) FORM AN INCLUSIVE COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD TO GATHER INSIGHT INTO COMMUNITY RESPONSES TO HEALTH RISK COMMUNICATION AND EXPOSURE INTERVENTIONS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PRODUCE A COMMUNITY-ALIGNED ACTION PLAN FOR WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE FOR THE RESIDENTS OF THE BAY AREA, CALIFORNIA. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF HOW BEST TO COMMUNICATE HEALTH RISKS TO ENABLE ACTIONS TO REDUCE WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND THE RESIDENTS OF THE BAY AREA OF CALIFORNIA WHO ARE AFFECTED BY WILDFIRE SMO

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH PROTECTION THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF QUANTITATIVE DATA ON THE REMOVAL OF HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES BY TREATMENT PROCESSES WHERE WASTEWATER IS THE SOURCE WATER. RESEARCHERS WILL QUANTIFY THE REMOVAL OF SELECTED HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES BY DIFFERENT TREATMENT TRAINS AND PROCESSES AT FIVE FULL-SCALE WATER REUSE FACILITIES ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE MONITORING FIVE FULL-SCALE TREATMENT FACILITIES FOR VIRUS AND SURROGATE REMOVAL AFTER VARIOUS TREATMENT PROCESSES, THEN VALIDATING THE USEFULNESS OF SURROGATES FOR ASSIGNING LOG REDUCTION VALUES FOR THE DIFFERENT TREATMENT PROCESSES. DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES FROM THIS STUDY INCLUDE A TOOLBOX WITH, AT A MINIMUM, STANDARDIZED PROTOCOLS FOR DETECTION OF PATHOGENIC VIRUSES, APPLICATION OF VIRUS LOG REDUCTION VALUES AND SURROGATES, AND EXAMPLES OF HOW THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT CAN BE USED IN PRACTICE TO PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH BY PROVIDING ROBUST VIRUS LOG REDUCTION VALUE CREDITS F

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO IDENTIFY DECENTRALIZED WASTEWATER TECHNOLOGIES AND MUNICIPAL TREATMENT UNIT PROCESSES CAPABLE OF REMOVING HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES TO ALLOW SAFE REUSE OF THE TREATED WASTEWATER AND TO EVALUATE THE USE OF FIVE SURROGATES AS POSSIBLE INDICATORS FOR PRESENCE OF HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES DURING TREATMENT PROCESSES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE USING TWO CULTURABLE AND THREE NON-CULTURABLE SURROGATE INDICATORS FOR HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES TO EVALUATE EACH TECHNOLOGY&RSQUOANDS PERFORMANCE AND TO CONCURRENTLY VALIDATE THE USE OF THESE SURROGATES BY PARALLEL MEASUREMENTS OF INDIGENOUS HUMAN ADENOVIRUSES AND HUMAN NOROVIRUSES USING STATE-OF-THE-ART ANALYTICAL METHODS. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A RATING OF EIGHT WASTEWATER TREATMENT PROCESSES WITH RESPECT TO REMOVALS/INACTIVATION OF HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES, AND DATA WITH THE OUTCOME OF ULTIMATELY INFORMING POLICIES AND GUIDELINES RELATIVE TO TESTING OF WASTEWATER TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES BEING CONSIDERED FOR REUSE OF TREATED WASTEWATER. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE WASTEWATER OPERATORS, STATE AND LOCAL REGULATORS, RESIDENTS OF BARNSTABLE COUNTY, MA, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE  PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND VIRUS ATTENUATION IN WASTEWATER AND WATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW QUANTITATIVE TOOLS WITH NOVEL SURROGATES TO IMPROVE SENSITIVITY, REDUCE ANALYSIS TURNAROUND TIME, AND REDUCE THE COST OF MEASURING VIRUSES IN WASTEWATER FOR VALIDATING TREATMENT PERFORMANCE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE A COMPREHENSIVE CHARACTERIZATION OF INDIGENOUS VIRUSES IN WASTEWATER USING METAGENOMICS TO IDENTIFY IMPROVED SURROGATES FOR ASSESSING TREATMENT PERFORMANCE; THE DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEW ANALYTICAL METHODS TO PROVIDE NOT ONLY RAPID AND PRECISE QUANTIFICATION OF VIRUSES IN WASTEWATER BUT ALSO THE ABILITY TO ASSESS VIABILITY; AND VALIDATION OF NEW QUANTITATIVE DETECTION ASSAYS FOR ESTIMATING REDUCTION OF VIRUSES USING BOTH FULL-SCALE ADVANCED WATER RECLAMATION TREATMENT FACILITIES AND BENCH-SCALE DISINFECTION EXPERIMENTS. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ADVANCED KNOWLEDGE ON THE ABUNDANCE, DIVERSITY, PERSISTENCE, AND FATE OF VIRUSES AND VIRAL VES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERNS ABOUT HUMAN VIRAL PATHOGENS IN TREATED WASTEWATER FOR NON-POTABLE REUSE ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE IDENTIFYING A SUITE OF VIRAL PATHOGENS AND SURROGATES AND DETECTION METHODS THAT MAY BEST SERVE AS AN INDICATION OF VIRAL RISK IN WATER REUSE. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A LIST OF BEST METHODS FOR IDENTIFYING THE VIRAL RISK FOR NON-POTABLE WATER REUSE AND STANDARD OPERATING PROTOCOLS (SOPS) FOR THESE METHODS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE WASTEWATER OPERATORS, STATE AND LOCAL REGULATORS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI WILL PARTICIPATE IN WASTEWATER SAMPLE AND WATER QUALITY DATA COLLECTION. TULANE UNIVERSITY, THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII, UC DAVIS AND THE UNIVERSITY OF UTAH WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE CROSS-LABORATORY STUDY TO COMPARE METHODS FOR DETECTION OF SELECTIVE VIRAL PATHOGENS AND SURROGATES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO EXPAND THE CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF VIRUS FATE DURING WASTEWATER TREATMENT AND DEVELOP SURROGATE-BASED CREDITING FRAMEWORKS FOR UNIT PROCESSES THAT HAVE LARGELY BEEN UNCREDITED OR UNDER-CREDITED IN NONPOTABLE AND POTABLE REUSE APPLICATIONS. DELIVERABLES WILL ELUCIDATE POTENTIAL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN CULTURE AND MOLECULAR DATA FOR HUMAN ENTERIC VIRUSES, SURROGATE BACTERIOPHAGES, AND FECAL INDICATOR VIRUSES. OUTCOMES OF THE RESEARCH INCLUDE SURROGATE-BASED PREDICTIVE MODELS AND REGULATORY CREDITING FRAMEWORKS THAT CAN BE READILY ADOPTED BY STATES AND THE WATER INDUSTRY. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE RESIDENTS OF COMMUNITIES IN NEVADA, VIRGINIA, AND FLORIDA SERVED BY CBAT FACILITIES COVERED BY THE STUDY, WASTEWATER OPERATORS, STATE AND LOCAL REGULATORS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. SUBAWARDEE SOUTHERN NEVADA WATER AUTHORITY WILL CONDUCT LABORATORY-SCALE SEQUENCING BATCH REACTORS AND ANALYZE THE CORRESPONDING SAMPLES FOR MICROBIOLOGICAL TARGETS AND GENERAL WATER QUALITY PARAMETERS. SUBAWARDEE DREXEL UNIVERSITY WILL WORK ON MATHEMATICAL MODEL DEVELOPMENT.

THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO 1) EVALUATE AN INTEGRATED STRATEGY CONTAINING BOTH INTERVENTIONS AND COMMUNICATIONS TO REDUCE WILDLAND FIRE POLLUTION EXPOSUREAND 2) ESTABLISH THAT TARGETED INTERVENTION CAN BE USED TO EFFECTIVELY REDUCE EXPOSURES OF SCHOOL COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO WILDLAND FIRE BURN EMISSIONSAND AND 3) INVESTIGATE HOW WILDLAND FIRE IMPACT FORECASTING CAN BE USED TO REDUCE EXPOSURES, BOTH BY ADJUSTING THE TIMING OF BURN ACTIVITIES AND PROVIDING GUIDANCE TO POTENTIALLY IMPACTED AREAS IN ADVANCE. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE AN ASSESSMENT OF APPROACHES TO REDUCE EXPOSURES TO AIR POLLUTION FROM WILDLAND FIRES, REDUCE EXPOSURES OF SCHOOLCHILDREN, AND ADVANCE AN OPERATION PRESCRIBED FIRE IMPACT FORECASTING SYSTEM.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO REDUCE WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURES AND HEALTH RISKS AMONG AGRICULTURAL WORKERS AND OTHER LOW-INCOME FAMILIES BY DESIGNING AND FIELD TESTING AN AFFORDABLE AND EFFECTIVE PARTICLE FILTRATION SYSTEM FOR ROOFTOP EVAPORATIVE COOLERS. PARTICIPANT ENGAGEMENT STRATEGY WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE THE SYSTEM AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL BARRIERS TO WIDESPREAD USE. THE PROJECT WILL (1) DESIGN A FILTER THAT IS EFFECTIVE, EASY TO INSTALL, AND AFFORDABLEAND (2) TEST THE FILTER IN THE HOMES OF AGRICULTURAL WORKERS IN THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY, WITH CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF INDOOR AND OUTDOOR PARTICULATE MATTER CONCENTRATIONS, AND MORE INTENSIVE TESTING IN A SUBSET OF HOMESAND (3) IMPLEMENT A PARTICIPANT ENGAGEMENT STRATEGY TO EVALUATE EVAPORATIVE COOLER FILTRATION SYSTEMS AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL BARRIERS TO WIDESPREAD USE. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF PROJECT IS TO PRODUCE AN AFFORDABLE AND EFFECTIVE FILTER DESIGN THAT COULD BE MASS-PRODUCED AFTER THE END OF THE GRANT FOR HOMES WITH EVAPORATIVE COOLERS IN THE WESTERN U.S., THEREBY PROTECTING PEOPLE FROM WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND LOW-INCOME PEOPLE AFFECTED BY WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE. CENTRAL CALIFORNIA ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE NETWORK WILL ENGAGE PARTICIPANTS AND DISTRIBUTE MONITORS AND FILTERS TO PARTICIPANTS. ILLINOIS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY WILL LEAD THE PILOTING, DESIGNING, TESTING AND DEPLOYMENT OF THE FILTRATION SYSTEMS. THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO BOULDER WILL FACILITATE THE DESIGN ADVISORY GROUP. THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SAN FRANCISCO WILL ADMINISTER HEALTH SURVEYS TO THE PARTICIPANTS.

THE GOAL OF THE RESEARCH IS TO DECREASE SMOKE EXPOSURES AND ASSOCIATED HEALTH IMPACTS FROM PRESCRIBED BURN EVENTS. MAIN OUTPUT OF THE RESEARCH IS A RISK COMMUNICATION TOOLKIT THAT CAN BE USED TO 1) FACILITATE COMMUNICATION TO REINFORCE THE SMOKE MANAGEMENT GOAL ASSOCIATED WITH THE CAREFUL PLANNING OF PRESCRIBED BURNSAND AND 2) EFFECTIVELY INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT INTERVENTIONS THAT CAN BE TAKEN TO REDUCE SMOKE EXPOSURE DURING PRESCRIBED BURNS.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO STUDY THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SEVERAL METHODS OF SMOKE EXPOSURE REDUCTION. THE RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT A TWO-YEAR LONGITUDINAL RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED TRIAL OF 265 SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA RESIDENTS FROM LOW-INCOME AND NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING COMMUNITIES IN SAN MATEO AND SANTA CLARA COUNTIES. THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO 1) EVALUATE IF AND HOW MUCH APP-DELIVERED NATIVE LANGUAGE MESSAGING, AIR SEALING, OR PORTABLE HIGH EFFICIENCY PARTICULATE AIR FILTERS CAN EFFECTIVELY REDUCE SMOKE EXPOSURE AND ASSOCIATED HEALTH RISKSAND 2) EVALUATE HOW THE EFFECTIVENESS IS MODERATED BY BEHAVIOR OVER TIMEAND AND 3) EVALUATE HOW AND WHY BEHAVIOR IS AFFECTED BY USE OF THE APP-DELIVERED NATIVE LANGUAGE MESSAGING. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL IDENTIFY AFFORDABLE AND ACTIONABLE INTERVENTION STEPS FOR INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES, AND INFORM POLICIES, PROGRAMS AND RISK COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES FOR COMMUNITY PARTNERS, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND LOCAL/STATE AGENCIES THAT ARE BEHAVIORALLY REALISTIC FOR THE HARD-TO-REACH COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE. METHODS, RESULTS, AND LESSONS LEARNED FROM THIS PROJECT CAN BE USED TO CONDUCT FUTURE EVALUATIONS OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF INTERVENTIONS FOR WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE IN OTHER SETTINGS (E.G., MULTI-FAMILY, WORK PLACES) AND AMONG OTHER HARD-TO-REACH POPULATIONS (E.G., RURAL COMMUNITIES, RESERVATIONS) IN CALIFORNIA AND BEYOND. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITYAND STATE AND LOCAL ENTITIES WORKING TO REDUCE WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURESAND AND COMMUNITIES AFFECTED BY WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURES. RTI INTERNATIONAL WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE FOR THE PERSONAL EXPOSURE AND AIR QUALITY ASSESSMENT BY DESIGNING THE EXPOSURE STUDY, TRAINING FIELD STAFF ON AIR SENSOR DEPLOYMENT AND DATA EXTRACTION, ASSESSING THE AIR QUALITY AND EXPOSURES FOR PARTICULATE MATTER, AND ASSESSING SLEEP QUALITY OF A SUB-POPULATION WHO HAS EXISTING HEALTH PROBLEMS.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO IDENTIFY AND REDUCE GAPS IN CURRENT KNOWLEDGE ON RISK COMMUNICATIONS FOR WILDFIRE SMOKE, WITH A FOCUS ON ACCESSIBILITY, COHERENCE, AND COMPREHENSIBILITY OF COMMUNICATIONS FOR HARD- TO-REACH POPULATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL 1) CREATE NEW AND MORE PRECISE MODELING OF WILDFIRE SMOKE RISK DATA FOR CALIFORNIAAND 2) CONDUCT A NEEDS ASSESSMENT OF WILDFIRE SMOKE RISK COMMUNICATIONAND 3) USE PARTICIPATORY DESIGN TO DEVELOP/REVISE RISK COMMUNICATIONS AND DISSEMINATION STRATEGIES FOR HARD-TO-REACH POPULATIONSAND AND 4)  TEST EFFECTIVENESS OF NEW/REVISED RISK COMMUNICATIONS AND DISSEMINATION STRATEGIES WITH USABILITY TESTING, FOCUS GROUPS AND INTERVIEWS.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: IMPROVED WILDFIRE-SMOKE RISK MAP AND MANAGEMENT FOR HARD-TO-REACH POPULATIONSAND HIGH-QUALITY RISK COMMUNICATION RESOURCESAND SUSTAINABLE STRATEGIES FOR LARGE-SCALE AND LOCALLY TARGETED DISSEMINATION STRATEGIESAND AND IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF BARRIERS AND SUPPORTS FOR WILDFIRE SMOKE HEALTH RISKS AND RISK COMMUNICATION NEEDS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITYAND STATE AND LOCAL ENTITIES WORKING TO REDUCE WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURESAND AND POPULATIONS AFFECTED BY WILDFIRE SMOKE EXPOSURE.

THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO CONDUCT FIELD AND LABORATORY RESEARCH TO ENABLE ACCURATE MODELING OF INTERVENTIONS INTENDED TO REDUCE INDOOR WOODSMOKE EXPOSURES. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF OUTDOOR TO INDOOR AIR POLLUTANT TRANSPORT IN SINGLE-FAMILY DETACHED HOMESAND EVALUATE COMMERCIAL AND LOW-COST AIR-CLEANING APPROACHES FOR PARTICLE AND GAS-PHASE POLLUTANTSAND CHARACTERIZE POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS (PAHS) ON INDOOR SURFACES TO ELUCIDATE HOW INDOOR WOODSMOKE MAY CAUSE LONG-TERM EXPOSURE TO PAHS INDOORS.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ASSESS PRACTICAL AND EFFECTIVE APPROACHES TO REDUCE INDOOR EXPOSURE TO PARTICULATE MATTER (PM) OF OUTDOOR WILDLAND FIRE ORIGIN IN SINGLE-FAMILY HOUSING IN THE WESTERN U.S. THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT FIELD STUDIES TO ASSESS A VARIETY OF SUSTAINABLE AND PRACTICAL INTERVENTIONS FOR REDUCING INDOOR PM LEVELS, SUCH AS INDOOR PARTICLE FILTRATION, VENTILATION STRATEGIES, AND BUILDING SEALING STRATEGIES. IN ADDITION, MODEL SIMULATIONS WILL BE USED TO INFER THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE INTERVENTIONS FOR VARIOUS SINGLE-FAMILY HOMES TYPES FOUND IN THE WESTERN US.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO INCREASE WILDFIRE SMOKE RISK MITIGATION IN RURAL COMMUNITIES NORTHERN NEVADA THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION OF STAKEHOLDER-DRIVEN MONITORING AND MESSAGING. RESEARCHERS WILL EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE OF SELECTED PORTABLE AIR QUALITY SENSORS AND PLACE THEM IN THREE RURAL NEVADA COUNTIES TO MONITOR AIR QUALITYAND DEVELOP EDUCATION MATERIALS TO REDUCE KNOWLEDGE GAPS IN WILDFIRE SMOKE RISK AMONG EMERGENCY MANAGERS AND THE PUBLICAND AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF IN AIR QUALITY MONITORING AND MESSAGING TO MITIGATE WILDFIRE SMOKE RISK.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO ENHANCE EXISTING EFFORTS TAKING PLACE IN WASHINGTON STATE TO IDENTIFY EVIDENCE-BASED SOLUTIONS UTILIZING PORTABLE AIR CLEANERS TO IMPROVE INDOOR AIR QUALITY IN SCHOOLS.  THE PROJECT WILL 1) IMPLEMENT A CLASSROOM-BASED INTERVENTION USING PORTABLE AIR CLEANERS TO REDUCE EXPOSURE TO WILDLAND FIRE SMOKE ACROSS 10 SCHOOLS IN WASHINGTON STATEAND 2) OBSERVE THE IMPACT OF THE INTERVENTION USING PORTABLE AIR CLEANERS ON RESPIRATORY HEALTH OF STUDENTS USING A RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED STUDY DESIGN WITHIN SCHOOLAND AND 3) ENGAGE WITH PARTICIPATING SCHOOLS TO ADAPT AN EXISTING HANDS-ON AIR QUALITY CURRICULUM AIMED AT INCREASING ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH LITERACY ON THE TOPIC OF AMBIENT SMOKE, AIR QUALITY AND HEALTH. THE EXPECTED OUTPUTS INCLUDE: 1) A MODEL OF SIZE-FRACTIONED PARTICLE INFILTRATION IN BOTH RURAL AND URBAN SCHOOLS THAT TAKES INTO ACCOUNT BUILDING TYPE, VENTILATION PARAMETERS, AND EXISTING FILTRATION TYPEAND 2) DIRECT EVALUATION OF THE EFFICACY OF REDUCING EXPOSURE TO WILDLAND FIRE SMOKE USING AN APPROPRIATELY SIZED PORTABLE AIR CLEANERS WITH AUTO MODE IN CLASSROOM SETTINGSAND AND 3) MEASURES OF THE ASSOCIATION BETWEEN INDOOR AIR QUALITY AND RESPIRATORY HEALTH IN A DIVERSE COHORT OF ELEMENTARY SCHOOL CHILDREN. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, STATE AND LOCAL ENTITIES WORKING WITH SCHOOL DISTRICTS, AND ELEMENTARY SCHOOL CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES. YAKAMA NATION AIR QUALITY SECTION WILL WORK WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON RESEARCHERS TO RESPOND TO TRIBAL PROGRAM NEED, ENSURE RELEVANCE TO THE COMMUNITY, PARTICIPATE IN DEVELOPING CULTURALLY-AWARE EDUCATIONAL MATERIAL THAT IS IN-LINE WITH REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS APPLICABLE ON YAKAMA NATION TRIBAL LAND, AND HELP ENSURE THAT THE RESEARCH TEAM DOES NOT INADVERTENTLY VIOLATE TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO INFORM PUBLIC HEALTH GUIDANCE ON IF (BASED ON SCHOOL AND NEARBY HOME CHARACTERISTICS) AND WHEN (I.E., AT WHAT AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI) OR PM2.5 CONCENTRATION LEVELS) SCHOOLS SHOULD CLOSE DURING WILDFIRE SMOKE EVENTS TO PROTECT THE HEALTH OF STUDENTS. TO ACHIEVE THE GOAL, RESEARCHERS WILL: 1)  INVESTIGATE FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE THE OUTDOOR TO INDOOR TRANSPORT OF PM2.5 INTO SCHOOLS AND STUDENTS&RSQUOAND HOMES DURING WILDFIRE EVENTSAND AND 2) ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PM2.5 LEVELS INSIDE AND OUTSIDE OF SCHOOLS AND CHILDREN&RSQUOANDS RESPIRATORY HEALTH.

THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE OF THIS CENTER IS TO MAKE CAUSAL LINKAGES BETWEEN CUMULATIVE ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURES, CAREGIVING ENVIRONMENTS IN EARLY CHILDHOOD, AND CHANGES IN NEURODEVELOPMENT FOR PRESCHOOLERS. THE STUDY WILL COMPLETE ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE ANALYSES AT BOTH THE HOME AND CHILDCARE CENTER, ALONG WITH NEURODEVELOPMENTAL AND CAREGIVING ENVIRONMENT EVALUATIONS. WITH THIS DATA, RESEARCHERS WILL LEVERAGE OBJECTIVE, PERFORMANCE-BASED MEASURES OF CHILDREN&RSQUOANDS COGNITIVE FUNCTION AND BEHAVIOR RATINGS TO INDEX NEURODEVELOPMENTAL FUNCTIONING TO CAUSALLY RELATE THEM TO CHEMICAL EXPOSURE.

RESEARCHERS WILL USE LONGITUDINAL STUDY DATA AND URINE SAMPLES FROM CHILDREN TO EXAMINE THE IMPACTS OF EARLY LIFE EXPOSURE TO PHTHALATES. THE STUDY WILL EVALUATE EXPOSURES IN RELATION TO NEUROBEHAVIOR DEVELOPMENT WITH ATTENTION TO THE POTENTIAL FOR SEX-SPECIFIC EFFECTS. ADDITIONALLY, THEY WILL EXAMINE HOW PRENATAL TOXICANT EXPOSURES RELATE TO 3RD TRIMESTER FETAL BRAIN IMAGING FEATURES, AND THEIR TRAJECTORIES OF DEVELOPMENT POSTNATALLY USING POSTNATAL IMAGING SCANS.

THIS RESEARCH SEEKS TO DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE INTEGRATIVE APPROACH, WHICH FUSES ANALYTICAL, COMPUTATIONAL, OBSERVATIONAL, AND STATISTICAL METHODS, TO ESTIMATE DUST/SOIL INGESTION RATES OF CHILDREN AGED 6 MONTHS THROUGH 6 YEARS WITH DEMOGRAPHIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABILITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE EXPOSURE SCIENTISTS WITH A HYBRID APPROACH TO ESTIMATE THE DUST/SOIL INGESTION RATE IN A DEFENSIBLE AND ACCURATE MANNER AND WILL PROVIDE HEALTH AND RISK ASSESSORS TABULATED, STRATIFIED ESTIMATES OF DUST/SOIL INGESTION RATES FOR SUBGROUPS OF CHILDREN OF INTEREST AND A HOLISTIC COMPUTATIONAL TOOL FOR POPULATION-OR SITE-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENTS.

RESEARCHERS WILL APPLY NEW TECHNOLOGIES IN BOTH DUST AND URINE ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE CHILD-SPECIFIC DUST INGESTION RATES, UNDER AN EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN THAT INCLUDES MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC AND SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS (SES) GROUPS. KEY OUTCOMES WILL BE TO: IDENTIFY A SET OF COMPOUNDS THAT SERVE AS OPTIMAL TRACERS OF DUST INGESTION THAT CAN EASILY BE APPLIED IN FUTURE MONITORING; ILLUSTRATE GEOGRAPHIC AND SES-BASED DIFFERENCES IN CHILDREN'S DUST INGESTION RATES AND CHEMICAL EXPOSURES; MEASURE DUST CONCENTRATIONS AND OVERALL CHEMICAL EXPOSURES FOR CHILDREN IN GEOGRAPHIC AND SES GROUPS NOT FREQUENTLY STUDIED; AND SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE RISK ASSESSMENT CALCULATIONS INVOLVING DUST INGESTION BY CHILDREN.

THIS PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON DEVELOPING AN ECOLOGICAL RISK ASSESSMENT FOR THE RELEASE OF A FULL SYNTHETIC MICROBIAL CELL (A SUBSET OF ALL SYNBIO ORGANISMS) INTO AN ENVIRONMENTAL MATRIX BY DEVELOPING THE BIOINFORMATIC TOOL ECOGENORISKSYNTHETIC BIOLOGICAL (SYNBIO) PRODUCTS POSE A UNIQUE CHALLENGE FOR EFFECTIVE ASSESSMENT AND MITIGATION OF RISKS. UNLIKE THE HANDLING OF CHEMICAL AGENTS, SELECT SYNBIO PRODUCTS MAINTAIN THE ABILITY TO ACTIVELY REPLICATE WITHIN THE ENVIRONMENT, COMPOUNDING ON THE MASS AND LOCATIONS REQUIRED TO MANAGE.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND, PREDICT, AND CONTROL THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN NATURAL SOIL MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES (SMCS) AND GENETICALLY ENGINEERED MICROBES (GEMS). SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL APPLY CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMPOSITION OF NATURAL SMCS TO CREATE LABORATORY MODEL SMCS TO MEASURE THE SURVIVAL AND PERSISTENCE OF GEMS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE CAPACITY OF DOMINANT SMC PHYLOTYPES TO CONTROL THE SURVIVAL AND PERSISTENCE OF GEMS.

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE BIOCONTAINMENT OF GENETICALLY ENGINEERED MICROBES  (GEMS) IN ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS AND GENERATE A NOVEL GEM KILL SWITCH RELEVANT TO BIOREMEDIATION. CONSISTENT WITH THE STATUTORY AUTHORITIES ABOVE, THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP FUNDAMENTAL SCIENTIFIC SCREENING AND MONITORING TECHNIQUES, AS IN SUBSECTIONS (C) AND (D), TO BETTER UNDERSTAND, ASSESS AND MITIGATE ENVIRONMENTAL RISKS OF WHILE ADVANCING RESEARCH ON THE RELIABILITY OF SUCH TECHNIQUES, AND IMPROVEMENTS ON MONITORING OF GEMS, PARTICULARLY FOR BROADLY USED BIOREMEDIATION APPLICATIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A ROBUST, DATA-DRIVEN MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT WILL ACCURATELY PREDICT THE OUTCOME OF A PRECISION GUIDED SYNTHETIC STERILE INSECT TECHNIQUE (PGSIT) TECHNOLOGY AIMED TO ELIMINATE THE AEDES AEGYPTI MOSQUITO VECTOR RESPONSIBLE FOR DENGUE OUTBREAKS IN THE HAWAII REGION.

THIS PROJECT COMBINES METAGENOMIC TECHNIQUES WITH MICROBIAL CULTURE METHODS TO CONDUCT MICROBIAL SOURCE TRACKING, POPULATE A BIOINFORMATICS LIBRARY, AND MONITOR GENETICALLY RECODED ORGANISMS IMPACTS ON NATURAL FRESHWATER MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL ELUCIDATE DETERMINANTS OF INDOOR DUST INGESTION IN 6- TO 24-MONTH-OLD INFANTS. RESEARCHERS WILL TEST IF THE FREQUENCY AND CHARACTERISTICS OF INDOOR DUST AND NON-DUST MOUTHING EVENTS CHANGE WITH AGE AND MOTOR DEVELOPMENT STAGE FOR DIFFERENT MICRO-ENVIRONMENTS, AND HOW HOME CHARACTERISTICS AND DEMOGRAPHIC FACTORS AFFECT INDOOR DUST MASS LOADING AND DUST TOXICANT CONCENTRATION. THE PROJECT ALSO EXAMINES HOW DUST TRANSFER IS INFLUENCED BY DUST PROPERTIES, SURFACE FEATURES, AND CONTACT DYNAMICS; AND CONTRIBUTIONS OF DEVELOPMENTAL, BEHAVIORAL, AND SOCIO-ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS TO DUST AND TOXICANT-RESOLVED DUST INGESTION RATES.

RESEARCHERS WILL PERFORM STUDIES TO QUANTIFY DUST LOADING ON CHILDRENS HANDS AND INDOOR HOME SURFACES AND WILL ALSO DELIVER A HOUSEHOLD DUST SURVEY TO FAMILIES FOR ANALYSIS OF KEY VARIABLES INFLUENCING DUST LOADING ON CHILDRENS HANDS AND IN HOMES AND INGESTION RATES. BY COLLECTING CHILDRENS HAND CONTACT AND MOUTHING ACTIVITIES IN HOMES THROUGH VIDEO METHODS, RESEARCHERS WILL EXPAND THE DATABASE OF CHILDRENS MICRO-ACTIVITIES TO INCLUDE KEY ENVIRONMENTS, LOCATIONS, AND SOCIODEMOGRAPHIC GROUPS. FINALLY, RESEARCHERS WILL ENHANCE AN EXISTING MODEL TO CAPTURE ADDITIONAL SOIL/DUST PATHWAYS FOR CHILDRENS DERMAL AND NON-DIETARY INGESTION.

RESEARCHERS WILL ASSESS DUST AND SOIL EXPOSURES FOR CHILDREN AGES SIX MONTHS TO SIX YEARS VIA MACRO-AND MICRO-ACTIVITY PATTERN AND TRACER STUDIES. RESEARCHERS WILL CREATE A NOVEL, INTEGRATED TOOLSET BASED ON MAJOR INNOVATIONS IN ACTIVITY PATTERNS AND TRACER STUDIES THAT WILL ADDRESS ALL FOUR KEY COMPONENTS NEEDED TO QUANTIFY CHILDREN&RSQUOANDS SOIL AND DUST EXPOSURE. THIS PROPOSED WORK WILL YIELD NOVEL INSIGHTS NECESSARY TO REFINE AND INCREASE CONFIDENCE IN SOIL AND DUST INGESTION ESTIMATES FOR YOUNG CHILDREN.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IMPLEMENT AN INNOVATIVE METHODOLOGY BASED ON NON-TARGETED SCREENING APPROACH TO IDENTIFY SPECIFIC TRACERS OF DUST AND SOIL EXPOSURE. RESEARCHERS WILL COMBINE THIS WITH RELEVANT INFORMATION ON CHILDREN'S BEHAVIOR AND OTHER CHARACTERISTICS TO PROVIDE A MORE ACCURATE ESTIMATE OF SOIL AND DUST INGESTION RATES. THE STUDY INCLUDES FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN FROM 6 MONTHS TO 6 YEARS. RESEARCHERS WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS/INTERVIEWS AND COLLECT ENVIRONMENTAL/BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES TO IDENTIFY HEALTH RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH CHEMICAL EXPOSURE TO YOUNG CHILDREN VIA SOIL AND DUST INGESTION.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND AND MITIGATE THE CURRENT AND POSSIBLE FUTURE SOIL HEAVY METAL AND METALLOID AND OTHER CHEMICAL CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE AMONG CHILDREN IN WEST ATLANTA BY ESTIMATING CHILDRENS SOIL INGESTION RATES. USING TARGETED AND NON-TARGETED SOIL ANALYSES, RESEARCHERS WILL CREATE A DETAILED MAP SHOWING THE SOIL ABUNDANCES OF LEAD AND OTHER CHEMICAL CONTAMINANTS IN WEST ATLANTA, WHERE HIGH CONTAMINATION WAS RECENTLY FOUND. CHILDRENS EXPOSURE TO LEAD AND OTHER CHEMICALS WILL ALSO BE QUANTIFIED USING SURVEY DATA AND BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES.

PRIVATE WELLS ARE THE DRINKING WATER SOURCE FOR OVER 43 MILLION U.S. HOUSEHOLDS AND ARE VULNERABLE TO CONTAMINATION FROM ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS DURING SEVERE WEATHER, ESPECIALLY THOSE HOUSEHOLDS NEAR CONTAMINATED SITES. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE IMPACTS OF EXPOSURE TO CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER ON BIRTH OUTCOMES. RESEARCHERS WILL SYNTHESIZE SOIL, HYDROLOGICAL, METEOROLOGICAL AND BUILT INFRASTRUCTURE DATA ALONGSIDE A STATEWIDE DATABASE OF PRIVATE WELL TESTING TO PREDICT CONTAMINATION EVENTS USING ECONOMETRIC AND MACHINE LEARNING TECHNIQUES.

THIS PROJECT WILL OPTIMIZE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF NUTRIENT TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES GUIDED DIRECTLY BY THE ECOLOGICAL RESPONSE OF THE WATERSHED (I.E., ALGAL PRODUCTION) FOR EFFECTIVE HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOM CONTROL. THE RESEARCH AIMS TO DEVELOP A HOLISTIC ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK FOR EVALUATING EXISTING AND EMERGING NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES/STRATEGIES AS WELL AS INTEGRATE HYDRO-ECOLOGICAL MODELS OF TEMPORAL ALGAE PRODUCTION WITH NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT OPTIMIZATION MODELS.

THE OVERALL PROJECT GOAL IS TO DEVELOP AND SCALE UP AN INNOVATIVE BIOREACTOR AND BIOCHAR-SORPTION-CHANNEL (B2) TREATMENT SYSTEM TO EFFECTIVELY CAPTURE NUTRIENTS FROM SUBSURFACE DRAINAGE WATER, RECYCLE NUTRIENT-CAPTURED BIOCHARS AS A SLOW-RELEASE FERTILIZER, AND KEEP NUTRIENTS IN THE CLOSED AGRICULTURAL LOOP. THIS PROJECT WILL OFFER AN INNOVATIVE, FEASIBLE, AND COST-EFFECTIVE PRACTICE TO MITIGATE NUTRIENT POLLUTION IN WATERSHEDS FROM AGRICULTURAL FIELDS, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY, AND THEREBY DIMINISH THE OCCURRENCE OF HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS).

THE RECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP AND ACCELERATE THREE INNOVATIVE HIGH-FLOW WATER TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES THAT CAN REMOVE PHOSPHORUS TO ULTRALOW LEVELS. THE RECIPIENT WILL ANALYZE LOW-PHOSPHOROUS REACTIVE FILTRATION TECHNOLOGY AND DEVELOP NEW PHOSPHOROUS FILTRATION TECHNOLOGY. THEIR INNOVATIVE WATER TECHNOLOGIES WILL REMOVE >99% OF TOTAL PHOSPHORUS TO NUTRIENT LEVELS LOW ENOUGH TO HEAL ALGAE IMPACTED NATURAL WATERS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO IMPROVE FULL-SCALE APPLICATIONS OF SHORTCUT NITROGEN REMOVAL PROCESSES BY INCREASING NITRITE AVAILABILITY FOR ANAEROBIC AMMONIUM OXIDIZING BACTERIA (ANAMMOX) IN MAINSTREAM SYSTEMS. WITH THE OPPORTUNITY FOR INNOVATIVE FULL-SCALE PROCESS DEPLOYMENT OVER THE TIMEFRAME OF THIS THREE-YEAR PROJECT, THE PROJECT INCLUDES A UTILITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE (UAC) ENGAGING TECHNICAL REPRESENTATIVES FROM 8 PROGRESSIVE UTILITIES IN HAB HOTSPOT REGIONS INCLUDING THE GREAT LAKES, MIDWEST, AND FLORIDA.

THE PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A NOVEL TECHNOLOGY THAT WILL PREVENT HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS IN WATERING PONDS. THE RESEARCH INVOLVES THE SYNTHESIS OF EIGHT CANDIDATE MAGNESIUM-ALUMINUM OXIDE AND MAGNESIUM-IRON OXIDE SORBENT MEDIAS FOR THE UPTAKE OF UREA, AMMONIUM, PHOSPHATE, AND NITRATE IONS. THE TECHNOLOGY WILL ALLOW FOR THE ABSORBED NUTRIENTS TO BE USED AS A TIME-RELEASE FERTILIZER. THE GOAL WILL BE TO CREATE A SUSTAINABLE SOLUTION FOR THE PREVENTION OF HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS AND REDUCE THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND FINANCIAL COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH FERTILIZER PRODUCTION AND DECONTAMINATION OF PONDS.

THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE GROWING CONCERNS CAUSED BY HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS) BY DEVELOPING A ROBUST, ENVIRONMENTALLY-SUSTAINABLE, AND WIDELY APPLICABLE NUTRIENT REMOVAL/RECOVERY TECHNOLOGY BASED ON A MINERAL-HYDROGEL COMPOSITE. THE COMPOSITE WILL BE OPTIMIZED TO ACHIEVE A TARGET NUTRIENT REMOVAL PERFORMANCE AND VALIDATED WITH REGARDS TO ITS PERFORMANCE AND EFFECTS ON MODEL ALGAL ECOSYSTEMS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DEMONSTRATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF FARM RUNOFF TREATMENT SYSTEMS IN REDUCING NUTRIENT DISCHARGES TO COASTAL WATERWAYS AND PROVIDE A BLUEPRINT FOR SCALING-UP TREATMENT SYSTEMS WITHIN TWO KEY AGRICULTURAL WATERSHEDS OF THE MONTEREY BAY, CA. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL LINK BETWEEN AGRICULTURAL NUTRIENT DISCHARGES AND THE GROWTH OF HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS (HABS).

NATURAL DISASTERS CAN SUBSTANTIALLY INCREASE POLLUTANT RELEASES FROM INDUSTRIAL FACILITIES, OFTEN LOCATED IN VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE OF AN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY IN HOUSTON TO HURRICANE/FLOOD-INDUCED RELEASES OF METALS AND VOCS. RESEARCHERS WILL CHARACTERIZE THE POTENTIAL FOR HURRICANES/FLOODS TO CAUSE RELEASES OF POLLUTANTS FROM STORAGE FACILITIES, AS WELL AS NON-CHEMICAL STRESSORS IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO IDENTIFY INFRASTRUCTURE SOLUTIONS TO REDUCE RISKS FROM POLLUTANTS RELEASED BY INDUSTRIAL FACILITIES.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO UNDERSTAND HOW FLOODING CAUSED BY HURRICANES INFLUENCES DISTRIBUTION OF PFAS AND HOW SOCIETAL FACTORS CAN EXACERBATE IMPACTS OF PFAS EXPOSURE. RESEARCHERS WILL CHARACTERIZE PFAS SPECIES DIVERSITY AND CONCENTRATION RANGES IN WATER, SOIL, SEDIMENTS, AND BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES BEFORE AND IMMEDIATELY AFTER A FLOODING EVENT. RESEARCH WILL DESIGN A SIMULATION MODEL TO FORECAST PFAS TRANSPORT AND RISK EXPOSURE OF DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES AFTER FLOODING EVENTS. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO BUILD COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TO REDUCE EXPOSURE AND POSSIBLE HEALTH EFFECTS OF PFAS.

THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A GENERALIZABLE AND COMPREHENSIVE RISK ANALYSIS FRAMEWORK THAT LINKS NATURAL HAZARDS AND CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS TO THE RELEASE, FATE, AND TRANSPORT OF CONTAMINANTS. RESEARCHERS WILL DEVELOP A SYSTEMS MODEL THAT WILL PROVIDE COMMUNITIES THE CAPACITY TO CHARACTERIZE RISKS THAT RESULT FROM INTERACTIONS ACROSS NATURAL, TECHNOLOGICAL, AND SOCIOECONOMIC SYSTEMS. COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL ENABLE TRANSLATION OF MODELS INTO IMPROVED COMMUNITY READINESS AND RESILIENCE TO NATURAL DISASTER DRIVEN CONTAMINANT EXPOSURES.

THIS PROJECT WILL INTRODUCE COMMUNITY-BASED RISK REDUCTION EFFORTS AIMED TO DECREASE RISK AND INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF VULNERABLE OLDER POPULATIONS IN PUERTO RICO FOLLOWING FLOODING EVENTS. RESEARCHERS WILL MODEL WASTEWATER CONTAMINANTS IN FLOODING EVENTS TO IDENTIFY HOTSPOTS OF CONTAMINANTS AND THEIR PROXIMITY TO VULNERABLE, OLDER ADULT POPULATIONS. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO DETERMINE WHAT MODIFYING PSYCHOSOCIAL FACTORS MAY AFFECT THE VULNERABILITY OF OLDER ADULTS TO RISK POSED BY CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE. RESULTS WILL PROVIDE SPATIAL INFORMATION ON MULTIPLE RISK FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH FLOODING.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ANALYZE AND COMMUNICATE THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF COASTAL FLOODING OF CONTAMINATED SITES ON VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES. RESEARCHERS WILL DERIVE AREA-LEVEL MEASURES OF BIOLOGICAL SUSCEPTIBILITY AND SOCIAL VULNERABILITY TO CHARACTERIZE THE VULNERABILITY OF COMMUNITIES LIVING NEAR TO SITES WITH EXCESS RELEASES. RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO DEVELOP ACCESSIBLE, BILINGUAL ONLINE MAPPING AND DATA VISUALIZATION TOOLS AND IN-PERSON ROUNDTABLES IN THREE AT-RISK COASTAL COMMUNITIES ON THE EAST, WEST, AND GULF COASTS.

THE PROJECT INVOLVES A STUDY OF GUT AND BLOOD-BRAIN-BARRIER PERMEABILITY TO 100 DIVERSE CHEMICALS TO MAKE TWO PREDICTIVE MODELS: A MASS-BALANCE MODEL AND A QUANTITATIVE STRUCTURE-ACTIVITY RELATIONSHIP (QSAR) MODEL. THE NEW PHARMACOKINETIC DATA WILL THEN PARAMETERIZE A PHYSIOLOGICALLY-BASED TOXICOKINETIC MODEL & BE VALIDATED AGAINST BIODISTRIBUTION DATA.

THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH METHODS WITHIN A RISK-BASED DECISION FRAMEWORK FOR USING NEW APPROACH METHODOLOGIES (NAMS) BY INTEGRATING NEW BIOLOGICAL (I.E. TISSUE CHIPS), ANALYTICAL, AND COMPUTATIONAL MODELING METHODS FOR DATA-DRIVEN IN VITRO ' IN VIVO EXTRAPOLATIONS (IVIVE). THE DATA-DRIVEN TOXICOKINETIC MODELING DEVELOPED WILL BE TESTED WITH A WIDE RANGE OF CHEMICAL COMPOUNDS AND CHEMICAL MIXTURES DEVISED TO MODEL REALISTIC REAL-WORLD EXPOSURES.

THIS PROJECT WILL FILL A FUNDAMENTAL GAP ON ORGAN-ON-A-CHIP TOXICITY SCREENING DEVICES TO ASSESS HOW CHEMICAL TO DEVICE SUBSTRATE CONTACT AFFECT THEIR TOXICOKINETICS. A QUANTITATIVE STRUCTURE-PROPERTY RELATIONSHIP (QSPR) MODEL WILL BE DEVELOPED TO PREDICT CHEMICAL-POLYDIMETHYLSILOXANE (PDMS) INTERACTIONS. AFTER INITIAL TESTING OF A SET OF 54 CHEMICALS, THE NEW QSPR MODEL WILL BE USED TO PREDICT SEQUESTRATION INTO PDMS FOR A WIDER SET OF CHEMICALS AND SHOULD ENABLE PROSPECTIVE TOXICOKINETIC MODELING FOR ANY CHEMICAL.

THIS PROJECT WILL DETERMINE THE METABOLIC ACTIVITIES OF KEY XENOBIOTIC-METABOLIZING ENZYMES IN TRANSGENIC KNOCKOUT ZEBRAFISH, OFTEN USED IN TOXICITY ASSESSMENTS. PARENT AND PRIMARY METABOLITE PROFILES FOR TOP HIT COMPOUNDS WILL BE DETERMINED, AND MORE DETAILED KINETIC ASSAYS WILL BE PERFORMED ON THEM. A NOVEL MULTIPLEXED MULTIDIMENSIONAL GCXGC-MS IDENTIFICATION WILL CHARACTERIZE THE METABOLITE PROFILES FOR SELECTED INDIVIDUAL COMPOUNDS, AND WILL BE USABLE FOR OTHERS.

THE PROJECT WILL DETERMINE THE BIDIRECTIONAL PERMEABILITY OF MARKER COMPOUNDS TO DETERMINE THE PERMEATION OF 50 KNOWN ENVIRONMENTAL TOXICANTS. THEY WILL INTEGRATE A HUMAN CELL-BASED MODEL OF THE BLOOD-BRAIN BARRIER TO MEASURE COMPOUND PERMEABILITY. THEIR PHYSIOLOGICAL-BASED PHARMACOKINETIC (PBPK) MODELS WILL IMPROVE ACCURACY IN PREDICTING DOSES OF CONCERN OF CHEMICALS THAT CAUSE PERTURBATIONS IN BRAIN CELL-BASED ASSAYS.

THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO IMPROVE CURRENTLY EXISTING CHEMICAL MECHANISMS USED IN THE GEOS-CHEM MODEL FOR AIR QUALITY SIMULATION AND ITS IMPLICATIONS. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO IMPLEMENT A COMMON FRAMEWORK FOR GEOS-CHEM CHEMICAL MECHANISMS; IMPROVE EXISTING MECHANISMS FOR AEROSOL, HALOGENS, MERCURY AND ISOPRENE CHEMISTRY; INCREASE COMPUTATIONAL SPEED USING ADAPTIVE REDUCTION AND MACHINE-LEARNING TECHNIQUES; AND APPLY THE UPDATED MODEL TO ESTIMATE BACKGROUND INFLUENCES AND INTERFERENCES ON AIR QUALITY MODELS.

THE PRIMARY OUTCOME OF THIS RESEARCH WILL BE THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN ALGORITHM AND ASSOCIATED TOOL TO GENERATE ACCURATE AND SIMPLIFIED CHEMICAL MECHANISMS USED IN AIR QUALITY MODELS. SPECIFIC FOCUS OF THIS WORK WILL BE ON THE GAS-PHASE CHEMISTRY OF ISOPRENE. THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO LEAD TO IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF ISOPRENE CHEMISTRY AND MODELING OF AIR QUALITY.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT WILL TO DEVELOP CHEMICAL MECHANISMS THAT ARE ACCURATE AND COMPUTATIONALLY EFFICIENT FOR USE IN AIR QUALITY MODELS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON APPLYING MACHINE LEARNING NEURAL NETWORK-BASED TECHNIQUES FOR CREATING CHEMICAL MECHANISMS THAT OVERCOME COMPUTATIONAL BARRIERS. THE RESEARCH IS EXPECTED TO LEAD TO MUCH FASTER ALGORITHMS FOR SIMULATING ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY IN AIR QUALITY MODELS.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A DIAGNOSTIC SOFTWARE PACKAGE, BASED ON MACHINE LEARNING, TO IDENTIFY THE KEY ELEMENTS OF A CHEMICAL MECHANISM TO AID THE FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF AIR QUALITY MODELS (AQMS); AS WELL AS TO CREATE A CHEMICAL MECHANISM EMULATOR THAT CAN BE USED AS AN ALTERNATIVE, COMPUTATIONALLY INEXPENSIVE METHOD TO SIMULATE ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO GREATLY SIMPLIFY APPLICATION-SPECIFIC MODEL DEVELOPMENT, AS WILL BE DEMONSTRATED USING THE REGIONAL CMAQ AND GLOBAL GEOS-CHEM AIR QUALITY MODELS.

THIS RESEARCH IS EXPECTED TO LEAD TO TWO GREATLY IMPROVED CHEMICAL MECHANISMS THAT ARE COMMONLY USED FOR ATMOSPHERIC RESEARCH AND AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE KEY VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS CONTRIBUTING TO OZONE FORMATION IN U.S. URBAN AREAS. THE SPECIFIC FOCUS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE ON ADDING GAS-PHASE CHEMISTRY OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS EMITTED FROM VOLATILE CHEMICAL PRODUCTS (VCPS).

THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO IMPROVE THE CHEMICAL MECHANISM REPRESENTATION OF SECONDARY ORGANIC AEROSOL (SOA) FORMATION FROM OXYGENATED VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS) IN BIOMASS BURNING AND VOLATILE CHEMICAL PRODUCTS (VCP) SOURCES. THIS PROPOSAL HYPOTHESIZES THAT THE INCLUSION OF OXYGENATED VOCS, PARTICULARLY PHENOLS, FURANS, GLYCOLS, AND GLYCOL ETHERS, IN CHEMICAL MECHANISMS WILL IMPROVE PREDICTIONS OF SOA FORMATION AND PROPERTIES BY AIR QUALITY MODELS (AQMS).

THE PRIMARY OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE IMPROVEMENT OF DATA AND TOOLS USED FOR GENERATING EXPLICIT AND DETAILED CHEMICAL MECHANISMS.  SPECIFIC FOCUS OF THIS WORK WILL BE ON ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY OF AIR POLLUTANTS FROM EMERGING SOURCES, SUCH AS WILDLAND FIRES AND VOLATILE CONSUMER PRODUCTS.  THE UPDATED DATA AND TOOLS ARE EXPECTED TO LEAD TO A GREATLY IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY AND IMPROVED AIR QUALITY MODELS.

THE PROJECT WILL UPDATE THE CHEMICAL MECHANISMS RELATED TO DINITROGEN PENTOXIDE (N2O5) CHEMISTRY IN THE CMAQ AIR QUALITY MODEL AND USE THE IMPROVED CMAQ MODEL TO INVESTIGATE THE INFLUENCE OF N2O5 CHEMISTRY ON NOX, OZONE AND FINE PM.  THE RESEARCH WILL GENERATE PUBLICATIONS AND FINDINGS THAT LEAD TO IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF N2O5 CHEMISTRY AND ITS IMPACTS ON THE FORMATION, FATE, AND TRANSPORT OF NOX, OZONE, AND FINE PARTICULATE MATTER (PM), WHICH ARE AIR POLLUTANTS ASSOCIATED WITH ADVERSE HEALTH IMPACTS.

THE PRIMARY OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A GENERAL, SCALABLE APPROACH TOWARDS THE CONSTRUCTION OF CHEMICAL MECHANISMS THAT REPRODUCE THE KEY PROPERTIES AND REACTIVITIES OF ORGANIC COMPOUNDS. THE SPECIFIC FOCUS OF THIS WORK WILL BE A FEW CLASSES OF ORGANIC SPECIES (ALKANES, MONOTERPENES, AND AROMATICS), AND THE STUDY OF THOSE SYSTEMS (E.G., MODEL-MEASUREMENT COMPARISONS, THE DEVELOPMENT OF REDUCED MECHANISMS) IS EXPECTED TO LEAD TO A GREATLY IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR CHEMISTRY.

THE PROPOSAL INCORPORATES A SYSTEMATIC ANALYTICAL STRATEGY TO IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY THE OCCURRENCE OF PER - AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) IN LANDFILL LEACHATE, INVESTIGATING THE FATE OF PFAS PASSING THROUGH TYPICAL LANDFILL LINER SYSTEMS, TOOLS TO ESTIMATE PFAS MASS FLUX FROM LANDFILLS, AND A RELATIVELY NOVEL TREATMENT TECHNIQUE, I.E., ULTRA SONICATION, TO EXPLORE ITS EFFICACY IN DECOMPOSING PFAS FROM LANDFILL LEACHATE.

THE PROJECT DEVELOPS PRACTICAL STRATEGIES FOR REMOVING LEGACY AND EMERGING OF PER - AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) FROM LEACHATE AND GROUNDWATER.
